\hypertarget{introduction-variables-as-memory-containers}{%
\section{1. Introduction: Variables as Memory
Containers}\label{introduction-variables-as-memory-containers}}

In programming, variables are named storage locations that hold data
values in your computer's memory. Think of them as labeled containers
that let you store, access, and modify information throughout your
program.

Without variables, we would have to use literal values everywhere,
making our code inflexible and difficult to maintain. Variables allow us
to:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Store data for later use
\item
  Give meaningful names to values
\item
  Change values during program execution
\item
  Track program state and progress
\item
  Make code more readable and maintainable
\end{itemize}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Key Concept}: Variables connect the abstract world of values
with meaningful names that make sense to humans. By naming our data, we
can work with it more effectively and make our code more understandable.
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{creating-variables-the-assignment-statement}{%
\section{2. Creating Variables: The Assignment
Statement}\label{creating-variables-the-assignment-statement}}

In Python, you create a variable by assigning a value using the
\texttt{=} operator. This process is called assignment:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Creating variables with different data types}
\NormalTok{user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alice"}       \CommentTok{\# A string variable}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{25}                  \CommentTok{\# An integer variable}
\NormalTok{height }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{5.9}              \CommentTok{\# A float variable}
\NormalTok{is\_student }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}         \CommentTok{\# A boolean variable}
\NormalTok{favorite\_colors }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"blue"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"green"}\NormalTok{]  }\CommentTok{\# A list variable}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When Python executes an assignment statement: 1. The expression on the
right side is evaluated first 2. Memory is allocated to store the
resulting value 3. The variable name on the left is connected to that
memory location

\hypertarget{dynamic-typing}{%
\subsection{Dynamic Typing}\label{dynamic-typing}}

Python is a dynamically-typed language, which means the type of a
variable is determined by its assigned value, not by an explicit
declaration:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Variable types are determined by their values}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}          \CommentTok{\# x is now an integer}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{type}\NormalTok{(x))  }\CommentTok{\# \textless{}class \textquotesingle{}int\textquotesingle{}\textgreater{}}

\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"hello"}     \CommentTok{\# x is now a string}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{type}\NormalTok{(x))  }\CommentTok{\# \textless{}class \textquotesingle{}str\textquotesingle{}\textgreater{}}

\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{]   }\CommentTok{\# x is now a list}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{type}\NormalTok{(x))  }\CommentTok{\# \textless{}class \textquotesingle{}list\textquotesingle{}\textgreater{}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The type of a variable can change during program execution as you assign
different values to it. This flexibility is powerful but requires
careful attention.

\hypertarget{variable-naming-rules-and-conventions}{%
\section{3. Variable Naming: Rules and
Conventions}\label{variable-naming-rules-and-conventions}}

Choosing good variable names is essential for writing clear,
maintainable code. Python has specific rules and conventions for naming
variables:

\hypertarget{rules-these-are-enforced-by-python}{%
\subsection{Rules (These are enforced by
Python)}\label{rules-these-are-enforced-by-python}}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Must start with a letter or underscore (\_)
\item
  Can only contain letters, numbers, and underscores
\item
  Cannot be a Python reserved keyword (like \texttt{if}, \texttt{for},
  \texttt{class}, etc.)
\item
  Names are case-sensitive (\texttt{name} and \texttt{Name} are
  different variables)
\end{itemize}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Valid variable names}
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alice"}
\NormalTok{\_hidden }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}
\NormalTok{count\_2 }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{42}
\NormalTok{first\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Bob"}

\CommentTok{\# Invalid variable names}
\CommentTok{\# 2count = 10        \# Cannot start with a number}
\CommentTok{\# my{-}variable = 5    \# Cannot use hyphens}
\CommentTok{\# class = "Python"   \# Cannot use Python keywords}
\CommentTok{\# $price = 19.99     \# Cannot use special characters}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{conventions-best-practices-recommended-by-pep-8}{%
\subsection{Conventions (Best practices recommended by PEP
8)}\label{conventions-best-practices-recommended-by-pep-8}}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Use lowercase letters for variable names
\item
  Separate words with underscores (snake\_case)
\item
  Choose descriptive, meaningful names
\item
  Use plural names for collections
\end{itemize}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Following naming conventions (do this)}
\NormalTok{user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alice"}
\NormalTok{items\_count }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{42}
\NormalTok{active\_users }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Bob"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Charlie"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{is\_registered }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}

\CommentTok{\# Not following conventions (avoid these)}
\NormalTok{UserName }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alice"}     \CommentTok{\# PascalCase is for classes}
\NormalTok{itemscount }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{42}        \CommentTok{\# Words run together}
\NormalTok{a }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Bob"}\NormalTok{]   }\CommentTok{\# Too short and non{-}descriptive}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Readability Tip}: Write code as if someone else will read it
later. That someone might be you in six months, struggling to remember
what your code does.
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{changing-variable-values}{%
\section{4. Changing Variable Values}\label{changing-variable-values}}

One of the most powerful features of variables is that their values can
change during program execution:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Changing a variable\textquotesingle{}s value}
\NormalTok{score }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}           \CommentTok{\# Initial score}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(score)        }\CommentTok{\# Output: 0}

\NormalTok{score }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}          \CommentTok{\# Score changed}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(score)        }\CommentTok{\# Output: 10}

\NormalTok{score }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{5}   \CommentTok{\# Update based on current value}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(score)        }\CommentTok{\# Output: 15}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{compound-assignment-operators}{%
\subsection{Compound Assignment
Operators}\label{compound-assignment-operators}}

Python provides shorthand operators for updating variables:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Compound assignment operators}
\NormalTok{count }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}
\NormalTok{count }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{5}      \CommentTok{\# Same as: count = count + 5}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(count)    }\CommentTok{\# Output: 15}

\NormalTok{message }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Hello"}
\NormalTok{message }\OperatorTok{+=} \StringTok{" World"}  \CommentTok{\# Same as: message = message + " World"}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(message)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Hello World}

\NormalTok{num }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}
\NormalTok{num }\OperatorTok{*=} \DecValTok{2}        \CommentTok{\# Same as: num = num * 2}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(num)      }\CommentTok{\# Output: 20}

\NormalTok{value }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{100}
\NormalTok{value }\OperatorTok{{-}=} \DecValTok{25}     \CommentTok{\# Same as: value = value {-} 25}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(value)    }\CommentTok{\# Output: 75}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Other compound operators include \texttt{//=} (floor division),
\texttt{/=} (division), \texttt{\%=} (modulo), and \texttt{**=}
(exponentiation).

\hypertarget{multiple-assignment-and-value-swapping}{%
\section{5. Multiple Assignment and Value
Swapping}\label{multiple-assignment-and-value-swapping}}

Python allows assigning values to multiple variables in a single
statement:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Multiple assignment}
\NormalTok{x, y, z }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(x, y, z)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 1 2 3}

\CommentTok{\# Assigning the same value to multiple variables}
\NormalTok{a }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ b }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ c }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a, b, c)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 0 0 0}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

A common use case is swapping variable values:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Swapping values (traditional way in many languages)}
\NormalTok{a }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5}
\NormalTok{b }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}

\NormalTok{temp }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ a}
\NormalTok{a }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ b}
\NormalTok{b }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ temp}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a, b)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 10 5}

\CommentTok{\# Python\textquotesingle{}s elegant way to swap values}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{1}
\NormalTok{y }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{2}

\NormalTok{x, y }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ y, x}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(x, y)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 2 1}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{constants-variables-that-shouldnt-change}{%
\section{6. Constants: Variables That Shouldn't
Change}\label{constants-variables-that-shouldnt-change}}

Constants are values that should not change during program execution.
Python doesn't have built-in constants, but there's a convention to use
uppercase names for values that shouldn't be modified:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Constants (by convention)}
\NormalTok{PI }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{3.14159}
\NormalTok{MAX\_RETRY\_COUNT }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{3}
\NormalTok{DEFAULT\_USERNAME }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"guest"}
\NormalTok{DATABASE\_URL }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"mongodb://localhost:27017"}

\CommentTok{\# Regular variables}
\NormalTok{current\_user }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alice"}
\NormalTok{retry\_count }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Following this convention helps other programmers (and your future self)
understand which values should remain unchanged.

\textbf{\emph{AI Collaboration Corner: Naming Variables}}

When asking AI for help with variable naming, be specific about your
context:

Instead of:

\begin{verbatim}
What should I name my variables?
\end{verbatim}

Try:

\begin{verbatim}
I'm building a shopping cart system with these pieces of data:
- The items a user has selected to purchase
- The total price of all items
- Whether the cart has been checked out
- The user's shipping address
- The date when the order was placed

Could you suggest clear, descriptive variable names that follow Python
conventions for these data points? Also, which ones might be good candidates
for constants instead of variables?
\end{verbatim}

The second prompt gives specific context about your project and data,
leading to more relevant naming suggestions. It also asks for guidance
on variables vs.~constants, adding another layer of value.

\hypertarget{variable-scope-where-variables-live}{%
\section{7. Variable Scope: Where Variables
Live}\label{variable-scope-where-variables-live}}

In Python, a variable's scope determines where in your code the variable
is accessible:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Global scope (accessible throughout the program)}
\NormalTok{global\_var }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m available everywhere"}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ my\_function():}
    \CommentTok{\# Local scope (only accessible within this function)}
\NormalTok{    local\_var }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m only available inside this function"}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(global\_var)  }\CommentTok{\# Can access global\_var}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(local\_var)   }\CommentTok{\# Can access local\_var}

\NormalTok{my\_function()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(global\_var)      }\CommentTok{\# Can access global\_var}
\CommentTok{\# print(local\_var)     \# Error! Can\textquotesingle{}t access local\_var outside the function}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

We'll cover scope in more detail when we discuss functions in later
chapters.

\hypertarget{project-corner-building-chatbot-state-with-variables}{%
\section{8. Project Corner: Building Chatbot State with
Variables}\label{project-corner-building-chatbot-state-with-variables}}

Let's enhance our chatbot by using variables to track the conversation
state:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{PyBot: A Python chatbot with memory}
\CommentTok{Version 0.4: Using variables to track state}
\CommentTok{"""}

\CommentTok{\# Bot configuration (constants)}
\NormalTok{BOT\_NAME }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}
\NormalTok{VERSION }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"0.4"}
\NormalTok{CREATOR }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Your Name"}

\CommentTok{\# Bot state variables (will change during execution)}
\NormalTok{user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}
\NormalTok{message\_count }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\NormalTok{last\_topic }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}
\NormalTok{greeting\_shown }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{False}
\NormalTok{favorite\_color }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}

\CommentTok{\# Display personalized greeting}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ display\_greeting():}
    \CommentTok{"""Display greeting based on chatbot state."""}
    \KeywordTok{global}\NormalTok{ greeting\_shown, user\_name}

    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ greeting\_shown:}
        \CommentTok{\# First{-}time greeting}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{BOT\_NAME}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{BOT\_NAME}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, version }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{VERSION}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        user\_name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input  }\CommentTok{\# Store name in a variable for later use}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{BOT\_NAME}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        greeting\_shown }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}  \CommentTok{\# Update state variable}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Returning user greeting}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{BOT\_NAME}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Welcome back, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Process user message}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_message(message):}
    \CommentTok{"""Process user message and update state variables."""}
    \KeywordTok{global}\NormalTok{ message\_count, last\_topic, favorite\_color}

    \CommentTok{\# Increment message counter}
\NormalTok{    message\_count }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}

    \CommentTok{\# Convert to lowercase for easier processing}
\NormalTok{    message }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ message.lower()}

    \CommentTok{\# Update last topic based on message content}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"weather"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ message:}
\NormalTok{        last\_topic }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"weather"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"food"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ message:}
\NormalTok{        last\_topic }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"food"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"color"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ message:}
\NormalTok{        last\_topic }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"color"}

        \CommentTok{\# If user mentions their favorite color, store it}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"favorite"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ message }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"is"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ message:}
            \CommentTok{\# Simple color extraction (will improve in later chapters)}
\NormalTok{            words }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ message.split()}
            \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ i, word }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{enumerate}\NormalTok{(words):}
                \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ word }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"is"} \KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ i }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(words) }\OperatorTok{{-}} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{                    favorite\_color }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ words[i }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{].lower()}
                    \ControlFlowTok{break}

    \CommentTok{\# Respond based on state variables}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ message\_count }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"That\textquotesingle{}s your first message! Thanks for chatting with me."}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"color"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ message }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ favorite\_color:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"I remember your favorite color is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{favorite\_color}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ last\_topic:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"I see we\textquotesingle{}re talking about }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{last\_topic}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ now."}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Thanks for your message. That\textquotesingle{}s }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{message\_count}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ messages so far!"}

\CommentTok{\# Display chatbot status using state variables}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ display\_status():}
    \CommentTok{"""Show current chatbot state using tracked variables."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{BOT\_NAME}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ Status:"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"User: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_name }\ControlFlowTok{else} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Unknown\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Messages received: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{message\_count}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Last topic: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{last\_topic }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ last\_topic }\ControlFlowTok{else} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}None\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ favorite\_color:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"User\textquotesingle{}s favorite color: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{favorite\_color}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{50} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Run a simple chat session}
\NormalTok{display\_greeting()}

\CommentTok{\# Simulate a conversation}
\ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
    \CommentTok{\# Get user input}
\NormalTok{    user\_message }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for exit command}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_message.lower() }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"exit"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"quit"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{]:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{BOT\_NAME}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! It was nice chatting with you."}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{break}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for status command}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_message.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"status"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        display\_status()}
        \ControlFlowTok{continue}

    \CommentTok{\# Process message and respond}
\NormalTok{    response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ process\_message(user\_message)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{BOT\_NAME}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This enhanced chatbot demonstrates: - Using variables to store user
information (\texttt{user\_name}, \texttt{favorite\_color}) - Tracking
conversation state (\texttt{message\_count}, \texttt{last\_topic},
\texttt{greeting\_shown}) - Updating variables as the conversation
progresses - Using variables to customize responses - Distinguishing
between constants (uppercase) and variables (lowercase)

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Project Evolution}: We're building a chatbot that can remember
information across the conversation. In future chapters, we'll enhance
this with better input processing, decision logic, and more
sophisticated memory management.
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{common-variable-pitfalls-to-avoid}{%
\section{9. Common Variable Pitfalls to
Avoid}\label{common-variable-pitfalls-to-avoid}}

When working with variables, be aware of these common issues:

\hypertarget{using-variables-before-assignment}{%
\subsection{Using Variables Before
Assignment}\label{using-variables-before-assignment}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Error: Using a variable before assigning it}
\CommentTok{\# print(unassigned\_var)  \# NameError: name \textquotesingle{}unassigned\_var\textquotesingle{} is not defined}

\CommentTok{\# Correct approach: Assign first, then use}
\NormalTok{assigned\_var }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"I exist!"}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(assigned\_var)  }\CommentTok{\# Works fine}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{name-shadowing}{%
\subsection{Name Shadowing}\label{name-shadowing}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Shadowing (overriding) variables}
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Global name"}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_function():}
\NormalTok{    name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Local name"}  \CommentTok{\# Creates a new local variable, doesn\textquotesingle{}t change the global one}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(name)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Local name}

\NormalTok{test\_function()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(name)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Global name (original value unchanged)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{accidental-reassignment}{%
\subsection{Accidental Reassignment}\label{accidental-reassignment}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Accidental type changes}
\NormalTok{user\_id }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"ABC123"}   \CommentTok{\# String (for an ID code)}
\NormalTok{user\_id }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{42}         \CommentTok{\# Now it\textquotesingle{}s an integer!}

\CommentTok{\# This might cause problems later if code expects a string:}
\CommentTok{\# message = "User " + user\_id  \# TypeError: can only concatenate str (not "int") to str}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{confusing-assignment-with-equality}{%
\subsection{Confusing Assignment (=) with Equality
(==)}\label{confusing-assignment-with-equality}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Assignment vs. equality comparison}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5}      \CommentTok{\# Assignment: sets x to 5}
\CommentTok{\# if x = 10:  \# SyntaxError: invalid syntax}
\CommentTok{\#     print("This is wrong!")}

\CommentTok{\# Correct comparison}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ x }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{:  }\CommentTok{\# Equality check: is x equal to 10?}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"x is 10"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"x is not 10"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-3}{%
\section{10. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-3}}

Test your understanding of variables:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Which statement correctly creates a variable in Python?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    variable name = ``Alice''
  \item
    name := ``Alice''
  \item
    name = ``Alice''
  \item
    define name = ``Alice''
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of these is NOT a valid variable name in Python?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \_user\_name
  \item
    UserName
  \item
    user123
  \item
    for
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What happens when you assign a new value to an existing variable?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Python creates a new variable with the same name
  \item
    Python keeps both the old and new values
  \item
    The old value is discarded and replaced with the new value
  \item
    Python raises an error unless you use a special reassignment
    operator
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What does this code do? \texttt{x,\ y\ =\ y,\ x}

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Creates a tuple containing x and y
  \item
    Tests if x equals y and assigns the result
  \item
    Swaps the values of x and y
  \item
    Raises a syntax error
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What's the difference between a variable and a constant in Python?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Variables can be reassigned but constants cannot
  \item
    Constants are faster than variables
  \item
    Python doesn't have constants, only a naming convention
  \item
    Constants must be declared with a special keyword
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  In our chatbot project, why do we use variables like
  \texttt{message\_count} and \texttt{last\_topic}?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    To make the code run faster
  \item
    To track the state of the conversation
  \item
    Because Python requires them
  \item
    To reduce memory usage
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers \& Feedback:} 1. c) name = ``Alice'' --- The standard
assignment syntax in Python 2. d) for --- Reserved keywords cannot be
used as variable names 3. c) The old value is discarded and replaced
with the new value --- Variables can change 4. c) Swaps the values of x
and y --- A Python idiom for value swapping 5. c) Python doesn't have
constants, only a naming convention --- UPPERCASE names signal constants
6. b) To track the state of the conversation --- Variables maintain
information between interactions

\textbf{\emph{AI Collaboration Corner: Debugging Variable Issues}}

When asking AI for help with variable problems, provide the context
around the issue:

Instead of:

\begin{verbatim}
My code isn't working with variables
\end{verbatim}

Try:

\begin{verbatim}
I'm getting this error when running my code:

NameError: name 'user_response' is not defined

Here's the relevant code section:

def process_input():
    if user_input == "yes":
        result = "Affirmative"
    else:
        result = "Negative"

    return user_response  # This line has the error

What's causing this error and how should I fix it?
\end{verbatim}

The second prompt shows the specific error, the code context, and lets
the AI identify the issue (using an undefined variable name instead of
the defined `result' variable). This leads to a much more helpful
response.

\section{Summary}\label{summary-3}}

In this chapter, you've learned how variables allow you to store, name,
and manipulate data in your Python programs. You've explored how to
create and name variables following Python conventions, how to change
their values, and how to use them to track state in your applications.

For our chatbot project, you've implemented a more sophisticated design
that uses variables to remember user information and track the
conversation state. This memory capability is a fundamental aspect of
creating interactive applications that respond intelligently to users.

Understanding variables is essential for effective programming, as they
form the backbone of data management in your code. As your programs
become more complex, organizing and tracking data through well-named
variables will become increasingly important.

In the next chapter, we'll explore output techniques, learning how to
display information to users in effective and formatted ways.

\hypertarget{introduction-why-output-matters}{%
\section{1. Introduction: Why Output
Matters}\label{introduction-why-output-matters}}

In programming, output is your code's voice---how it communicates with
users and the world. Without output, your code would work silently in
the background, with no way to show its results or interact with users.
This is like having thoughts but no way to express them.

Output is particularly crucial in conversational applications like our
chatbot project. Just as humans convey meaning through both what they
say and how they say it, programs use output not just to display raw
information, but to communicate in a way that's clear, useful, and
engaging.

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Key Concept}: Effective output is about more than just
displaying information---it's about communicating with purpose, guiding
users, and creating an engaging experience that meets users' needs.
\end{quote}

Whether you're building a personal chatbot, a data analysis tool, or a
complex web application, your output system forms the foundation of the
user experience. In the AI era, where machines and humans collaborate
more closely than ever, thoughtful output design bridges the gap between
computational processes and human understanding.

\hypertarget{the-print-function-your-output-assistant}{%
\section{\texorpdfstring{2. The \texttt{print()} Function: Your Output
Assistant}{2. The print() Function: Your Output Assistant}}\label{the-print-function-your-output-assistant}}

Python's \texttt{print()} function is your primary tool for displaying
information to users. While seemingly simple, it offers remarkable
flexibility:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Basic print function usage}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Hello, World!\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Displays: Hello, World!}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The \texttt{print()} function can display virtually any type of data
Python supports:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Printing different types of values}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Hello, World!\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)         }\CommentTok{\# Strings (text)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{42}\NormalTok{)                      }\CommentTok{\# Integers (whole numbers)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{3.14159}\NormalTok{)                 }\CommentTok{\# Floating{-}point numbers (decimals)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)                    }\CommentTok{\# Booleans (True/False)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{)                    }\CommentTok{\# None value (absence of value)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{([}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{])               }\CommentTok{\# Lists (collections)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Alice\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{\})       }\CommentTok{\# Dictionaries (key{-}value pairs)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When you pass data to \texttt{print()}, Python automatically converts it
to a string representation for display. This is why you can print
numbers, booleans, and other non-string values directly.

\hypertarget{multiple-items-in-one-print-statement}{%
\subsection{Multiple Items in One Print
Statement}\label{multiple-items-in-one-print-statement}}

You can display multiple items in a single \texttt{print()} call by
separating them with commas:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Printing multiple items}
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alice"}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{30}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Name:"}\NormalTok{, name, }\StringTok{"Age:"}\NormalTok{, age)  }\CommentTok{\# Displays: Name: Alice Age: 30}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Notice that \texttt{print()} automatically adds spaces between multiple
items. This behavior can be customized, as we'll see shortly.

\hypertarget{interactive-vs.-script-environments}{%
\subsection{Interactive vs.~Script
Environments}\label{interactive-vs.-script-environments}}

Output behaves differently depending on your programming environment:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# In a Jupyter notebook or interactive environment}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{21}
\NormalTok{age  }\CommentTok{\# This displays the value directly: 21}

\CommentTok{\# In a Python script, you need print()}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{21}
\CommentTok{\# Just writing \textquotesingle{}age\textquotesingle{} here doesn\textquotesingle{}t display anything}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(age)  }\CommentTok{\# This explicitly shows the value: 21}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Pro Tip}: When writing code that will be run as a script (not in
an interactive environment like Jupyter), always use \texttt{print()} to
display information. Simply referring to a variable won't show its value
when the script runs.
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{customizing-your-output}{%
\section{3. Customizing Your Output}\label{customizing-your-output}}

The \texttt{print()} function accepts several parameters that let you
control exactly how output appears.

\hypertarget{separators-and-end-characters}{%
\subsection{Separators and End
Characters}\label{separators-and-end-characters}}

These parameters give you fine-grained control over output formatting:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# The \textquotesingle{}sep\textquotesingle{} parameter: what goes between multiple items}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Name"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Age"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{, sep}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{": "}\NormalTok{)         }\CommentTok{\# Name: Alice: Age: 30}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Name"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Age"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{, sep}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{" | "}\NormalTok{)        }\CommentTok{\# Name | Alice | Age | 30}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Name"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Age"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{, sep}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)         }\CommentTok{\# Each item on a new line}

\CommentTok{\# The \textquotesingle{}end\textquotesingle{} parameter: what goes at the end (default is newline \textquotesingle{}\textbackslash{}n\textquotesingle{})}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello"}\NormalTok{, end}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"! "}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"World"}\NormalTok{)                                      }\CommentTok{\# Hello! World}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Item 1"}\NormalTok{, end}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{" → "}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Item 2"}\NormalTok{, end}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{" → "}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Item 3"}\NormalTok{)                                     }\CommentTok{\# Item 1 → Item 2 → Item 3}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

These parameters are particularly useful for creating custom layouts,
tables, or progress indicators:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Creating a simple progress indicator}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ time}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Processing"}\NormalTok{, end}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{""}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ \_ }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{range}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\FloatTok{0.3}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Simulate work}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"."}\NormalTok{, end}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{""}\NormalTok{, flush}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# flush ensures immediate display}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{" Done!"}\NormalTok{)      }\CommentTok{\# Processing......... Done!}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{the-file-parameter}{%
\subsection{The File Parameter}\label{the-file-parameter}}

By default, \texttt{print()} sends output to the screen (specifically to
\texttt{sys.stdout}), but you can redirect it:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Printing to a file}
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"output.txt"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"w"}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"This text goes to a file"}\NormalTok{, }\BuiltInTok{file}\OperatorTok{=}\BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"More text in the file"}\NormalTok{, }\BuiltInTok{file}\OperatorTok{=}\BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Printing to standard error}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ sys}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Warning: something unusual happened"}\NormalTok{, }\BuiltInTok{file}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{sys.stderr)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{string-formatting-from-basic-to-advanced}{%
\section{4. String Formatting: From Basic to
Advanced}\label{string-formatting-from-basic-to-advanced}}

String formatting is essential for creating clear, professional output.
Python offers several approaches, each with its own strengths.

\hypertarget{string-concatenation-basic}{%
\subsection{String Concatenation
(Basic)}\label{string-concatenation-basic}}

The simplest approach is to build strings using the \texttt{+} operator:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alice"}
\NormalTok{greeting }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Hello, "} \OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ name }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"!"}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(greeting)  }\CommentTok{\# Hello, Alice!}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

While simple, this becomes cumbersome for complex formatting and
requires explicit type conversion:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{30}
\CommentTok{\# print("You are " + age + " years old.")  \# TypeError!}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You are "} \OperatorTok{+} \BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(age) }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{" years old."}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Correct, but unwieldy}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{the-format-method-intermediate}{%
\subsection{The Format Method
(Intermediate)}\label{the-format-method-intermediate}}

The \texttt{.format()} method offers more flexibility:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Bob"}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{35}
\NormalTok{message }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Hello, }\SpecialCharTok{\{\}}\StringTok{! You are }\SpecialCharTok{\{\}}\StringTok{ years old."}\NormalTok{.}\BuiltInTok{format}\NormalTok{(name, age)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(message)  }\CommentTok{\# Hello, Bob! You are 35 years old.}

\CommentTok{\# With position specifiers}
\NormalTok{message }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Hello, }\SpecialCharTok{\{0\}}\StringTok{! You are }\SpecialCharTok{\{1\}}\StringTok{ years old. Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{0\}}\StringTok{!"}\NormalTok{.}\BuiltInTok{format}\NormalTok{(name, age)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(message)  }\CommentTok{\# Hello, Bob! You are 35 years old. Nice to meet you, Bob!}

\CommentTok{\# With named placeholders}
\NormalTok{message }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Hello, }\SpecialCharTok{\{name\}}\StringTok{! You are }\SpecialCharTok{\{age\}}\StringTok{ years old."}\NormalTok{.}\BuiltInTok{format}\NormalTok{(name}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{name, age}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{age)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(message)  }\CommentTok{\# Hello, Bob! You are 35 years old.}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{f-strings-modern-pythons-formatting-powerhouse}{%
\subsection{F-Strings: Modern Python's Formatting
Powerhouse}\label{f-strings-modern-pythons-formatting-powerhouse}}

F-strings (formatted string literals, introduced in Python 3.6) combine
simplicity with power:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Charlie"}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{40}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! You are }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{age}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ years old."}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Hello, Charlie! You are 40 years old.}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

F-strings allow you to evaluate expressions inside the curly braces:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Arithmetic within f{-}strings}
\NormalTok{price }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{19.99}
\NormalTok{quantity }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{3}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Total: $}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{price }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ quantity}\SpecialCharTok{:.2f\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Total: $59.97}

\CommentTok{\# Function calls within f{-}strings}
\NormalTok{text }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"python"}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Uppercase: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{upper()}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Uppercase: PYTHON}

\CommentTok{\# Conditionals within f{-}strings (Python 3.8+)}
\NormalTok{temperature }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{75}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"It\textquotesingle{}s }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{temperature}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{°F {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}warm\textquotesingle{}} \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{70} \ControlFlowTok{else} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}cool\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# It\textquotesingle{}s 75°F {-} warm}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{precision-formatting-for-numbers}{%
\subsection{Precision Formatting for
Numbers}\label{precision-formatting-for-numbers}}

For data-intensive applications, precise number formatting is essential:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{value }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{123.456789}

\CommentTok{\# Controlling decimal places}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Fixed point, 2 decimal places: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{value}\SpecialCharTok{:.2f\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# 123.46}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Fixed point, 4 decimal places: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{value}\SpecialCharTok{:.4f\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# 123.4568}

\CommentTok{\# Width and alignment}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"|}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{value}\SpecialCharTok{:10.2f\}}\SpecialStringTok{|"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# |    123.46|  (10 char width)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"|}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{value}\SpecialCharTok{:\textless{}10.2f\}}\SpecialStringTok{|"}\NormalTok{) }\CommentTok{\# |123.46    |  (left{-}aligned)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"|}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{value}\SpecialCharTok{:\^{}10.2f\}}\SpecialStringTok{|"}\NormalTok{) }\CommentTok{\# |  123.46  |  (center{-}aligned)}

\CommentTok{\# With thousands separator}
\NormalTok{big\_number }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{1234567.89}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"With commas: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{big\_number}\SpecialCharTok{:,}\FloatTok{.2}\ErrorTok{f}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# 1,234,567.89}

\CommentTok{\# Scientific notation}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Scientific: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{value}\SpecialCharTok{:e\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# 1.234568e+02}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{creating-visual-structure-in-output}{%
\section{5. Creating Visual Structure in
Output}\label{creating-visual-structure-in-output}}

Well-structured output makes information easier to understand and use.
Python's string manipulation capabilities allow you to create visually
appealing text interfaces.

\hypertarget{using-repetition-and-alignment}{%
\subsection{Using Repetition and
Alignment}\label{using-repetition-and-alignment}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Creating borders and dividers}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# ==================================================}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# {-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}}

\CommentTok{\# Centering text}
\NormalTok{title }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"USER PROFILE"}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{:=\^{}50\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# ===================USER PROFILE====================}

\CommentTok{\# Creating a simple framed header}
\NormalTok{width }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{50}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"+"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ (width }\OperatorTok{{-}} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"+"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"|}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{:}\OperatorTok{\^{}}\NormalTok{\{width}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{\}}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{|"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"+"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ (width }\OperatorTok{{-}} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"+"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{building-a-structured-information-display}{%
\subsection{Building a Structured Information
Display}\label{building-a-structured-information-display}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ display\_user\_profile(name, age, email, location):}
    \CommentTok{"""Display a structured user profile with visual formatting."""}
\NormalTok{    width }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{60}

    \CommentTok{\# Header}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}USER PROFILE\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{:}\OperatorTok{\^{}}\NormalTok{\{width\}}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}

    \CommentTok{\# Main content with aligned fields}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"  }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name:\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{:\textless{}12\}}\SpecialStringTok{ }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"  }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age:\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{:\textless{}12\}}\SpecialStringTok{ }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{age}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"  }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Email:\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{:\textless{}12\}}\SpecialStringTok{ }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{email}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"  }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Location:\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{:\textless{}12\}}\SpecialStringTok{ }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{location}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Footer}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Profile generated on: 2023{-}07{-}15\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{:}\OperatorTok{\^{}}\NormalTok{\{width\}}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Using our display function}
\NormalTok{display\_user\_profile(}\StringTok{"Alice Johnson"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{32}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"alice@example.com"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"New York, NY"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This produces:

\begin{verbatim}
============================================================
                       USER PROFILE
============================================================
  Name:        Alice Johnson
  Age:         32
  Email:       alice@example.com
  Location:    New York, NY
------------------------------------------------------------
               Profile generated on: 2023-07-15
============================================================
\end{verbatim}

\hypertarget{multi-line-text-with-triple-quotes}{%
\subsection{Multi-line Text with Triple
Quotes}\label{multi-line-text-with-triple-quotes}}

For longer text blocks, triple quotes create multi-line strings:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{instructions }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"""}
\StringTok{WELCOME TO PYTHON ADVENTURE!}
\StringTok{===========================}

\StringTok{In this text{-}based game, you\textquotesingle{}ll explore a virtual world}
\StringTok{using simple commands:}

\StringTok{  {-} NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, WEST: Move in that direction}
\StringTok{  {-} LOOK: Examine your surroundings}
\StringTok{  {-} INVENTORY: Check your items}
\StringTok{  {-} TAKE [item]: Pick up an object}
\StringTok{  {-} USE [item]: Use an item in your inventory}

\StringTok{Type HELP at any time to see these instructions again.}
\StringTok{Let\textquotesingle{}s begin your adventure!}
\StringTok{"""}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(instructions)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Visual Design Tip}: Use elements like borders, alignment, and
spacing consistently throughout your application. This creates a visual
language that helps users understand the information's structure and
importance.
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{special-characters-and-escape-sequences}{%
\section{6. Special Characters and Escape
Sequences}\label{special-characters-and-escape-sequences}}

Python uses backslash escape sequences to represent special characters:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Common escape sequences}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Line 1}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{Line 2"}\NormalTok{)           }\CommentTok{\# \textbackslash{}n creates a new line}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Column 1}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}t}\StringTok{Column 2"}\NormalTok{)       }\CommentTok{\# \textbackslash{}t creates a tab}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"She said, }\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{Hello!}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}"}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)     }\CommentTok{\# \textbackslash{}" for quotes inside a string}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"C:}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{Program Files}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}\textbackslash{}}\StringTok{Python"}\NormalTok{) }\CommentTok{\# \textbackslash{}\textbackslash{} for backslash}

\CommentTok{\# Less common but useful escape sequences}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Bell sound: }\CharTok{\textbackslash{}a}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)           }\CommentTok{\# \textbackslash{}a produces an alert (bell) sound}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Backspace: Hello}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}b}\StringTok{World"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# \textbackslash{}b is backspace (rarely used)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Form}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}f}\StringTok{feed"}\NormalTok{)               }\CommentTok{\# \textbackslash{}f is form feed (page break)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Carriage}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}r}\StringTok{return"}\NormalTok{)         }\CommentTok{\# \textbackslash{}r returns to start of line}

\CommentTok{\# Unicode characters (Python 3)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}u2764}\StringTok{ Python"}\NormalTok{)            }\CommentTok{\# ❤ Python (Unicode heart)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}N\{ROCKET\}}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)               }\CommentTok{\# 🚀 (Unicode rocket by name)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Tip}: The \texttt{repr()} function shows the raw string with
escape sequences: \texttt{print(repr("Hello\textbackslash{}nWorld"))}
displays
\texttt{\textquotesingle{}Hello\textbackslash{}nWorld\textquotesingle{}}
with the \texttt{\textbackslash{}n} visible rather than creating a new
line.
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{getting-help-with-the-help-function}{%
\section{\texorpdfstring{7. Getting Help with the \texttt{help()}
Function}{7. Getting Help with the help() Function}}\label{getting-help-with-the-help-function}}

Python's \texttt{help()} function is your built-in documentation
browser:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Learn about the print() function}
\BuiltInTok{help}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This displays:

\begin{verbatim}
Help on built-in function print in module builtins:

print(...)
    print(value, ..., sep=' ', end='\n', file=sys.stdout, flush=False)

    Prints the values to a stream, or to sys.stdout by default.
    Optional keyword arguments:
    file:  a file-like object (stream); defaults to the current sys.stdout.
    sep:   string inserted between values, default a space.
    end:   string appended after the last value, default a newline.
    flush: whether to forcibly flush the stream.
\end{verbatim}

You can use \texttt{help()} with any Python function, method, or module:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\BuiltInTok{help}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{.}\BuiltInTok{format}\NormalTok{)      }\CommentTok{\# Documentation for string formatting}
\BuiltInTok{help}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)           }\CommentTok{\# Documentation for f{-}strings (in Python 3.6+)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Learning Tip}: Make \texttt{help()} your go-to resource when
exploring Python. It provides accurate, up-to-date information about the
exact version of Python you're using.
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{project-corner-building-your-chatbots-voice}{%
\section{8. Project Corner: Building Your Chatbot's
Voice}\label{project-corner-building-your-chatbots-voice}}

Now let's apply what we've learned to develop our chatbot project. A
chatbot's ability to communicate clearly is crucial for creating a good
user experience.

\hypertarget{chatbot-basic-output-structure}{%
\subsection{Chatbot Basic Output
Structure}\label{chatbot-basic-output-structure}}

Let's create a distinctive and user-friendly output system for our
chatbot:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Chatbot output structure {-} Version 1.0}
\NormalTok{bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}
\NormalTok{version }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"1.0"}

\CommentTok{\# Welcome message with visual elements}
\NormalTok{width }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{60}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ v}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{version}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{.center(width))}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Your Python Learning Assistant"}\NormalTok{.center(width))}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}

\CommentTok{\# Introduction using multi{-}line formatted output}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"""}
\SpecialStringTok{Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, a Python{-}powered chatbot created to assist with}
\SpecialStringTok{your learning journey.}

\SpecialStringTok{As you progress through this book, I\textquotesingle{}ll evolve with new capabilities}
\SpecialStringTok{that demonstrate Python concepts in action. Right now, I can:}

\SpecialStringTok{  • Display formatted messages (using what you just learned!)}
\SpecialStringTok{  • Provide visual structure to information}
\SpecialStringTok{  • Show different types of message formatting}

\SpecialStringTok{Soon, I\textquotesingle{}ll be able to respond to your inputs, remember information,}
\SpecialStringTok{make decisions, and much more!}
\SpecialStringTok{"""}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Closing line with different formatting}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} I\textquotesingle{}m looking forward to our conversations!"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This produces a professional-looking interface:

\begin{verbatim}
============================================================
                      PyBot v1.0
                Your Python Learning Assistant
============================================================

Hello! I'm PyBot, a Python-powered chatbot created to assist with
your learning journey.

As you progress through this book, I'll evolve with new capabilities
that demonstrate Python concepts in action. Right now, I can:

  • Display formatted messages (using what you just learned!)
  • Provide visual structure to information
  • Show different types of message formatting

Soon, I'll be able to respond to your inputs, remember information,
make decisions, and much more!

------------------------------------------------------------
PyBot> I'm looking forward to our conversations!
------------------------------------------------------------
\end{verbatim}

\hypertarget{message-types-for-different-purposes}{%
\subsection{Message Types for Different
Purposes}\label{message-types-for-different-purposes}}

In a real chatbot, different types of messages serve different purposes.
Let's create specific formatting for each message type:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ chatbot\_output(message\_type, text):}
    \CommentTok{"""Display chatbot messages with appropriate formatting.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        message\_type: The type of message (\textquotesingle{}normal\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}system\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}error\textquotesingle{}, or \textquotesingle{}help\textquotesingle{})}
\CommentTok{        text: The message content}
\CommentTok{    """}
\NormalTok{    bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ message\_type }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"normal"}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Regular conversational message}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ message\_type }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"system"}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# System notifications and status updates}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"[SYSTEM] }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ message\_type }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"error"}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Error messages stand out with asterisks}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ [ERROR]\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}*\textquotesingle{}} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ (}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(text) }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{18}\NormalTok{)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ message\_type }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Help messages with special formatting}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{60}\NormalTok{)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ HELP"}\NormalTok{.center(}\DecValTok{60}\NormalTok{))}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{60}\NormalTok{)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{60} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Example usage}
\NormalTok{chatbot\_output(}\StringTok{"normal"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Hello! How can I help you today?"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{chatbot\_output(}\StringTok{"system"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Processing your request..."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{chatbot\_output(}\StringTok{"error"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"I couldn\textquotesingle{}t understand that command."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{chatbot\_output(}\StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"""}
\StringTok{Available commands:}
\StringTok{{-} HELLO: Greet the chatbot}
\StringTok{{-} HELP: Show this help message}
\StringTok{{-} BYE: End the conversation}
\StringTok{"""}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Output:

\begin{verbatim}
PyBot> Hello! How can I help you today?
[SYSTEM] Processing your request...
PyBot [ERROR]> I couldn't understand that command.
**************************************************

------------------------------------------------------------
                        PyBot HELP
------------------------------------------------------------

Available commands:
- HELLO: Greet the chatbot
- HELP: Show this help message
- BYE: End the conversation

------------------------------------------------------------
\end{verbatim}

\hypertarget{simulating-a-complete-conversation}{%
\subsection{Simulating a Complete
Conversation}\label{simulating-a-complete-conversation}}

Let's put it all together to simulate a complete chatbot conversation:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ time}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ simulate\_chatbot\_conversation():}
    \CommentTok{"""Simulate a conversation with our chatbot using different output techniques."""}
\NormalTok{    bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}
\NormalTok{    width }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{60}

    \CommentTok{\# Welcome screen}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ Chat Simulation"}\NormalTok{.center(width))}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}

    \CommentTok{\# Initial greeting}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, your Python assistant."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} What\textquotesingle{}s your name?"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Simulate user input}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\FloatTok{1.5}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alex"}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} My name is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{."}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Bot response with formatted output}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\FloatTok{0.8}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} I can help you learn Python concepts."}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# System message}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\FloatTok{1.2}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"[SYSTEM] }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ is retrieving information..."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\FloatTok{1.5}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Information display with structure}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Here are today\textquotesingle{}s Python topics:"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"  • Variables and data types"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"  • Input and output techniques"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"  • String formatting with f{-}strings"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"  • Basic control structures"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Error message simulation}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\FloatTok{1.5}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Can you write my homework for me?"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\FloatTok{1.2}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ [ERROR]\textgreater{} I\textquotesingle{}m designed to help you learn, not to do your work for you."}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"*"} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{65}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Help message}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\FloatTok{1.5}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} help"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ HELP"}\NormalTok{.center(width))}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"""}
\StringTok{Commands you can try:}
\StringTok{{-} ASK [question]: Ask me about Python}
\StringTok{{-} TOPICS: Show available topics}
\StringTok{{-} EXAMPLE [topic]: Get an example about a topic}
\StringTok{{-} BYE: End our conversation}
\StringTok{    """}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}

    \CommentTok{\# Ending the conversation}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\FloatTok{1.5}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} bye"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    time.sleep(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! Happy coding!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"End of simulation"}\NormalTok{.center(width))}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ width }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Run the simulation}
\NormalTok{simulate\_chatbot\_conversation()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This demonstration shows how effective output techniques can create an
engaging, user-friendly conversational interface. As we progress through
the book, we'll expand our chatbot with real interactive capabilities.

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Project Evolution}: In this chapter, we're focusing on the
output side of our chatbot. In Chapter 6, we'll add user input
capabilities, and in later chapters, we'll implement logic to make the
