\hypertarget{learning-objectives-7}{%
\section{Learning Objectives}\label{learning-objectives-7}}

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: - Confidently use
arithmetic operators to perform calculations of any complexity - Apply
comparison operators to create meaningful boolean expressions - Combine
conditions with logical operators to create sophisticated tests -
Understand operator precedence and control the order of operations -
Convert between different data types for accurate calculations -
Implement basic decision-making logic in your chatbot project

\hypertarget{introduction-operators-as-your-programming-power-tools}{%
\section{1. Introduction: Operators as Your Programming Power
Tools}\label{introduction-operators-as-your-programming-power-tools}}

Operators are the essential tools that allow you to manipulate data,
make decisions, and create dynamic behavior in your programs. Just as
physical tools transform raw materials into finished products, operators
transform raw data into meaningful information and actions.

In programming, operators serve several critical functions:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Perform calculations} through arithmetic operators
\item
  \textbf{Make comparisons} with relational operators
\item
  \textbf{Combine conditions} using logical operators
\item
  \textbf{Check relationships} between values with identity and
  membership operators
\end{itemize}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Key Concept}: Operators are the verbs of programming---they let
your data do things rather than just exist. Without operators, your
variables would be like islands, unable to interact with each other.
\end{quote}

As we build our chatbot project, operators will give it the ability to
make decisions based on user input. This simple but powerful capability
transforms our chatbot from a script that merely displays predetermined
messages to a program that can respond intelligently to different
situations.

\hypertarget{arithmetic-operators-crunching-the-numbers}{%
\section{2. Arithmetic Operators: Crunching the
Numbers}\label{arithmetic-operators-crunching-the-numbers}}

Arithmetic operators perform mathematical operations on numeric values:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Basic arithmetic operations}
\NormalTok{a }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{15}
\NormalTok{b }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{4}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# Addition: 19}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# Subtraction: 11}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# Multiplication: 60}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# Division: 3.75}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{//}\NormalTok{ b)   }\CommentTok{\# Integer Division: 3}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{\%}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# Modulo (remainder): 3}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{**}\NormalTok{ b)   }\CommentTok{\# Exponentiation: 50625 (15 to the power of 4)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Each operator serves a specific mathematical purpose:

\hypertarget{addition-and-subtraction--}{%
\subsection{Addition (+) and Subtraction
(-)}\label{addition-and-subtraction--}}

These work as you'd expect from basic math:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Simple addition and subtraction}
\NormalTok{total }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10} \OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{5}          \CommentTok{\# 15}
\NormalTok{difference }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10} \OperatorTok{{-}} \DecValTok{5}     \CommentTok{\# 5}

\CommentTok{\# With variables}
\NormalTok{price }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{19.99}
\NormalTok{tax }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{1.60}
\NormalTok{total\_cost }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ price }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ tax  }\CommentTok{\# 21.59}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{multiplication-and-division}{%
\subsection{Multiplication (*) and Division
(/)}\label{multiplication-and-division}}

For multiplication and division operations:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Multiplication}
\NormalTok{area }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{10}           \CommentTok{\# 50}
\NormalTok{volume }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{2} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{3} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{4}      \CommentTok{\# 24}

\CommentTok{\# Division (always returns a float in Python 3)}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10} \OperatorTok{/} \DecValTok{2}         \CommentTok{\# 5.0}
\NormalTok{result2 }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{9} \OperatorTok{/} \DecValTok{2}         \CommentTok{\# 4.5}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{integer-division-and-modulo}{%
\subsection{Integer Division (//) and Modulo
(\%)}\label{integer-division-and-modulo}}

These less common operators are incredibly useful for specific tasks:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Integer division (rounds down to nearest integer)}
\NormalTok{minutes }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{137}
\NormalTok{hours }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ minutes }\OperatorTok{//} \DecValTok{60}    \CommentTok{\# 2 (2 whole hours in 137 minutes)}

\CommentTok{\# Modulo (remainder after division)}
\NormalTok{remainder }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ minutes }\OperatorTok{\%} \DecValTok{60}  \CommentTok{\# 17 (17 minutes left after 2 whole hours)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Together, integer division and modulo let you break a value into
component parts:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Converting seconds to hours, minutes, seconds}
\NormalTok{total\_seconds }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{9274}

\NormalTok{hours }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ total\_seconds }\OperatorTok{//} \DecValTok{3600}                       \CommentTok{\# 2}
\NormalTok{remaining }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ total\_seconds }\OperatorTok{\%} \DecValTok{3600}                    \CommentTok{\# 1074}
\NormalTok{minutes }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ remaining }\OperatorTok{//} \DecValTok{60}                           \CommentTok{\# 17}
\NormalTok{seconds }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ remaining }\OperatorTok{\%} \DecValTok{60}                            \CommentTok{\# 54}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{hours}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{h }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{minutes}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{seconds}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{s"}\NormalTok{)            }\CommentTok{\# 2h 17m 54s}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{exponentiation}{%
\subsection{Exponentiation (**)}\label{exponentiation}}

For raising a number to a power:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Exponentiation examples}
\NormalTok{square }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5} \OperatorTok{**} \DecValTok{2}         \CommentTok{\# 25}
\NormalTok{cube }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{2} \OperatorTok{**} \DecValTok{3}           \CommentTok{\# 8}
\NormalTok{big\_number }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10} \OperatorTok{**} \DecValTok{6}    \CommentTok{\# 1000000 (one million)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{string-operators}{%
\subsection{String Operators}\label{string-operators}}

Python's \texttt{+} and \texttt{*} operators also work with strings:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# String concatenation with +}
\NormalTok{first\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"John"}
\NormalTok{last\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Doe"}
\NormalTok{full\_name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ first\_name }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{" "} \OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ last\_name  }\CommentTok{\# "John Doe"}

\CommentTok{\# String repetition with *}
\NormalTok{separator }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"{-}"} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{20}    \CommentTok{\# "{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}"}
\NormalTok{padding }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{" "} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{5}       \CommentTok{\# "     " (5 spaces)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Practical Tip}: The modulo operator (\texttt{\%}) is
particularly useful for: - Determining if a number is even or odd:
\texttt{number\ \%\ 2\ ==\ 0} is True for even numbers - Cycling through
a range of values (e.g., for clock arithmetic) - Finding recurring
patterns
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{assignment-operators-efficient-variable-updates}{%
\section{3. Assignment Operators: Efficient Variable
Updates}\label{assignment-operators-efficient-variable-updates}}

Python offers shorthand operators that combine arithmetic with
assignment:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Regular assignment}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}

\CommentTok{\# Combined assignment operators}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{5}        \CommentTok{\# Equivalent to: x = x + 5}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{{-}=} \DecValTok{3}        \CommentTok{\# Equivalent to: x = x {-} 3}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{*=} \DecValTok{2}        \CommentTok{\# Equivalent to: x = x * 2}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{/=} \DecValTok{4}        \CommentTok{\# Equivalent to: x = x / 4}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{//=} \DecValTok{2}       \CommentTok{\# Equivalent to: x = x // 2}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{\%=} \DecValTok{3}        \CommentTok{\# Equivalent to: x = x \% 3}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{**=} \DecValTok{2}       \CommentTok{\# Equivalent to: x = x ** 2}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

These compound assignment operators make your code more concise and
often more readable, especially when incrementing or updating counters
and totals:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Practical example: counting words}
\NormalTok{text }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"This is a sample sentence for counting words"}
\NormalTok{words }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ text.split()}
\NormalTok{count }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}

\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ word }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ words:}
\NormalTok{    count }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}  \CommentTok{\# More concise than count = count + 1}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"The text contains }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{count}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ words."}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# 8 words}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{comparison-operators-making-decisions}{%
\section{4. Comparison Operators: Making
Decisions}\label{comparison-operators-making-decisions}}

Comparison operators compare values and return boolean results
(\texttt{True} or \texttt{False}):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{a }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}
\NormalTok{b }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{20}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{==}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# Equal to: False}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{!=}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# Not equal to: True}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ b)     }\CommentTok{\# Greater than: False}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{\textless{}}\NormalTok{ b)     }\CommentTok{\# Less than: True}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# Greater than or equal to: False}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# Less than or equal to: True}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

These operators form the foundation of conditional logic in Python,
allowing your programs to make decisions based on the state of your
data:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Using comparison operators for decision{-}making}
\NormalTok{temperature }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{32}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s a hot day!"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"The temperature is moderate or cool."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{comparing-different-types}{%
\subsection{Comparing Different Types}\label{comparing-different-types}}

Python can compare different numeric types seamlessly:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Comparing different numeric types}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{5} \OperatorTok{==} \FloatTok{5.0}\NormalTok{)   }\CommentTok{\# True (int vs float)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

However, comparing different non-numeric types may give unexpected
results:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Comparing different types can be tricky}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"5"} \OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)   }\CommentTok{\# False (string vs int)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{([}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{==}\NormalTok{ (}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# False (list vs tuple)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{chaining-comparisons}{%
\subsection{Chaining Comparisons}\label{chaining-comparisons}}

Python allows intuitive chaining of comparison operators:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Chained comparisons}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{25}
\NormalTok{is\_adult }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{18} \OperatorTok{\textless{}=}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{65}  \CommentTok{\# True if age is between 18 and 64 inclusive}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(is\_adult)  }\CommentTok{\# True}

\CommentTok{\# Equivalent to:}
\NormalTok{is\_adult }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ (age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{18}\NormalTok{) }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ (age }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{65}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This chaining makes range checks more readable and concise.

\hypertarget{logical-operators-building-complex-conditions}{%
\section{5. Logical Operators: Building Complex
Conditions}\label{logical-operators-building-complex-conditions}}

Logical operators combine boolean expressions to create complex
conditions:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Basic logical operators}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5}
\NormalTok{y }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}

\CommentTok{\# AND: True only if both operands are True}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(x }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0} \KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ y }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)    }\CommentTok{\# True}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(x }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{7} \KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ y }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)    }\CommentTok{\# False}

\CommentTok{\# OR: True if at least one operand is True}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(x }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{7} \KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ y }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{)     }\CommentTok{\# True}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(x }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{7} \KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ y }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{12}\NormalTok{)    }\CommentTok{\# False}

\CommentTok{\# NOT: Inverts the truth value}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ x }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{)          }\CommentTok{\# True}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ (x }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0} \KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ y }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# False}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{truth-table-for-logical-operators}{%
\subsection{Truth Table for Logical
Operators}\label{truth-table-for-logical-operators}}

Understanding truth tables helps predict logical operator outcomes:

\begin{verbatim}
AND Truth Table
A       B       A and B
True    True    True
True    False   False
False   True    False
False   False   False

OR Truth Table
A       B       A or B
True    True    True
True    False   True
False   True    True
False   False   False

NOT Truth Table
A       not A
True    False
False   True
\end{verbatim}

\hypertarget{short-circuit-evaluation}{%
\subsection{Short-Circuit Evaluation}\label{short-circuit-evaluation}}

Python's logical operators use short-circuit evaluation for efficiency:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Short{-}circuit evaluation with and}
\NormalTok{is\_valid }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{False}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ is\_valid }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ some\_function()  }\CommentTok{\# some\_function() is never called}

\CommentTok{\# Short{-}circuit evaluation with or}
\NormalTok{has\_permission }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ has\_permission }\KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ check\_permissions()  }\CommentTok{\# check\_permissions() is never called}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This behavior is particularly useful for conditional execution and
validation:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Using short{-}circuit to avoid errors}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_user\_name(user\_id):}
    \CommentTok{\# Assume this function gets a user name from a database}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_id }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{123}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Alice"}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{None}

\NormalTok{user\_id }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{456}
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_user\_name(user\_id)}

\CommentTok{\# Short{-}circuit prevents calling .upper() on None}
\NormalTok{display\_name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ name }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ name.upper()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(display\_name)  }\CommentTok{\# None}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{membership-and-identity-operators-special-tests}{%
\section{6. Membership and Identity Operators: Special
Tests}\label{membership-and-identity-operators-special-tests}}

Python provides special operators for checking membership and identity:

\hypertarget{membership-operators}{%
\subsection{Membership Operators}\label{membership-operators}}

The \texttt{in} and \texttt{not\ in} operators check if a value exists
within a collection:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Membership operators with lists}
\NormalTok{fruits }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"apple"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"banana"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"cherry"}\NormalTok{]}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"apple"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ fruits)        }\CommentTok{\# True}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"orange"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ fruits)       }\CommentTok{\# False}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"orange"} \KeywordTok{not} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ fruits)   }\CommentTok{\# True}

\CommentTok{\# Membership operators with strings}
\NormalTok{greeting }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Hello, World!"}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ greeting)      }\CommentTok{\# True}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"hello"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ greeting)      }\CommentTok{\# False (case{-}sensitive)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Membership operators are extremely useful for: - Checking if an item
exists in a list, tuple, or set - Searching for substrings within a
string - Checking if a key exists in a dictionary

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Practical applications of membership operators}
\NormalTok{user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"help"}
\NormalTok{valid\_commands }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"exit"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"save"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"load"}\NormalTok{]}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ valid\_commands:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Valid command"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Unknown command"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{identity-operators}{%
\subsection{Identity Operators}\label{identity-operators}}

The \texttt{is} and \texttt{is\ not} operators check if two variables
reference the same object in memory:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Identity operators}
\NormalTok{a }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{b }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{c }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ a}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\OperatorTok{==}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# True (same values)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\KeywordTok{is}\NormalTok{ b)    }\CommentTok{\# False (different objects)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\KeywordTok{is}\NormalTok{ c)    }\CommentTok{\# True (same object)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(a }\KeywordTok{is} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ b)  }\CommentTok{\# True (different objects)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Identity operators are particularly useful for comparing with singleton
objects like \texttt{None}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Checking for None}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(result }\KeywordTok{is} \VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{)      }\CommentTok{\# True {-} preferred way to check for None}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(result }\OperatorTok{==} \VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{)      }\CommentTok{\# True {-} works but not recommended}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Best Practice}: Always use \texttt{is} when comparing with
\texttt{None}, \texttt{True}, or \texttt{False}.
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{operator-precedence-understanding-evaluation-order}{%
\section{7. Operator Precedence: Understanding Evaluation
Order}\label{operator-precedence-understanding-evaluation-order}}

When multiple operators appear in an expression, Python follows a
specific order of operations:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Expression with multiple operators}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5} \OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{3} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{2}    \CommentTok{\# 11, not 16, because * has higher precedence than +}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Here's a simplified precedence table (from highest to lowest):

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \texttt{**} (Exponentiation)
\item
  \texttt{*}, \texttt{/}, \texttt{//}, \texttt{\%} (Multiplication,
  Division, Floor Division, Modulo)
\item
  \texttt{+}, \texttt{-} (Addition, Subtraction)
\item
  \texttt{==}, \texttt{!=}, \texttt{\textgreater{}},
  \texttt{\textless{}}, \texttt{\textgreater{}=}, \texttt{\textless{}=}
  (Comparisons)
\item
  \texttt{in}, \texttt{not\ in}, \texttt{is}, \texttt{is\ not}
  (Membership, Identity)
\item
  \texttt{not} (Logical NOT)
\item
  \texttt{and} (Logical AND)
\item
  \texttt{or} (Logical OR)
\end{enumerate}

You can override precedence using parentheses:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Using parentheses to control evaluation order}
\NormalTok{result1 }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5} \OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{3} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{2}        \CommentTok{\# 11 (multiplication first)}
\NormalTok{result2 }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ (}\DecValTok{5} \OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{2}      \CommentTok{\# 16 (addition first due to parentheses)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

For complex expressions, using parentheses makes your code more readable
and less prone to errors, even when they're not strictly necessary:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Clear parentheses usage for complex conditions}
\NormalTok{is\_valid }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ ((age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{18}\NormalTok{) }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ (age }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{65}\NormalTok{)) }\KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ (has\_special\_permission)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{project-corner-adding-intelligence-to-your-chatbot}{%
\section{8. Project Corner: Adding Intelligence to Your
Chatbot}\label{project-corner-adding-intelligence-to-your-chatbot}}

Now let's apply our knowledge of operators to enhance our chatbot. We'll
add basic decision-making capabilities that allow the chatbot to respond
differently based on user input.

\hypertarget{simple-response-logic}{%
\subsection{Simple Response Logic}\label{simple-response-logic}}

We'll first implement a simple decision system using comparison and
membership operators:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ simple\_logic\_chatbot():}
    \CommentTok{"""A chatbot that uses operators for basic decision making."""}
\NormalTok{    bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}

    \CommentTok{\# Welcome message}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, your Python assistant."}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} What\textquotesingle{}s your name?"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Get user\textquotesingle{}s name}
\NormalTok{    user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{).strip()}

    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} You can ask me questions or type \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to exit."}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Main conversation loop}
    \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Get user input}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{).strip().lower()}

        \CommentTok{\# Exit condition}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! Have a great day!"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{break}

        \CommentTok{\# Empty input check}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{""}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Did you want to ask something?"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{continue}

        \CommentTok{\# Generate a response based on user input}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"hello"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"hi"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Hello again, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"how are you"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} I\textquotesingle{}m just a computer program, but I\textquotesingle{}m functioning well!"}\NormalTok{)}

        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"your name"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} My name is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. I\textquotesingle{}m a simple chatbot built with Python."}\NormalTok{)}

        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"help"} \OperatorTok{==}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} I can respond to greetings, questions about my name,"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} how I\textquotesingle{}m doing, and Python questions. Try asking me something!"}\NormalTok{)}

        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"python"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"?"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Python is a powerful, easy{-}to{-}learn programming language."}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} You\textquotesingle{}re learning it right now through our book!"}\NormalTok{)}

        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(user\_input) }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Could you please be more specific? Short questions"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} are hard for me to understand."}\NormalTok{)}

        \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} That\textquotesingle{}s interesting! Tell me more or try asking"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} about Python concepts."}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Run the chatbot}
\CommentTok{\# simple\_logic\_chatbot()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This chatbot demonstrates several operator concepts: - \texttt{==} for
exact matches (exit command, help) - \texttt{in} for partial matching
within text - \texttt{or} to combine multiple conditions -
\texttt{len()} with \texttt{\textless{}} to check input length - String
methods like \texttt{.strip()} and \texttt{.lower()} to normalize input

\hypertarget{enhanced-decision-making-with-multiple-conditions}{%
\subsection{Enhanced Decision Making with Multiple
Conditions}\label{enhanced-decision-making-with-multiple-conditions}}

Let's expand our chatbot to handle more complex conditions using logical
operators:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ advanced\_logic\_chatbot():}
    \CommentTok{"""A chatbot with more sophisticated decision logic using operators."""}
\NormalTok{    bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}

    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, your Python learning assistant."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{).strip()}

    \CommentTok{\# Track conversation context}
\NormalTok{    question\_count }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\NormalTok{    greeting\_count }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\NormalTok{    python\_mentioned }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{False}
\NormalTok{    last\_topic }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}

    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! Ask me about Python or programming."}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{).strip().lower()}

        \CommentTok{\# Exit check with confirmation for long conversations}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ question\_count }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{:}
                \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} You\textquotesingle{}ve asked }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{question\_count}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ questions! Are you sure you want to leave?"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{                confirm }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{).strip().lower()}
                \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ confirm }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"yes"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"y"}\NormalTok{]:}
                    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! Hope I was helpful!"}\NormalTok{)}
                    \ControlFlowTok{break}
                \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
                    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Great! Let\textquotesingle{}s continue our conversation."}\NormalTok{)}
                    \ControlFlowTok{continue}
            \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
                \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! Come back if you have more questions."}\NormalTok{)}
                \ControlFlowTok{break}

        \CommentTok{\# Update conversation context}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"?"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
\NormalTok{            question\_count }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}

        \ControlFlowTok{if} \BuiltInTok{any}\NormalTok{(greeting }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ greeting }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hi"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hey"}\NormalTok{]):}
\NormalTok{            greeting\_count }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}

        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"python"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
\NormalTok{            python\_mentioned }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}

        \CommentTok{\# Response generation with complex conditions}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ greeting\_count }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{2} \KeywordTok{and} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(user\_input) }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{:}
            \CommentTok{\# Repeated short greetings}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} We\textquotesingle{}ve exchanged greetings already. Is there something"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} specific I can help you with?"}\NormalTok{)}

        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"python"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"learn"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \CommentTok{\# Questions about learning Python}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Learning Python is a great choice! The key concepts to master are:"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} 1. Variables and data types"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} 2. Control structures (if statements, loops)"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} 3. Functions and modules"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} 4. Object{-}oriented programming"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{            last\_topic }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"learning"}

        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"operator"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"?"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \CommentTok{\# Questions about operators}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Python has several types of operators:"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} {-} Arithmetic: +, {-}, *, /, //, \%, **"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} {-} Comparison: ==, !=, \textless{}, \textgreater{}, \textless{}=, \textgreater{}="}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} {-} Logical: and, or, not"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} {-} Membership: in, not in"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{            last\_topic }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"operators"}

        \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ last\_topic }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"operators"} \KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"example"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \CommentTok{\# Follow{-}up question about operators}
