\hypertarget{introduction-functions-as-building-blocks-of-modern-code}{%
\section{1. Introduction: Functions as Building Blocks of Modern
Code}\label{introduction-functions-as-building-blocks-of-modern-code}}

In today's programming landscape, particularly in the age of AI,
understanding functions is more important than ever. Functions are the
building blocks that make code modular, reusable, and maintainable.
They're like specialized tools in your Python toolkit, each designed to
perform a specific task efficiently.

Think of functions as the verbs of programming - they do things. When
you work with AI programming assistants or analyze code written by
others, recognizing and understanding functions will be crucial to your
success. Functions allow programmers to break complex problems into
smaller, manageable pieces - a technique that remains essential even
when collaborating with AI.

As we progress through this book, you'll see how functions become
increasingly important. They're the fundamental organization units of
code that both human and AI programmers use to create structured,
efficient programs.

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: When asking an AI assistant about a programming
task, try phrasing your request in terms of what function you need. For
example, instead of ``How do I convert a string to uppercase?'', ask
``What Python function converts a string to uppercase?'' This often gets
you more direct, practical answers.}}

\hypertarget{what-are-functions}{%
\section{2. What Are Functions?}\label{what-are-functions}}

Functions are named blocks of code that perform specific tasks. They
help you avoid writing the same code repeatedly, making your programs
more efficient and readable. Python includes many built-in functions
that provide ready-to-use capabilities.

Functions work like this: 1. You call (invoke) them by name 2. You
provide any necessary information (arguments) 3. They perform their task
4. They often give back a result (return value)

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Function pattern:}
\CommentTok{\# function\_name(arguments)}

\CommentTok{\# Examples of built{-}in functions}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello, Python learner!"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Displays text}
\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Python"}\NormalTok{)                    }\CommentTok{\# Measures string length (returns 6)}
\BuiltInTok{round}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{3.14159}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)               }\CommentTok{\# Rounds number to specified precision (returns 3.14)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{functions-in-the-context-of-ai-programming}{%
\subsection{Functions in the Context of AI
Programming}\label{functions-in-the-context-of-ai-programming}}

In the age of AI programming assistants, functions remain critically
important. When an AI assistant generates code for you, it will
typically organize that code into functions. Understanding how to read,
modify, and work with these functions is an essential skill.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Example of AI{-}generated function structure}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(numbers):}
    \CommentTok{"""Calculate the average of a list of numbers."""}
\NormalTok{    total }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
\NormalTok{    count }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ total }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ count }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ count }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0} \ControlFlowTok{else} \DecValTok{0}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This function contains all the typical elements you'll need to
understand: a name, parameters, docstring (documentation),
implementation code, and a return value.

\hypertarget{calling-functions}{%
\section{3. Calling Functions}\label{calling-functions}}

To use a function, we ``call'' it by writing its name followed by
parentheses:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Calling the print() function}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello, Python learner!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Calling the input() function}
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Calling the len() function}
\NormalTok{message }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Hello, world!"}
\NormalTok{message\_length }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(message)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"The message has }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{message\_length}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ characters."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When you call a function: - Start with the function's name (case
sensitive) - Follow with opening parenthesis \texttt{(} - Add any
required arguments (separated by commas) - Close with closing
parenthesis \texttt{)}

\hypertarget{common-function-calling-patterns}{%
\subsection{Common Function Calling
Patterns}\label{common-function-calling-patterns}}

Functions can be called in several ways:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Simple function call}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Function call with the result saved to a variable}
\NormalTok{user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter something: "}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Function call used directly in an expression}
\NormalTok{doubled }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Python"}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{2}

\CommentTok{\# Function calls can be nested (inner calls execute first)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Python"}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# First len() executes, then print() displays the result}

\CommentTok{\# Function call with multiple arguments}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"world"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"of"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Python!"}\NormalTok{, sep}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"{-}"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{function-arguments}{%
\section{4. Function Arguments}\label{function-arguments}}

Many functions require information to work with. These pieces of
information are called ``arguments'' and are placed inside the
parentheses when calling a function.

\hypertarget{positional-arguments}{%
\subsection{Positional Arguments}\label{positional-arguments}}

The most common way to pass arguments is by position:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Function with one argument}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello, world!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Function with multiple positional arguments}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"world"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"of"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Python!"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Prints: Hello world of Python!}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{keyword-arguments}{%
\subsection{Keyword Arguments}\label{keyword-arguments}}

Some functions accept named arguments, which makes the code more
readable:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Using keyword arguments}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"world"}\NormalTok{, sep}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{", "}\NormalTok{, end}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"!}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Prints: Hello, world!}

\CommentTok{\# Mixing positional and keyword arguments}
\CommentTok{\# Positional arguments must come before keyword arguments}
\BuiltInTok{round}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{3.14159}\NormalTok{, ndigits}\OperatorTok{=}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Returns 3.14}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: When reviewing AI-generated code, pay attention to
how functions are called. AI assistants sometimes use keyword arguments
for clarity even when not strictly necessary. This is generally good
practice as it makes code more self-documenting.}}

\hypertarget{return-values}{%
\section{5. Return Values}\label{return-values}}

Functions often give back information after they've completed their
task. This information is called a ``return value'' and is one of the
most important concepts in programming.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Functions that return values}
\NormalTok{year\_string }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}What is the current year? \textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Returns what the user types}
\NormalTok{year\_number }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(year\_string)                     }\CommentTok{\# Converts and returns as integer}
\NormalTok{is\_leap\_year }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ year\_number }\OperatorTok{\%} \DecValTok{4} \OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}                \CommentTok{\# Returns True or False}

\CommentTok{\# Using return values in expressions}
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{greeting }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Hello, "} \OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ name }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"!"}
\NormalTok{greeting\_length }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(greeting)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Your greeting is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{greeting\_length}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ characters long."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Not all functions return values. For example, \texttt{print()} doesn't
return anything useful (it returns \texttt{None}), but \texttt{input()}
returns whatever the user types.

\hypertarget{capturing-return-values}{%
\subsection{Capturing Return Values}\label{capturing-return-values}}

It's common to save return values in variables:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Save the return value for later use}
\NormalTok{user\_age }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"How old are you? "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{age\_in\_months }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(user\_age) }\OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{12}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"You are approximately }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{age\_in\_months}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ months old."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

But you can also use return values directly:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Use return values directly in expressions}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Double your age is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}How old are you? \textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{2}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

While the second approach is more compact, the first approach is often
more readable and easier to debug.

\hypertarget{essential-built-in-functions}{%
\section{6. Essential Built-in
Functions}\label{essential-built-in-functions}}

Python comes with many useful built-in functions ready for you to use.
Here are some of the most important ones for beginners:

\hypertarget{output-and-input}{%
\subsection{Output and Input}\label{output-and-input}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Print function {-} displays information}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Learning about functions!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Input function {-} gets information from the user}
\NormalTok{user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Type something: "}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{type-conversion-1}{%
\subsection{Type Conversion}\label{type-conversion-1}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Converting between types}
\NormalTok{age\_string }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"25"}
\NormalTok{age\_number }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(age\_string)  }\CommentTok{\# Convert string to integer}
\NormalTok{price }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{19.99}
\NormalTok{price\_string }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(price)     }\CommentTok{\# Convert float to string}
\NormalTok{is\_valid }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{bool}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)            }\CommentTok{\# Convert to boolean (True)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{information-functions}{%
\subsection{Information Functions}\label{information-functions}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Type function {-} tells you the data type}
\NormalTok{data\_type }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{type}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{42}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(data\_type)  }\CommentTok{\# \textless{}class \textquotesingle{}int\textquotesingle{}\textgreater{}}

\CommentTok{\# Length function {-} tells you the size}
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Python"}
\NormalTok{name\_length }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(name)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(name\_length)  }\CommentTok{\# 6}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{math-functions}{%
\subsection{Math Functions}\label{math-functions}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Math functions}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{pow}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{)      }\CommentTok{\# 2 raised to the power of 3 (returns 8)}
\NormalTok{absolute }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{abs}\NormalTok{(}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{15}\NormalTok{)     }\CommentTok{\# Absolute value (returns 15)}
\NormalTok{maximum }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{max}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{) }\CommentTok{\# Largest value (returns 10)}
\NormalTok{minimum }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{min}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{) }\CommentTok{\# Smallest value (returns 3)}
\NormalTok{total }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{([}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{])  }\CommentTok{\# Sum of a list (returns 6)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{help-and-documentation}{%
\subsection{Help and Documentation}\label{help-and-documentation}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Get help about a function}
\BuiltInTok{help}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Displays documentation for the print function}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{finding-help-with-documentation}{%
\section{7. Finding Help with
Documentation}\label{finding-help-with-documentation}}

The \texttt{help()} function is a built-in way to access documentation
about other functions:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Get help about the len() function}
\BuiltInTok{help}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This will display information about: - What the function does - Required
and optional arguments - Return value information - Usage examples
(sometimes)

\hypertarget{reading-function-documentation}{%
\subsection{Reading Function
Documentation}\label{reading-function-documentation}}

Function documentation typically follows this pattern:

\begin{verbatim}
Help on built-in function len in module builtins:

len(obj, /)
    Return the number of items in a container.
\end{verbatim}

This tells you: - The function name (\texttt{len}) - The parameter(s) it
takes (\texttt{obj}) - What it does (``Return the number of items in a
container'')

Learning to read function documentation is an essential skill that will
help you throughout your programming journey. When you encounter a new
function, the documentation is your first resource for understanding how
to use it.

\hypertarget{online-documentation-resources}{%
\subsection{Online Documentation
Resources}\label{online-documentation-resources}}

Beyond the built-in \texttt{help()} function, you can find comprehensive
Python documentation online:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Official Python Documentation:
  \href{https://docs.python.org/}{docs.python.org}
\item
  Python Standard Library Reference: Lists all built-in functions
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: When looking for help with a function, try asking
your AI assistant: ``Explain the {[}function\_name{]} function in Python
with examples.'' This often provides clearer, more beginner-friendly
explanations than formal documentation.}}

\hypertarget{functions-in-the-ai-context}{%
\section{8. Functions in the AI
Context}\label{functions-in-the-ai-context}}

When working with AI programming assistants, understanding functions
becomes even more important. Here's how functions appear in AI
interactions:

\hypertarget{identifying-functions-in-ai-generated-code}{%
\subsection{Identifying Functions in AI-Generated
Code}\label{identifying-functions-in-ai-generated-code}}

AI assistants often organize solutions into functions:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# AI{-}generated solution to find prime numbers}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ is\_prime(number):}
    \CommentTok{"""Check if a number is prime."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ number }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ number }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ number }\OperatorTok{\%} \DecValTok{2} \OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0} \KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ number }\OperatorTok{\%} \DecValTok{3} \OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}
\NormalTok{    i }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5}
    \ControlFlowTok{while}\NormalTok{ i }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ i }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=}\NormalTok{ number:}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ number }\OperatorTok{\%}\NormalTok{ i }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0} \KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ number }\OperatorTok{\%}\NormalTok{ (i }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}
\NormalTok{        i }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{6}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_primes\_up\_to(limit):}
    \CommentTok{"""Get all prime numbers up to the specified limit."""}
\NormalTok{    primes }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ num }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{range}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, limit }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{):}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ is\_prime(num):}
\NormalTok{            primes.append(num)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ primes}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Notice how the solution is organized into two functions, each handling a
specific part of the problem.

\hypertarget{asking-ai-to-explain-functions}{%
\subsection{Asking AI to Explain
Functions}\label{asking-ai-to-explain-functions}}

When you encounter functions that are confusing, you can ask an AI
assistant to explain them:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# If you see this function:}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_data(data, threshold}\OperatorTok{=}\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{, normalize}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{\# ... complex implementation ...}

\CommentTok{\# You can ask: "Explain what the process\_data function does.}
\CommentTok{\# What are the threshold and normalize parameters used for?"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{modifying-ai-generated-functions}{%
\subsection{Modifying AI-Generated
Functions}\label{modifying-ai-generated-functions}}

Often, you'll need to customize functions that AI generates:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Original AI{-}generated function}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_total(prices):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(prices)}

\CommentTok{\# Modified to include a discount}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_total(prices, discount}\OperatorTok{=}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{    subtotal }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(prices)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ subtotal }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ (}\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ discount)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-7}{%
\section{9. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-7}}

Test your understanding of Python functions:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  What symbol follows a function's name when calling it?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Square brackets {[}{]}
  \item
    Curly braces \{\}
  \item
    Parentheses ()
  \item
    Angle brackets \textless\textgreater{}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which built-in function displays information to the screen?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{show()}
  \item
    \texttt{display()}
  \item
    \texttt{print()}
  \item
    \texttt{output()}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  The \texttt{input()} function:

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Returns nothing
  \item
    Returns what the user types as a string
  \item
    Returns an integer
  \item
    Returns True or False
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  How do you find information about a function's usage?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Using the \texttt{info()} function
  \item
    Using the \texttt{manual()} function
  \item
    Using the \texttt{help()} function
  \item
    Using the \texttt{doc()} function
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What does the \texttt{pow(2,\ 3)} function call return?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    5
  \item
    6
  \item
    8
  \item
    9
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  In the function call \texttt{print("Hello",\ "world",\ sep="-")}, what
  is \texttt{sep="-"} called?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    A positional argument
  \item
    A keyword argument
  \item
    A parameter
  \item
    A function attribute
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of these functions doesn't return a useful value?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{len()}
  \item
    \texttt{input()}
  \item
    \texttt{print()}
  \item
    \texttt{int()}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What would \texttt{len(str(42))} return?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    42
  \item
    1
  \item
    2
  \item
    Error
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers \& Feedback:} 1. c) Parentheses () --- The universal way
to call functions in Python 2. c) \texttt{print()} --- One of the most
commonly used Python functions 3. b) Returns what the user types as a
string --- Always as a string, even if the user enters numbers! 4. c)
Using the \texttt{help()} function --- Your built-in documentation
resource 5. c) 8 --- 2 raised to the power of 3 (2³ = 8) 6. b) A keyword
argument --- It's specified by name rather than position 7. c)
\texttt{print()} --- It returns \texttt{None}, not a useful value 8. c)
2 --- First converts 42 to string ``42'', then gets the length (2
characters)

\hypertarget{common-function-mistakes-to-avoid}{%
\section{10. Common Function Mistakes to
Avoid}\label{common-function-mistakes-to-avoid}}

When working with functions, be careful to avoid these common pitfalls:

\hypertarget{forgetting-parentheses}{%
\subsection{Forgetting Parentheses}\label{forgetting-parentheses}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# INCORRECT: Missing parentheses}
\NormalTok{length }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len} \StringTok{"Python"}

\CommentTok{\# CORRECT: With parentheses}
\NormalTok{length }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Python"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{incorrect-argument-types}{%
\subsection{Incorrect Argument Types}\label{incorrect-argument-types}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# INCORRECT: Passing a string to a function expecting numbers}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{max}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"10"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Error!}

\CommentTok{\# CORRECT: Convert string to integer first}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{max}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"10"}\NormalTok{), }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Returns 10}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{ignoring-return-values}{%
\subsection{Ignoring Return Values}\label{ignoring-return-values}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# INCORRECT: Ignoring return value}
\BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# User input is lost!}

\CommentTok{\# CORRECT: Capturing return value}
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{misunderstanding-none-returns}{%
\subsection{Misunderstanding None
Returns}\label{misunderstanding-none-returns}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Misconception: Thinking print() returns the string it displays}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{\# result now contains None, not "Hello"}

\CommentTok{\# CORRECT: Understanding print() returns None}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Just for display, no need to capture return value}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{confusing-function-definition-and-calling}{%
\subsection{Confusing Function Definition and
Calling}\label{confusing-function-definition-and-calling}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# This is a function definition (we\textquotesingle{}ll cover this more in the next chapter)}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ greet(name):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Hello, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}

\CommentTok{\# This is a function call}
\NormalTok{greeting }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ greet(}\StringTok{"Python learner"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{project-corner-adding-function-power-to-your-chatbot}{%
\section{11. Project Corner: Adding Function Power to Your
Chatbot}\label{project-corner-adding-function-power-to-your-chatbot}}

Let's apply what you've learned about functions to enhance your chatbot
from previous chapters:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Using functions to structure our chatbot}
\NormalTok{bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}

\CommentTok{\# Function to get user\textquotesingle{}s name}
\NormalTok{user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Using various functions together}
\NormalTok{user\_question }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What would you like to know? "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{user\_question }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_question.lower()  }\CommentTok{\# Using a string method (also a function!)}

\CommentTok{\# Process the input and generate responses}
\ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"age"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_question:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"I was created today!"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"name"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_question:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"My name is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{."}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"calculate"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_question:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"I can do math! Try asking me to calculate something."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    math\_question }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter a calculation (e.g., \textquotesingle{}2 + 2\textquotesingle{}): "}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# For now, we\textquotesingle{}ll keep it simple}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"+"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ math\_question:}
\NormalTok{        parts }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ math\_question.split(}\StringTok{"+"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(parts) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{                num1 }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(parts[}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{].strip())}
\NormalTok{                num2 }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(parts[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{].strip())}
\NormalTok{                result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ num1 }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ num2}
                \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"The answer is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{result}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{except}\NormalTok{:}
                \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Sorry, I couldn\textquotesingle{}t understand those numbers."}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"I can only handle addition for now. Stay tuned for updates!"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m still learning and don\textquotesingle{}t know how to respond to that yet."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This chatbot is functional but still has its logic all in one place. In
Chapter 9, we'll learn to create our own functions to better organize
our code and make our chatbot more maintainable.

\hypertarget{adding-a-help-function}{%
\subsection{Adding a Help Function}\label{adding-a-help-function}}

Let's add a feature to our chatbot that leverages the \texttt{help()}
function:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Enhanced chatbot with help function}
\NormalTok{bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, your Python assistant."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower()}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! It was nice talking with you."}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{break}

    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.startswith(}\StringTok{"help("}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{\# Extract the function name from help(function\_name)}
        \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            function\_name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input[}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{:}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{].strip()  }\CommentTok{\# Remove "help(" and ")"}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Let me tell you about the }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{function\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ function:"}\NormalTok{)}
            \CommentTok{\# We use the built{-}in help system but capture the output}
            \BuiltInTok{help}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{eval}\NormalTok{(function\_name))  }\CommentTok{\# This is advanced {-} we\textquotesingle{}ll explain eval later}
        \ControlFlowTok{except}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} I\textquotesingle{}m sorry, I couldn\textquotesingle{}t find information about that function."}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Here are some built{-}in functions you can ask about:"}\NormalTok{)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"  print, input, len, int, str, float, bool, max, min, sum, abs, round, pow"}\NormalTok{)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Use help(function\_name) to learn about a specific function."}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"age"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} I was created today!"}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"name"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} My name is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{."}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"calculate"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} I can do math! Try asking me to calculate something."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        math\_question }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{)}

        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"+"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ math\_question:}
\NormalTok{            parts }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ math\_question.split(}\StringTok{"+"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{if} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(parts) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{                    num1 }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(parts[}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{].strip())}
\NormalTok{                    num2 }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(parts[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{].strip())}
\NormalTok{                    result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ num1 }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ num2}
                    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} The answer is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{result}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
                \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{:}
                    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Sorry, I couldn\textquotesingle{}t understand those numbers."}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} I can only handle addition for now. Stay tuned for updates!"}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} I\textquotesingle{}m still learning and don\textquotesingle{}t know how to respond to that yet."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This enhanced chatbot now uses functions in several ways: 1. Built-in
functions like \texttt{input()}, \texttt{print()}, and \texttt{lower()}
2. The \texttt{help()} function to provide information about Python
functions 3. String functions like \texttt{split()} and \texttt{strip()}
4. Type conversion with \texttt{int()}

As you learn to create your own functions in the next chapter, you'll be
able to make your chatbot even more organized and powerful.

\textbf{Challenges}: - Add support for other mathematical operations
using the \texttt{eval()} function (with appropriate safety measures) -
Use the \texttt{max()} and \texttt{min()} functions to find the highest
or lowest number in a list - Create a feature that uses the
\texttt{len()} function to count the characters in the user's messages

\hypertarget{functions-and-ai-collaboration}{%
\section{12. Functions and AI
Collaboration}\label{functions-and-ai-collaboration}}

In the age of AI programming assistants, functions play a crucial role
in how we communicate about code. When working with AI tools, these
strategies can help you get the most out of function-related
interactions:

\hypertarget{asking-about-specific-functions}{%
\subsection{Asking About Specific
Functions}\label{asking-about-specific-functions}}

When you need to understand a Python function, specific questions yield
better results:

\begin{verbatim}
"What parameters does the sorted() function accept?"
"Show me examples of using the min() function with different argument types."
"What's the difference between print() and return in Python?"
\end{verbatim}

\hypertarget{getting-function-recommendations}{%
\subsection{Getting Function
Recommendations}\label{getting-function-recommendations}}

AI assistants can suggest appropriate functions for specific tasks:

\begin{verbatim}
"What Python function can I use to find the position of a substring?"
"Is there a built-in function to calculate the average of a list of numbers?"
"What's the best function to use for reading a text file in Python?"
\end{verbatim}

\hypertarget{improving-function-usage}{%
\subsection{Improving Function Usage}\label{improving-function-usage}}

When you already have code using functions, ask for improvements:

\begin{verbatim}
"Is there a more efficient way to write this function call?"
"How can I make this code more readable while keeping the same functionality?"
"What error handling should I add to this function call?"
\end{verbatim}

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: When an AI assistant recommends a function you're
unfamiliar with, ask it to compare that function with ones you already
know. For example: ``How is dictionary.get() different from using
dictionary{[}key{]}?'' This builds on your existing knowledge.}}

\hypertarget{summary-7}{%
\section{Summary}\label{summary-7}}

Functions are the building blocks of Python programming, allowing you to
perform tasks without understanding all the underlying details. They
provide modularity, reusability, and organization to your code.

In this chapter, you've learned: - How to call built-in Python functions
- How to pass arguments to functions correctly - How to capture and use
return values - How to find help and documentation for functions - How
functions appear in AI-generated code - How to apply function concepts
to your chatbot project

As you progress through this book, functions will become increasingly
important, especially when we start creating our own functions in the
next chapter. The ability to understand and work with functions is a
fundamental skill that will serve you well throughout your Python
journey, particularly when collaborating with AI programming assistants.

Remember that both human programmers and AI assistants organize code
using functions - they're the universal building blocks of structured
programs. By mastering functions, you're taking a significant step
toward effective programming in the AI era.

\hypertarget{introduction-function-creation-as-a-superpower}{%
\section{1. Introduction: Function Creation as a
Superpower}\label{introduction-function-creation-as-a-superpower}}

In the previous chapter, we learned how to use built-in and library
functions. Now, we'll unlock one of Python's most powerful features: the
ability to create your own custom functions. This is where programming
truly becomes creative -- you're no longer limited to what others have
built; you can craft tools perfectly tailored to your specific needs.

Creating functions is like gaining a superpower that allows you to:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Organize} your code into logical, self-contained units
\item
  \textbf{Reuse} code without copying and pasting (DRY - Don't Repeat
  Yourself)
\item
  \textbf{Abstract} complex operations behind simple interfaces
\item
  \textbf{Focus} on one problem at a time
\item
  \textbf{Test} discrete pieces of functionality
\item
  \textbf{Collaborate} by defining clear boundaries in code
\end{itemize}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Key Concept}: Functions transform programming from writing
sequential instructions to designing components that work together. This
``modular'' approach is how all sophisticated software is built, from
web browsers to AI systems.
\end{quote}

For our chatbot project, custom functions will take us from a linear
script to a well-structured program that's easier to understand, debug,
and extend. Creating functions is the first step toward proper software
architecture.

\hypertarget{function-definition-the-building-blocks}{%
\section{2. Function Definition: The Building
Blocks}\label{function-definition-the-building-blocks}}

A function in Python consists of a \textbf{header} (the definition line)
and a \textbf{body} (the indented code block that follows):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ function\_name(parameters):}
    \CommentTok{"""Docstring: explains what the function does."""}
    \CommentTok{\# Function body {-} indented code}
    \CommentTok{\# that runs when the function is called}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ result  }\CommentTok{\# Optional return statement}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Let's break down each component:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \texttt{def}: The keyword that tells Python you're defining a function
\item
  \texttt{function\_name}: A name you choose (following variable naming
  conventions)
\item
  \texttt{parameters}: Optional inputs the function can accept (in
  parentheses)
\item
  \texttt{docstring}: Optional (but recommended) documentation in triple
  quotes
\item
  Function body: The indented code block that executes when called
\item
  \texttt{return}: Optional statement to send a value back to the caller
\end{itemize}

Here's a simple example:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ greet():}
    \CommentTok{"""Display a simple greeting."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello, world!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Calling the function}
\NormalTok{greet()  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Hello, world!}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Every time you call the function, its code executes:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{greet()  }\CommentTok{\# Hello, world!}
\NormalTok{greet()  }\CommentTok{\# Hello, world!}
\NormalTok{greet()  }\CommentTok{\# Hello, world!}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{function-naming-best-practices}{%
\subsection{Function Naming Best
Practices}\label{function-naming-best-practices}}

Good function names are:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Descriptive} of what the function does
\item
  \textbf{Verb-focused} since functions perform actions (e.g.,
  \texttt{calculate\_total}, not just \texttt{total})
\item
  \textbf{Lowercase} with underscores between words (snake\_case)
\item
  \textbf{Consistent} in style throughout your program
\end{itemize}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Good function names}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_area(width, height):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ width }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ height}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ validate\_email(email):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"@"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"."} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_user\_choice():}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter your choice: "}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Less helpful function names}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calc(w, h):  }\CommentTok{\# Too vague and abbreviated}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ w }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ h}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ function1():  }\CommentTok{\# Says nothing about purpose}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{parameters-and-arguments-making-functions-flexible}{%
\section{3. Parameters and Arguments: Making Functions
Flexible}\label{parameters-and-arguments-making-functions-flexible}}

Parameters make functions adaptable by allowing them to work with
different inputs each time they're called:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ greet(name):}
    \CommentTok{"""Greet a person by name."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Calling with different arguments}
\NormalTok{greet(}\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Hello, Alice!}
\NormalTok{greet(}\StringTok{"Bob"}\NormalTok{)    }\CommentTok{\# Output: Hello, Bob!}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{required-parameters}{%
\subsection{Required Parameters}\label{required-parameters}}

In the example above, \texttt{name} is a required parameter. If you
don't provide it, Python raises an error:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{greet()  }\CommentTok{\# Error: greet() missing 1 required positional argument: \textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{multiple-parameters}{%
\subsection{Multiple Parameters}\label{multiple-parameters}}

Functions can accept multiple parameters:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ display\_info(name, age, location):}
    \CommentTok{"""Display a person\textquotesingle{}s information."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Name: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Age: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{age}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Location: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{location}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Call with multiple arguments}
\NormalTok{display\_info(}\StringTok{"Charlie"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{25}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"San Francisco"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When calling functions with multiple parameters, you must provide them
in the correct order, or use named arguments:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Positional arguments (order matters)}
\NormalTok{display\_info(}\StringTok{"Charlie"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{25}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"San Francisco"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Named arguments (order doesn\textquotesingle{}t matter)}
\NormalTok{display\_info(location}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"San Francisco"}\NormalTok{, name}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"Charlie"}\NormalTok{, age}\OperatorTok{=}\DecValTok{25}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Mix of positional and named (positional must come first)}
\NormalTok{display\_info(}\StringTok{"Charlie"}\NormalTok{, location}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"San Francisco"}\NormalTok{, age}\OperatorTok{=}\DecValTok{25}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{default-parameter-values}{%
\subsection{Default Parameter Values}\label{default-parameter-values}}

You can make parameters optional by providing default values:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ greet(name, greeting}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"Hello"}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{"""Greet a person with a customizable greeting."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{greeting}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Using the default greeting}
\NormalTok{greet(}\StringTok{"Diana"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Hello, Diana!}

\CommentTok{\# Overriding the default}
\NormalTok{greet(}\StringTok{"Edward"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Good morning"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Good morning, Edward!}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Default parameters must come after non-default parameters:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Correct: default parameter after required parameter}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ function(required, optional}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"default"}\NormalTok{):}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\CommentTok{\# Incorrect: default parameter before required parameter}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ function(optional}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"default"}\NormalTok{, required):  }\CommentTok{\# SyntaxError}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{parameter-types-and-docstrings}{%
\subsection{Parameter Types and
Docstrings}\label{parameter-types-and-docstrings}}

Good practice includes documenting the expected types and purpose of
parameters:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_total(price, quantity, tax\_rate}\OperatorTok{=}\FloatTok{0.08}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Calculate the total cost including tax.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        price (float): The price per item}
\CommentTok{        quantity (int): The number of items}
\CommentTok{        tax\_rate (float, optional): The tax rate as a decimal. Defaults to 0.08.}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        float: The total cost including tax}
\CommentTok{    """}
\NormalTok{    subtotal }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ price }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ quantity}
\NormalTok{    tax }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ subtotal }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ tax\_rate}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ subtotal }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ tax}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This documentation helps other developers (and future you) understand
how to use the function correctly.

\hypertarget{return-values-getting-results-from-functions}{%
\section{4. Return Values: Getting Results from
Functions}\label{return-values-getting-results-from-functions}}

Functions can send data back to the caller using the \texttt{return}
statement:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add(a, b):}
    \CommentTok{"""Add two numbers and return the result."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ b}

\CommentTok{\# Using the return value}
\NormalTok{sum\_result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ add(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(sum\_result)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 8}

\CommentTok{\# Using the return value directly in an expression}
\NormalTok{total }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ add(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ add(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(total)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 11}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The \texttt{return} statement immediately exits the function and sends
the specified value back:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ absolute\_value(number):}
    \CommentTok{"""Return the absolute value of a number."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ number }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ number  }\CommentTok{\# Function ends here if number is positive}

    \CommentTok{\# This code only runs if the number is negative}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{number}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(absolute\_value(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{))    }\CommentTok{\# Output: 5}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(absolute\_value(}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 10}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{returning-multiple-values}{%
\subsection{Returning Multiple Values}\label{returning-multiple-values}}

Python functions can return multiple values using tuples:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_dimensions():}
    \CommentTok{"""Return width and height."""}
\NormalTok{    width }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{800}
\NormalTok{    height }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{600}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ width, height  }\CommentTok{\# Returns a tuple (800, 600)}

\CommentTok{\# Unpacking the returned tuple}
\NormalTok{screen\_width, screen\_height }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_dimensions()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Width: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{screen\_width}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, Height: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{screen\_height}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{no-return-statement}{%
\subsection{No Return Statement}\label{no-return-statement}}

If a function doesn't include a \texttt{return} statement, Python
implicitly returns \texttt{None}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ greet(name):}
    \CommentTok{"""Greet a person by name."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# This function doesn\textquotesingle{}t explicitly return anything}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ greet(}\StringTok{"Frank"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(result)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: None}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This behavior explains why \texttt{print()} doesn't appear to return
anything - it's returning \texttt{None} after displaying output.

\hypertarget{return-early-for-validation}{%
\subsection{Return Early for
Validation}\label{return-early-for-validation}}

Returning early is useful for validation:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ divide(a, b):}
    \CommentTok{"""Divide a by b, with validation."""}
    \CommentTok{\# Validate input first}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ b }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Error: Cannot divide by zero"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{None}  \CommentTok{\# Return early on invalid input}

    \CommentTok{\# Only execute if validation passed}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ b}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{variable-scope-understanding-where-variables-live}{%
\section{5. Variable Scope: Understanding Where Variables
Live}\label{variable-scope-understanding-where-variables-live}}

When you create a variable inside a function, it only exists within that
function. This is called ``local scope'':

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ show\_local():}
    \CommentTok{"""Demonstrate local variable scope."""}
    \CommentTok{\# This variable only exists inside this function}
\NormalTok{    message }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m a local variable"}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(message)}

\NormalTok{show\_local()  }\CommentTok{\# Output: I\textquotesingle{}m a local variable}
\CommentTok{\# print(message)  \# Error: name \textquotesingle{}message\textquotesingle{} is not defined}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Parameters are also local variables:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ double(number):  }\CommentTok{\# \textquotesingle{}number\textquotesingle{} is a local variable}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ number }\OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{2}

\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ double(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{\# print(number)  \# Error: \textquotesingle{}number\textquotesingle{} doesn\textquotesingle{}t exist outside the function}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{local-vs.-global-scope}{%
\subsection{Local vs.~Global Scope}\label{local-vs.-global-scope}}

Variables defined outside any function have ``global scope'' and can be
accessed (but not modified) inside functions:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Global variable}
\NormalTok{counter }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ increment():}
    \CommentTok{"""Try to increment the counter."""}
    \CommentTok{\# This creates a new local variable, not modifying the global one}
\NormalTok{    counter }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ counter }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{1}  \CommentTok{\# UnboundLocalError}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ counter}

\CommentTok{\# To modify a global variable:}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ correct\_increment():}
    \CommentTok{"""Increment the global counter."""}
    \KeywordTok{global}\NormalTok{ counter  }\CommentTok{\# Declare that we want to use the global variable}
\NormalTok{    counter }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ counter }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{1}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ counter}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

However, it's generally better practice to pass values as parameters and
return results, rather than relying on global variables:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Better approach}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ increment(value):}
    \CommentTok{"""Increment the given value."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ value }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{1}

\NormalTok{counter }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\NormalTok{counter }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ increment(counter)  }\CommentTok{\# counter becomes 1}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{variable-lifetime}{%
\subsection{Variable Lifetime}\label{variable-lifetime}}

Local variables are created when the function is called and destroyed
when it returns:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_data():}
\NormalTok{    temp }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{100}  \CommentTok{\# Created when function starts}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Processing at }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{temp}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \CommentTok{\# \textquotesingle{}temp\textquotesingle{} is destroyed when function ends}

\NormalTok{process\_data()}
\NormalTok{process\_data()  }\CommentTok{\# Creates a fresh \textquotesingle{}temp\textquotesingle{} variable}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This explains why functions don't ``remember'' values from previous
calls unless you use global variables or other techniques we'll learn
later.

\hypertarget{designing-effective-functions}{%
\section{6. Designing Effective
Functions}\label{designing-effective-functions}}

Well-designed functions follow several principles:

\hypertarget{single-responsibility-principle}{%
\subsection{1. Single Responsibility
Principle}\label{single-responsibility-principle}}

Each function should have one clear purpose:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Too many responsibilities}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_user(name):}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Processing user: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    validate\_email(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{@example.com"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    create\_account(name)}
\NormalTok{    send\_welcome\_email(name)}

\CommentTok{\# Better: separate functions for each responsibility}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ validate\_user\_email(email):}
    \CommentTok{"""Check if email is valid."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"@"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"."} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ create\_user\_account(username):}
    \CommentTok{"""Create account in the system."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Creating account for }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{username}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ send\_welcome\_email(email):}
    \CommentTok{"""Send welcome message to user."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Sending welcome email to }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{email}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{keep-functions-short-and-focused}{%
\subsection{2. Keep Functions Short and
Focused}\label{keep-functions-short-and-focused}}

Aim for functions that fit on one screen (20-30 lines maximum):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Too long and complex}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ do\_everything():}
    \CommentTok{\# 100 lines of code doing many different things}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\CommentTok{\# Better: break into smaller functions}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ validate\_input():}
    \CommentTok{\# 10 lines of code}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_data():}
    \CommentTok{\# 15 lines of code}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ generate\_report():}
    \CommentTok{\# 20 lines of code}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{use-descriptive-names-and-documentation}{%
\subsection{3. Use Descriptive Names and
Documentation}\label{use-descriptive-names-and-documentation}}

Make your functions self-documenting:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Unclear}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calc(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ b}

\CommentTok{\# Better}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_rectangle\_area(width, height):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Calculate the area of a rectangle.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        width (float): Width of the rectangle}
\CommentTok{        height (float): Height of the rectangle}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        float: Area of the rectangle}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ width }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ height}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{minimize-side-effects}{%
\subsection{4. Minimize Side Effects}\label{minimize-side-effects}}

Functions should ideally return values rather than modifying global
state:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Function with side effects}
\NormalTok{total }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add\_to\_total(value):}
    \KeywordTok{global}\NormalTok{ total}
\NormalTok{    total }\OperatorTok{+=}\NormalTok{ value}

\CommentTok{\# Better: pure function}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ b}

\NormalTok{total }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ add(total, value)  }\CommentTok{\# Explicit about what\textquotesingle{}s changing}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{error-handling}{%
\subsection{5. Error Handling}\label{error-handling}}

Consider what happens when things go wrong:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ divide(a, b):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Divide a by b.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        a (float): Numerator}
\CommentTok{        b (float): Denominator (must be non{-}zero)}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        float: Result of a/b, or None if division by zero attempted}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ b }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Error: Cannot divide by zero"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{None}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ b}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{project-corner-structuring-your-chatbot-with-functions}{%
\section{7. Project Corner: Structuring Your Chatbot with
Functions}\label{project-corner-structuring-your-chatbot-with-functions}}

Now let's apply these principles to enhance our chatbot project with
well-designed functions. Previously, we had a simple script; now we'll
organize it into modular, reusable components.

\hypertarget{basic-function-based-chatbot}{%
\subsection{Basic Function-Based
Chatbot}\label{basic-function-based-chatbot}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input, user\_name):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Generate a response based on user input.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        user\_input (str): The user\textquotesingle{}s message}
\CommentTok{        user\_name (str): The user\textquotesingle{}s name}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        str: The chatbot\textquotesingle{}s response}
\CommentTok{    """}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower()}

    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"hello"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"hi"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Hello there, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"how are you"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m just a computer program, but thanks for asking!"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"your name"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"My name is PyBot. I\textquotesingle{}m here to help you learn Python!"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"bye"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"goodbye"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! Have a great day!"}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m not sure how to respond to that yet."}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ run\_chatbot():}
    \CommentTok{"""Run the main chatbot interaction loop."""}
\NormalTok{    bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. Type \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to exit."}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{    user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{break}

\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input, user\_name)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Run the chatbot if this file is executed directly}
\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"\_\_main\_\_"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    run\_chatbot()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This approach already improves our code by: - Separating response
generation into a dedicated function - Adding proper documentation with
docstrings - Creating a main function that handles the chatbot loop -
Using a conditional to only run the chatbot when the file is executed
directly

\hypertarget{enhanced-modular-chatbot}{%
\subsection{Enhanced Modular Chatbot}\label{enhanced-modular-chatbot}}

Let's take it further by adding more functions for specific tasks:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_user\_name():}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Get the user\textquotesingle{}s name with basic validation.}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        str: The user\textquotesingle{}s name}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{).strip()}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ name:  }\CommentTok{\# Check that name isn\textquotesingle{}t empty}
            \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ name}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"I didn\textquotesingle{}t catch that. Please tell me your name."}\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ display\_welcome(bot\_name):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Display the welcome message.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        bot\_name (str): The chatbot\textquotesingle{}s name}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"} \OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Welcome to }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"="} \OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, a simple chatbot."}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"I can help you learn about Python functions."}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Type \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to exit, \textquotesingle{}help\textquotesingle{} for commands.}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_user\_input(user\_name):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Get input from the user with their name as prompt.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        user\_name (str): The user\textquotesingle{}s name}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        str: The user\textquotesingle{}s input}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{).strip()}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ display\_response(bot\_name, response):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Display the chatbot\textquotesingle{}s response.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        bot\_name (str): The chatbot\textquotesingle{}s name}
\CommentTok{        response (str): The response to display}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input, user\_name):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Generate a response based on user input.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        user\_input (str): The user\textquotesingle{}s message}
\CommentTok{        user\_name (str): The user\textquotesingle{}s name}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        str: The chatbot\textquotesingle{}s response}
\CommentTok{    """}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower()}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for specific commands}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ get\_help\_message()}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for greetings}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \BuiltInTok{any}\NormalTok{(greeting }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ greeting }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hi"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hey"}\NormalTok{]):}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Hello there, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for questions about the bot}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"your name"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"My name is PyBot. I\textquotesingle{}m a simple chatbot built with Python functions!"}

    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"how are you"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m just a computer program, but I\textquotesingle{}m functioning well. Thanks for asking!"}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for farewells}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \BuiltInTok{any}\NormalTok{(farewell }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ farewell }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"exit"}\NormalTok{]):}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! Have a great day!"}

    \CommentTok{\# Default response}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m not sure how to respond to that yet. Type \textquotesingle{}help\textquotesingle{} for commands."}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_help\_message():}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Return the help message.}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        str: The help message}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"""}
\StringTok{I understand the following:}
\StringTok{{-} Greetings (hello, hi)}
\StringTok{{-} Questions about me}
\StringTok{{-} \textquotesingle{}how are you\textquotesingle{}}
\StringTok{{-} \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} or \textquotesingle{}goodbye\textquotesingle{} to exit}
\StringTok{"""}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ run\_chatbot():}
    \CommentTok{"""Run the main chatbot interaction loop."""}
\NormalTok{    bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}

\NormalTok{    display\_welcome(bot\_name)}
\NormalTok{    user\_name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_user\_name()}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_user\_input(user\_name)}

        \CommentTok{\# Check for exit command}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            display\_response(bot\_name, }\SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{break}

\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input, user\_name)}
\NormalTok{        display\_response(bot\_name, response)}

\CommentTok{\# Run the chatbot if this file is executed directly}
\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"\_\_main\_\_"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    run\_chatbot()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This enhanced version demonstrates several advanced function design
principles:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Each function has a single responsibility} - input, output,
  logic, etc.
\item
  \textbf{Functions are composable} - the main function calls smaller
  functions
\item
  \textbf{Error handling is built in} - input validation in
  \texttt{get\_user\_name()}
\item
  \textbf{Code is self-documenting} - function names clearly describe
  their purpose
\item
  \textbf{Helper functions hide complexity} - like
  \texttt{get\_help\_message()}
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{adding-new-capabilities-with-functions}{%
\subsection{Adding New Capabilities with
Functions}\label{adding-new-capabilities-with-functions}}

When you want to extend your chatbot, you can simply add new functions:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_age(birth\_year):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Calculate age based on birth year.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        birth\_year (int): The year the person was born}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        int: The calculated age (approximate)}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ datetime }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ datetime}
\NormalTok{    current\_year }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.now().year}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ current\_year }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ birth\_year}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ handle\_age\_question(user\_input):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Extract birth year from input and calculate age.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        user\_input (str): The user\textquotesingle{}s message}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        str: Age calculation response or None if not an age question}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"calculate age"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"how old"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower():}
        \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
            \CommentTok{\# Try to extract a year from the input}
\NormalTok{            words }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.split()}
            \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ word }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ words:}
