                \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ word.isdigit() }\KeywordTok{and} \DecValTok{1900} \OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(word) }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{2020}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{                    age }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ calculate\_age(}\BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(word))}
                    \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"If you were born in }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{word}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, you are approximately }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{age}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ years old now."}

            \CommentTok{\# If no year found, ask for it}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I can calculate age. What year were you born?"}
        \ControlFlowTok{except}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I couldn\textquotesingle{}t calculate that age. Try specifying a birth year between 1900 and 2020."}

    \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{None}  \CommentTok{\# Not an age question}

\CommentTok{\# Then in get\_response():}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input, user\_name):}
    \CommentTok{\# Existing response logic...}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for age{-}related questions}
\NormalTok{    age\_response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ handle\_age\_question(user\_input)}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ age\_response:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ age\_response}

    \CommentTok{\# Other response logic...}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This modular approach makes extending your chatbot clean and manageable.
Each new capability goes into its own function, keeping your code
organized.

\hypertarget{ai-collaboration-corner-designing-better-functions}{%
\section{8. AI Collaboration Corner: Designing Better
Functions}\label{ai-collaboration-corner-designing-better-functions}}

Let's explore how AI assistants can help you create better functions in
your Python code.

\hypertarget{before-vague-prompting-3}{%
\subsection{Before: Vague Prompting}\label{before-vague-prompting-3}}

\begin{verbatim}
Help me create a function in Python.
\end{verbatim}

\textbf{AI Response:} \emph{To create a function in Python, you use the
\texttt{def} keyword followed by the function name and parentheses.
Here's a basic example:}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ greet(name):}
    \CommentTok{"""This function greets the person passed in as a parameter."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{greet(}\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Hello, Alice!}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\emph{Functions can have parameters, return values, and docstrings that
explain what they do. Parameters make your functions reusable with
different inputs.}

This response provides basic information but doesn't address specific
function design needs.

\hypertarget{after-detailed-specific-prompting-3}{%
\subsection{After: Detailed, Specific
Prompting}\label{after-detailed-specific-prompting-3}}

\begin{verbatim}
I'm building a chatbot that needs to process user input and determine sentiment
(positive/negative/neutral). I want to create a well-designed function that:

1. Takes a message string as input
2. Analyzes the text for positive and negative keywords
3. Returns both a sentiment label and a confidence score

Please provide a function with proper documentation, parameter validation, and
error handling. Also explain any design decisions in your implementation.
\end{verbatim}

\textbf{AI Response:} \emph{Here's a well-designed function to analyze
sentiment in chatbot messages:}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ analyze\_sentiment(message, custom\_keywords}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Analyze the sentiment of a message as positive, negative, or neutral.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        message (str): The user message to analyze}
\CommentTok{        custom\_keywords (dict, optional): Dictionary with custom \textquotesingle{}positive\textquotesingle{} and}
\CommentTok{                                         \textquotesingle{}negative\textquotesingle{} keyword lists to use instead}
\CommentTok{                                         of the defaults}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        tuple: (sentiment, confidence) where:}
\CommentTok{            {-} sentiment (str): \textquotesingle{}positive\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}negative\textquotesingle{}, or \textquotesingle{}neutral\textquotesingle{}}
\CommentTok{            {-} confidence (float): Score between 0.0 and 1.0 indicating confidence}

\CommentTok{    Raises:}
\CommentTok{        TypeError: If message is not a string or custom\_keywords is not a dict/None}
\CommentTok{        ValueError: If message is empty}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \CommentTok{\# Validate inputs}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not} \BuiltInTok{isinstance}\NormalTok{(message, }\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{):}
        \ControlFlowTok{raise} \PreprocessorTok{TypeError}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Message must be a string"}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ custom\_keywords }\KeywordTok{is} \KeywordTok{not} \VariableTok{None} \KeywordTok{and} \KeywordTok{not} \BuiltInTok{isinstance}\NormalTok{(custom\_keywords, }\BuiltInTok{dict}\NormalTok{):}
        \ControlFlowTok{raise} \PreprocessorTok{TypeError}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Custom keywords must be a dictionary"}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ message.strip():}
        \ControlFlowTok{raise} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Message cannot be empty"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Prepare the message for analysis}
\NormalTok{    message }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ message.lower()}
\NormalTok{    words }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ message.split()}

    \CommentTok{\# Default sentiment keywords}
\NormalTok{    default\_keywords }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
        \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}positive\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}happy\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}glad\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}good\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}great\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}excellent\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}wonderful\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{,}
                     \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}amazing\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}love\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}like\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}thanks\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}thank\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}awesome\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{],}
        \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}negative\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}bad\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}sad\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}terrible\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}awful\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}horrible\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}hate\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{,}
                     \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}dislike\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}sorry\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}disappointed\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}unhappy\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}wrong\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{    \}}

    \CommentTok{\# Use custom keywords if provided, otherwise use defaults}
\NormalTok{    keywords }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ custom\_keywords }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ custom\_keywords }\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{ default\_keywords}

    \CommentTok{\# Count sentiment matches}
\NormalTok{    positive\_matches }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1} \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ word }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ words }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ word }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ keywords[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}positive\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{])}
\NormalTok{    negative\_matches }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1} \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ word }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ words }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ word }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ keywords[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}negative\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{])}
\NormalTok{    total\_sentiment\_words }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ positive\_matches }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ negative\_matches}

    \CommentTok{\# Calculate sentiment and confidence}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ total\_sentiment\_words }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}neutral\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.5}  \CommentTok{\# No sentiment words found}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ positive\_matches }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ negative\_matches:}
\NormalTok{        sentiment }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}positive\textquotesingle{}}
\NormalTok{        confidence }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ positive\_matches }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ total\_sentiment\_words}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ negative\_matches }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ positive\_matches:}
\NormalTok{        sentiment }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}negative\textquotesingle{}}
\NormalTok{        confidence }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ negative\_matches }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ total\_sentiment\_words}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        sentiment }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}neutral\textquotesingle{}}
\NormalTok{        confidence }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{0.5}

    \CommentTok{\# Adjust confidence to be between 0.5 and 1.0 (0.5 = neutral)}
\NormalTok{    confidence }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{0.5} \OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ (confidence }\OperatorTok{*} \FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ sentiment, confidence}

\CommentTok{\# Example usage:}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ demo\_sentiment\_analysis():}
    \CommentTok{"""Run examples of sentiment analysis."""}
\NormalTok{    test\_messages }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}
        \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m really happy with your service, thank you!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"This is absolutely terrible and disappointing."}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"The weather is cloudy today."}
\NormalTok{    ]}

    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ message }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ test\_messages:}
\NormalTok{        sentiment, confidence }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ analyze\_sentiment(message)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Message: \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{message}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}"}\NormalTok{)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Sentiment: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{sentiment}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, Confidence: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{confidence}\SpecialCharTok{:.2f\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\emph{Design decisions explained:}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \emph{Function signature:}

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{Primary parameter (\texttt{message}) for the text to analyze}
  \item
    \emph{Optional parameter (\texttt{custom\_keywords}) for
    flexibility/customization}
  \item
    \emph{Return value is a tuple with both result and confidence score}
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \emph{Robust validation:}

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{Type checking for parameters}
  \item
    \emph{Empty message validation}
  \item
    \emph{Explicit error messages for troubleshooting}
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \emph{Well-structured implementation:}

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{Message preprocessing (lowercase, word splitting)}
  \item
    \emph{Default keywords with option for customization}
  \item
    \emph{Explicit algorithm for sentiment determination}
  \item
    \emph{Confidence scoring scaled to a meaningful range}
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \emph{Complete documentation:}

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{Clear description of function purpose}
  \item
    \emph{Detailed parameter documentation}
  \item
    \emph{Return value format explanation}
  \item
    \emph{Documentation of potential errors}
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \emph{Design principle: Single Responsibility:}

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{The function does one thing well (sentiment analysis)}
  \item
    \emph{Doesn't mix other concerns like input/output}
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

\emph{This function demonstrates good practices like thorough
validation, flexible parameters, meaningful return values, and
comprehensive documentation. It's also designed to be extended easily
(e.g., by providing custom keywords).}

\hypertarget{how-to-craft-effective-prompts-for-function-design}{%
\subsection{How to Craft Effective Prompts for Function
Design}\label{how-to-craft-effective-prompts-for-function-design}}

When working with an AI assistant on function design:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  \textbf{Specify the exact purpose} of the function you need
\item
  \textbf{Describe inputs and outputs} clearly
\item
  \textbf{Mention any special requirements} like error handling or
  validation
\item
  \textbf{Ask about design considerations} specific to your use case
\item
  \textbf{Request documentation} if you want it included
\end{enumerate}

For example:

\begin{verbatim}
I need to create a function that validates user registration data with these requirements:
1. It should check username (letters/numbers only, 3-15 chars), email (must have @ and .),
   and password (8+ chars with at least one number)
2. For invalid data, it should return specific error messages about what's wrong
3. For valid data, it should return a success message
4. The function should be well-documented and follow Python best practices

Please provide the function code with comments explaining the implementation.
\end{verbatim}

This specific prompt will yield a well-designed validation function
tailored to your exact requirements.

\hypertarget{common-function-design-pitfalls-to-avoid}{%
\section{9. Common Function Design Pitfalls to
Avoid}\label{common-function-design-pitfalls-to-avoid}}

As you create your own functions, watch for these common issues:

\hypertarget{too-many-parameters}{%
\subsection{Too Many Parameters}\label{too-many-parameters}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Hard to use and understand}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ create\_user(name, email, password, age, location, interests, account\_type,}
\NormalTok{                newsletter, referral\_code, language, theme\_preference):}
    \CommentTok{\# Function with too many parameters}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\CommentTok{\# Better approach}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ create\_user(name, email, password, }\OperatorTok{**}\NormalTok{optional\_fields):}
    \CommentTok{\# Core parameters separate from optional ones}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\CommentTok{\# Or use a dictionary/class for related parameters}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ create\_user(user\_data):}
    \CommentTok{\# Access fields with user\_data[\textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}], etc.}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{side-effects-without-documentation}{%
\subsection{Side Effects Without
Documentation}\label{side-effects-without-documentation}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Surprising side effect}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_stats(data):}
    \CommentTok{"""Calculate mean and median of data."""}
\NormalTok{    data.sort()  }\CommentTok{\# Side effect: modifies input list!}
\NormalTok{    mean }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(data) }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(data)}
\NormalTok{    median }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ data[}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(data) }\OperatorTok{//} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ mean, median}

\CommentTok{\# Better: document the side effect}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_stats(data):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Calculate statistics from data.}

\CommentTok{    Note: This function sorts the input list in{-}place.}
\CommentTok{    """}
\NormalTok{    data.sort()}
    \CommentTok{\# Rest of function...}

\CommentTok{\# Best: avoid the side effect}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_stats(data):}
    \CommentTok{"""Calculate statistics from data (non{-}modifying)."""}
\NormalTok{    sorted\_data }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sorted}\NormalTok{(data)  }\CommentTok{\# Creates a new sorted list}
    \CommentTok{\# Use sorted\_data instead of modifying input}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{not-handling-edge-cases}{%
\subsection{Not Handling Edge Cases}\label{not-handling-edge-cases}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Missing edge case handling}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(numbers):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(numbers) }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers)  }\CommentTok{\# Crashes on empty list}

\CommentTok{\# Better approach}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(numbers):}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ numbers:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \DecValTok{0}  \CommentTok{\# Or raise an exception, or return None}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(numbers) }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{function-naming-confusion}{%
\subsection{Function Naming Confusion}\label{function-naming-confusion}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Confusing name {-} doesn\textquotesingle{}t match behavior}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ check\_email(email):}
    \CommentTok{"""Validates an email and returns a boolean."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"@"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"."} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email}

\CommentTok{\# Better name}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ is\_valid\_email(email):}
    \CommentTok{"""Validates an email and returns a boolean."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"@"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"."} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email}

\CommentTok{\# Or}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ validate\_email(email):}
    \CommentTok{"""Validates an email and returns errors or None."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"@"} \KeywordTok{not} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Email must contain @ symbol"}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"."} \KeywordTok{not} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Email must contain a domain"}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{None}  \CommentTok{\# No errors}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{inconsistent-return-types}{%
\subsection{Inconsistent Return Types}\label{inconsistent-return-types}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Inconsistent {-} sometimes returns bool, sometimes string}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_payment(amount):}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ amount }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Invalid amount"}  \CommentTok{\# String}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ process\_successful:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}  \CommentTok{\# Boolean}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Payment failed"}  \CommentTok{\# String}

\CommentTok{\# Better approach {-} consistent return type}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_payment(amount):}
    \CommentTok{"""Process payment and return result with message."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ amount }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Invalid amount"}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ process\_successful:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Payment successful"}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Payment failed"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{doing-too-much-in-one-function}{%
\subsection{Doing Too Much in One
Function}\label{doing-too-much-in-one-function}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Function trying to do too much}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_order(order\_id):}
    \CommentTok{\# Validate the order}
    \CommentTok{\# Calculate the total}
    \CommentTok{\# Process payment}
    \CommentTok{\# Update inventory}
    \CommentTok{\# Send confirmation email}
    \CommentTok{\# Update order status}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\CommentTok{\# Better: separate functions for each responsibility}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ validate\_order(order\_id):}
    \CommentTok{\# Validation logic}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_order\_total(order\_items):}
    \CommentTok{\# Calculation logic}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_payment(amount, payment\_method):}
    \CommentTok{\# Payment processing}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\CommentTok{\# Etc.}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{real-world-function-examples}{%
\section{10. Real-World Function
Examples}\label{real-world-function-examples}}

Let's look at some realistic examples of function design in different
contexts:

\hypertarget{data-processing-function}{%
\subsection{Data Processing Function}\label{data-processing-function}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ clean\_data(data, columns}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{, drop\_duplicates}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{, fill\_missing}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Clean a pandas DataFrame by handling specified issues.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        data (pandas.DataFrame): The DataFrame to clean}
\CommentTok{        columns (list, optional): Specific columns to clean. Defaults to all columns.}
\CommentTok{        drop\_duplicates (bool, optional): Whether to remove duplicate rows. Defaults to True.}
\CommentTok{        fill\_missing (dict, optional): How to fill missing values \{column: value\}.}
\CommentTok{                                       Defaults to None (don\textquotesingle{}t fill).}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        pandas.DataFrame: The cleaned DataFrame}
\CommentTok{        dict: Summary of changes made}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ pandas }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ pd}

    \CommentTok{\# Validate input}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not} \BuiltInTok{isinstance}\NormalTok{(data, pd.DataFrame):}
        \ControlFlowTok{raise} \PreprocessorTok{TypeError}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"data must be a pandas DataFrame"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Work on a copy to avoid modifying the original}
\NormalTok{    df }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ data.copy()}

    \CommentTok{\# Track changes for summary}
\NormalTok{    changes }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
        \StringTok{"rows\_before"}\NormalTok{: }\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(df),}
        \StringTok{"duplicates\_removed"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"missing\_values\_filled"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{0}
\NormalTok{    \}}

    \CommentTok{\# Use only specified columns if provided}
\NormalTok{    working\_columns }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ columns }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ columns }\KeywordTok{is} \KeywordTok{not} \VariableTok{None} \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{ df.columns}

    \CommentTok{\# Handle duplicates if requested}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ drop\_duplicates:}
\NormalTok{        before\_rows }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(df)}
\NormalTok{        df }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ df.drop\_duplicates(subset}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{working\_columns)}
\NormalTok{        changes[}\StringTok{"duplicates\_removed"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ before\_rows }\OperatorTok{{-}} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(df)}

    \CommentTok{\# Fill missing values if specified}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ fill\_missing:}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ col, value }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ fill\_missing.items():}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ col }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ df.columns:}
\NormalTok{                missing\_count }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ df[col].isna().}\BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{()}
\NormalTok{                df[col] }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ df[col].fillna(value)}
\NormalTok{                changes[}\StringTok{"missing\_values\_filled"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+=}\NormalTok{ missing\_count}

\NormalTok{    changes[}\StringTok{"rows\_after"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(df)}

    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ df, changes}

\CommentTok{\# Example usage:}
\CommentTok{\# df, summary = clean\_data(customer\_data,}
\CommentTok{\#                          columns=["name", "email"],}
\CommentTok{\#                          fill\_missing=\{"age": 0, "income": 0\})}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{web-application-function}{%
\subsection{Web Application Function}\label{web-application-function}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ authenticate\_user(username, password, max\_attempts}\OperatorTok{=}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, lockout\_minutes}\OperatorTok{=}\DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Authenticate a user against the database.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        username (str): The username to authenticate}
\CommentTok{        password (str): The password to verify}
\CommentTok{        max\_attempts (int, optional): Maximum failed attempts before lockout. Defaults to 3.}
\CommentTok{        lockout\_minutes (int, optional): Minutes to lock account after max\_attempts. Defaults to 30.}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        dict: Authentication result with format:}
\CommentTok{              \{"success": bool, "user\_id": int or None, "message": str\}}

\CommentTok{    Note:}
\CommentTok{        This function updates the database attempts counter and lockout status.}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ datetime}

    \CommentTok{\# Validate inputs}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ username }\KeywordTok{or} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ password:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{"success"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"user\_id"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"message"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"Username and password required"}\NormalTok{\}}

    \CommentTok{\# Check if user exists}
\NormalTok{    user }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_user\_by\_username(username)}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ user:}
        \CommentTok{\# Don\textquotesingle{}t reveal that the username doesn\textquotesingle{}t exist (security best practice)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{"success"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"user\_id"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"message"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"Invalid credentials"}\NormalTok{\}}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for account lockout}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user.locked\_until }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ user.locked\_until }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ datetime.datetime.now():}
\NormalTok{        remaining\_minutes }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ (user.locked\_until }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ datetime.datetime.now()).seconds }\OperatorTok{//} \DecValTok{60}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ \{}
            \StringTok{"success"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{,}
            \StringTok{"user\_id"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{,}
            \StringTok{"message"}\NormalTok{: }\SpecialStringTok{f"Account temporarily locked. Try again in }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{remaining\_minutes}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ minutes."}
\NormalTok{        \}}

    \CommentTok{\# Reset lockout if it has expired}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user.locked\_until }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ user.locked\_until }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=}\NormalTok{ datetime.datetime.now():}
\NormalTok{        user.failed\_attempts }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\NormalTok{        user.locked\_until }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}
\NormalTok{        update\_user(user)}

    \CommentTok{\# Verify password}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ verify\_password(password, user.password\_hash):}
        \CommentTok{\# Success: reset failed attempts and return success}
\NormalTok{        user.failed\_attempts }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\NormalTok{        update\_user(user)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{"success"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"user\_id"}\NormalTok{: user.}\BuiltInTok{id}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"message"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"Login successful"}\NormalTok{\}}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Failed attempt: increment counter}
\NormalTok{        user.failed\_attempts }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}

        \CommentTok{\# Check if should lock account}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user.failed\_attempts }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=}\NormalTok{ max\_attempts:}
\NormalTok{            lockout\_time }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.datetime.now() }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ datetime.timedelta(minutes}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{lockout\_minutes)}
\NormalTok{            user.locked\_until }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ lockout\_time}
\NormalTok{            message }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Too many failed attempts. Account locked for }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{lockout\_minutes}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ minutes."}
        \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            attempts\_left }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ max\_attempts }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ user.failed\_attempts}
\NormalTok{            message }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Invalid credentials. }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{attempts\_left}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ attempts remaining."}

\NormalTok{        update\_user(user)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{"success"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"user\_id"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"message"}\NormalTok{: message\}}

\CommentTok{\# Note: This assumes helper functions get\_user\_by\_username(),}
\CommentTok{\# verify\_password(), and update\_user() exist elsewhere}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{game-development-function}{%
\subsection{Game Development Function}\label{game-development-function}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_damage(attacker, defender, attack\_type}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"normal"}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Calculate damage for an attack in a game.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        attacker (dict): Attacker stats including \textquotesingle{}strength\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}level\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}weapon\_power\textquotesingle{}}
\CommentTok{        defender (dict): Defender stats including \textquotesingle{}defense\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}level\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}resistance\textquotesingle{}}
\CommentTok{        attack\_type (str, optional): Type of attack {-} "normal", "critical", or "special".}
\CommentTok{                                    Defaults to "normal".}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        dict: Damage calculation results including:}
\CommentTok{              {-} \textquotesingle{}damage\textquotesingle{}: Final damage amount (int)}
\CommentTok{              {-} \textquotesingle{}critical\textquotesingle{}: Whether it was a critical hit (bool)}
\CommentTok{              {-} \textquotesingle{}hit\textquotesingle{}: Whether the attack landed (bool)}
\CommentTok{              {-} \textquotesingle{}message\textquotesingle{}: Description of the attack result (str)}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ random}

    \CommentTok{\# Base damage calculation}
\NormalTok{    base\_damage }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ (attacker.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}strength\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ attacker.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}weapon\_power\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{*} \FloatTok{1.5}

    \CommentTok{\# Accuracy check (chance to miss)}
\NormalTok{    accuracy }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{min}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{95}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{80} \OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ (attacker.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}level\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ defender.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}level\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)) }\OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    hit\_roll }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ random.randint(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Check if attack hits}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ hit\_roll }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ accuracy:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ \{}
            \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}damage\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{,}
            \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}critical\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{,}
            \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}hit\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{,}
            \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}message\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"The attack missed!"}
\NormalTok{        \}}

    \CommentTok{\# Critical hit chance}
\NormalTok{    critical\_chance }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{min}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{25}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{5} \OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ attacker.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}level\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{//} \DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    is\_critical }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ random.randint(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=}\NormalTok{ critical\_chance}

    \CommentTok{\# Damage modifiers}
\NormalTok{    damage\_multiplier }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{1.0}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ is\_critical:}
\NormalTok{        damage\_multiplier }\OperatorTok{*=} \FloatTok{2.0}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ attack\_type }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"critical"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        damage\_multiplier }\OperatorTok{*=} \FloatTok{1.5}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ attack\_type }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"special"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        damage\_multiplier }\OperatorTok{*=} \FloatTok{1.75}

    \CommentTok{\# Apply defender\textquotesingle{}s defense}
\NormalTok{    defense\_reduction }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ defender.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}defense\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{*} \FloatTok{0.5}
\NormalTok{    damage }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{max}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{((base\_damage }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ defense\_reduction) }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ damage\_multiplier))}

    \CommentTok{\# Apply damage resistance for special attacks}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ attack\_type }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"special"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        resistance }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ defender.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}resistance\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{/} \DecValTok{100}
\NormalTok{        damage }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(damage }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ (}\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{{-}} \BuiltInTok{min}\NormalTok{(}\FloatTok{0.75}\NormalTok{, resistance)))}

    \CommentTok{\# Create result message}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ is\_critical:}
\NormalTok{        message }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Critical hit! "}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        message }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{""}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ attack\_type }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"special"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        message }\OperatorTok{+=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Special attack deals }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{damage}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ damage!"}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        message }\OperatorTok{+=} \SpecialStringTok{f"The attack deals }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{damage}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ damage."}

    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ \{}
        \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}damage\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: damage,}
        \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}critical\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: is\_critical,}
        \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}hit\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}message\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: message}
\NormalTok{    \}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

These examples demonstrate how functions in real-world applications
handle multiple parameters, process complex logic, implement validation,
and return structured results. Notice how each function:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Has clear documentation
\item
  Validates inputs
\item
  Has sensible defaults for optional parameters
\item
  Returns structured data with multiple pieces of information
\item
  Maintains a single responsibility despite complex internal logic
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-8}{%
\section{11. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-8}}

Test your understanding of Python function creation:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  What is the correct syntax for defining a function that takes a
  parameter?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{function\ my\_func(param):}
  \item
    \texttt{def\ my\_func{[}param{]}:}
  \item
    \texttt{def\ my\_func(param):}
  \item
    \texttt{new\ my\_func(param):}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What happens if a function doesn't include a \texttt{return}
  statement?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    The function returns the value of the last expression
  \item
    The function returns \texttt{False}
  \item
    The function returns \texttt{None}
  \item
    The function raises an error
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  If a function has a parameter with a default value, where must it be
  placed?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    It must be the first parameter
  \item
    It must be after all parameters without default values
  \item
    It can be placed anywhere in the parameter list
  \item
    Default values are not allowed in function parameters
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What does the term ``function scope'' refer to?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    The range of values a function can return
  \item
    The visibility and lifetime of variables within a function
  \item
    The number of parameters a function can accept
  \item
    The performance characteristics of a function
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of the following is the best practice for function design?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Creating functions with as many features as possible
  \item
    Using global variables for communication between functions
  \item
    Having functions perform a single, well-defined task
  \item
    Minimizing the number of functions in your program
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What is a ``docstring'' in a Python function?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    A special comment that becomes part of the function's help
    documentation
  \item
    A mandatory error message for when the function fails
  \item
    A type of return value
  \item
    A system for categorizing functions
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  When is it appropriate to use default parameter values?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Never, they make functions confusing
  \item
    For parameters that are commonly passed the same value
  \item
    Only for numeric parameters
  \item
    Only when the function has exactly one parameter
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What happens to local variables when a function finishes execution?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    They remain in memory permanently
  \item
    They are destroyed and their memory is reclaimed
  \item
    They become global variables
  \item
    They are saved to disk
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers:} 1. c) \texttt{def\ my\_func(param):} - This is the
correct Python syntax for function definition 2. c) The function returns
\texttt{None} - Python implicitly returns None if no return statement is
provided 3. b) It must be after all parameters without default values -
Python requires default parameters to come after non-default ones 4. b)
The visibility and lifetime of variables within a function - Scope
determines where variables can be accessed 5. c) Having functions
perform a single, well-defined task - The single responsibility
principle 6. a) A special comment that becomes part of the function's
help documentation - Docstrings document function purpose and usage 7.
b) For parameters that are commonly passed the same value - Default
values reduce repetition for common cases 8. b) They are destroyed and
their memory is reclaimed - Local variables only exist during function
execution

\hypertarget{try-it-yourself-function-design-exercises}{%
\section{12. Try It Yourself: Function Design
Exercises}\label{try-it-yourself-function-design-exercises}}

Practice your function design skills with these exercises:

\hypertarget{exercise-1-basic-function-creation}{%
\subsection{Exercise 1: Basic Function
Creation}\label{exercise-1-basic-function-creation}}
