\hypertarget{introduction-the-power-of-choice-in-programming}{%
\section{1. Introduction: The Power of Choice in
Programming}\label{introduction-the-power-of-choice-in-programming}}

So far, our programs have been linear---they execute from top to bottom,
following the same path each time. While useful, these programs can't
adapt to different situations or respond differently based on varying
inputs. True programming power comes when your code can make decisions.

Decision-making transforms your programs from fixed sequences into
dynamic, responsive systems. It's the difference between:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  A calculator that only adds numbers vs.~one that chooses the right
  operation based on user input
\item
  A chatbot that says the same thing every time vs.~one that responds
  differently to different messages
\item
  A game that always follows the same pattern vs.~one that adapts to
  player actions
\end{itemize}

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Key Concept}: Conditional statements are the branching points in
your code---places where your program asks a question and chooses a path
based on the answer. Without conditionals, programs remain static and
inflexible.
\end{quote}

In everyday life, we constantly make decisions based on conditions: ``If
it's raining, I'll take an umbrella,'' or ``If the store is open, I'll
buy groceries; otherwise, I'll order delivery.'' Conditional statements
in programming work the same way, letting your programs adapt to
circumstances just as you do.

\hypertarget{the-if-statement-your-first-decision-point}{%
\section{\texorpdfstring{2. The \texttt{if} Statement: Your First
Decision
Point}{2. The if Statement: Your First Decision Point}}\label{the-if-statement-your-first-decision-point}}

The \texttt{if} statement is the fundamental building block of
decision-making in Python. It evaluates a condition and executes a block
of code only when that condition is \texttt{True}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ condition:}
    \CommentTok{\# This code runs only if the condition is True}
\NormalTok{    statement1}
\NormalTok{    statement2}
    \CommentTok{\# and so on...}

\CommentTok{\# This code always runs, regardless of the condition}
\NormalTok{outside\_statement}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Let's break down the key components:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{if}}: The keyword that signals a decision point
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{condition}}: An expression that evaluates to either
  \texttt{True} or \texttt{False}
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{:}}: The colon marks the end of the condition and the
  start of the conditional block
\item
  \textbf{Indented block}: All indented statements form the ``body'' of
  the \texttt{if} statement and execute only when the condition is
  \texttt{True}
\end{itemize}

Here's a concrete example:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{temperature }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{32}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s hot today!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Remember to stay hydrated."}\NormalTok{)}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enjoy your day!"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# This always executes}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When \texttt{temperature} is 32, both statements in the \texttt{if}
block will run because the condition
\texttt{temperature\ \textgreater{}\ 30} evaluates to \texttt{True}.
However, if \texttt{temperature} were 25, those statements would be
skipped, and only ``Enjoy your day!'' would be displayed.

\hypertarget{indentation-matters}{%
\subsection{Indentation Matters}\label{indentation-matters}}

Unlike many programming languages that use braces \texttt{\{\}} or
keywords like \texttt{begin}/\texttt{end} to define blocks, Python uses
indentation. This makes the code cleaner but requires careful attention
to spacing:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s hot today!"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Indented (part of the if block)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enjoy your day!"}\NormalTok{)      }\CommentTok{\# Not indented (outside the if block)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The standard indentation is 4 spaces, though the exact number is less
important than consistency. Whatever indentation you choose, stick with
it throughout your code.

\hypertarget{building-effective-conditions}{%
\section{3. Building Effective
Conditions}\label{building-effective-conditions}}

A condition is any expression that evaluates to either \texttt{True} or
\texttt{False}, known as a ``boolean expression.'' You can create
conditions using:

\hypertarget{comparison-operators}{%
\subsection{Comparison Operators}\label{comparison-operators}}

These operators compare values and return a boolean result:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{25}

\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{18}    \CommentTok{\# Greater than: True if age is greater than 18}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{65}    \CommentTok{\# Less than: True if age is less than 65}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{21}   \CommentTok{\# Greater than or equal to: True if age is at least 21}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{30}   \CommentTok{\# Less than or equal to: True if age is at most 30}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{25}   \CommentTok{\# Equal to: True if age is exactly 25}
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{!=} \DecValTok{30}   \CommentTok{\# Not equal to: True if age is not 30}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{boolean-variables}{%
\subsection{Boolean Variables}\label{boolean-variables}}

Variables that directly store \texttt{True} or \texttt{False} values:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{is\_student }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}
\NormalTok{has\_membership }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{False}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ is\_student:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Student discount applied"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ has\_membership:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Consider upgrading to a membership"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{membership-tests}{%
\subsection{Membership Tests}\label{membership-tests}}

Check if a value exists within a sequence:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{fruits }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"apple"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"banana"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"cherry"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{choice }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"banana"}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ choice }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ fruits:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"We have }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{choice}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"orange"} \KeywordTok{not} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ fruits:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Sorry, we don\textquotesingle{}t have oranges"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{string-operations}{%
\subsection{String Operations}\label{string-operations}}

Check properties or contents of strings:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alice Johnson"}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ name.startswith(}\StringTok{"A"}\NormalTok{):}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Name starts with A"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"son"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ name:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Name contains \textquotesingle{}son\textquotesingle{}"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ name.isalpha():  }\CommentTok{\# Would be False because of the space}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Name contains only letters"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{function-results}{%
\subsection{Function Results}\label{function-results}}

Functions that return boolean values:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{email }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"user@example.com"}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ is\_valid\_email(email):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"@"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"."} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ is\_valid\_email(email):}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Email format looks valid"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{boolean-clarity}{%
\subsection{Boolean Clarity}\label{boolean-clarity}}

For complex conditions, storing the result in a descriptively named
boolean variable improves readability:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{25}
\NormalTok{income }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{45000}
\NormalTok{credit\_score }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{720}

\CommentTok{\# Hard to read directly in the if statement}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{21} \KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ income }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{40000} \KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ credit\_score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{700}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Loan approved"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Clearer with descriptive boolean variables}
\NormalTok{meets\_age\_requirement }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{21}
\NormalTok{meets\_income\_requirement }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ income }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{40000}
\NormalTok{meets\_credit\_requirement }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ credit\_score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{700}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ meets\_age\_requirement }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ meets\_income\_requirement }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ meets\_credit\_requirement:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Loan approved"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This approach makes your code self-documenting---the boolean variable
names explain what's being checked.

\hypertarget{adding-alternatives-with-else}{%
\section{\texorpdfstring{4. Adding Alternatives with
\texttt{else}}{4. Adding Alternatives with else}}\label{adding-alternatives-with-else}}

The \texttt{else} clause provides an alternative path when the condition
is \texttt{False}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{temperature }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{25}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s hot today!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Remember to stay hydrated."}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s not very hot today."}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Normal precautions are sufficient."}\NormalTok{)}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enjoy your day!"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# This always executes}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When the condition is \texttt{False} (as it is when \texttt{temperature}
is 25), the \texttt{else} block executes instead of the \texttt{if}
block. This creates a simple ``either-or'' decision structure.

The \texttt{else} clause is optional. Use it when you need to choose
between exactly two alternatives; omit it when you only need to execute
code conditionally without an alternative.

\hypertarget{multiple-choices-with-elif}{%
\section{\texorpdfstring{5. Multiple Choices with
\texttt{elif}}{5. Multiple Choices with elif}}\label{multiple-choices-with-elif}}

Real-world decisions often involve more than two options. The
\texttt{elif} (short for ``else if'') statement lets you check multiple
conditions in sequence:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{temperature }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{22}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s a hot day!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Remember to stay hydrated."}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{20}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s a pleasant day!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enjoy the nice weather."}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s a bit cool today."}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Consider wearing a light jacket."}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s cold today!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Don\textquotesingle{}t forget your coat."}\NormalTok{)}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Have a great day!"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# This always executes}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Python evaluates each condition in order: 1. First, it checks if
\texttt{temperature\ \textgreater{}\ 30} (False when temperature is 22)
2. Then, it checks if \texttt{temperature\ \textgreater{}\ 20} (True
when temperature is 22) 3. Since the second condition is True, it
executes that block and skips the rest

Only one block will execute, even if multiple conditions could be true.
The first true condition ``wins,'' and the rest are skipped.

\hypertarget{the-importance-of-order}{%
\subsection{The Importance of Order}\label{the-importance-of-order}}

The order of your \texttt{elif} statements matters. Consider this
example:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{score }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{85}

\CommentTok{\# Correct order (most specific to least specific)}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{90}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    grade }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"A"}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{80}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    grade }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"B"}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{70}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    grade }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"C"}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{60}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    grade }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"D"}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    grade }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"F"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If we reversed the order:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Incorrect order (least specific to most specific)}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{60}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    grade }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"D"}    \CommentTok{\# This would always trigger first for any passing score!}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{70}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    grade }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"C"}    \CommentTok{\# These would never be reached for passing scores}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{80}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    grade }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"B"}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{90}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    grade }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"A"}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    grade }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"F"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

With a score of 85, the first example correctly assigns grade ``B'', but
the second incorrectly assigns ``D'' because the first condition is
already true.

\begin{quote}
\textbf{Best Practice}: When conditions overlap, arrange them from most
specific/restrictive to most general.
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{combining-conditions-with-logical-operators}{%
\section{6. Combining Conditions with Logical
Operators}\label{combining-conditions-with-logical-operators}}

To create more sophisticated conditions, you can combine simpler ones
using logical operators:

\hypertarget{the-and-operator}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{The \texttt{and}
Operator}{The and Operator}}\label{the-and-operator}}

True only if both conditions are true:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{25}
\NormalTok{income }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{50000}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{21} \KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ income }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{40000}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Eligible for premium credit card"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{the-or-operator}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{The \texttt{or}
Operator}{The or Operator}}\label{the-or-operator}}

True if at least one condition is true:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{is\_holiday }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}
\NormalTok{is\_weekend }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{False}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ is\_holiday }\KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ is\_weekend:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"The office is closed"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{the-not-operator}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{The \texttt{not}
Operator}{The not Operator}}\label{the-not-operator}}

Inverts a boolean value:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{is\_working\_day }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}

\ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ is\_working\_day:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You can sleep in today"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Time to go to work"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{complex-combinations}{%
\subsection{Complex Combinations}\label{complex-combinations}}

You can create complex conditions by combining these operators:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{65}
\NormalTok{income }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{30000}
\NormalTok{is\_student }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{False}
\NormalTok{has\_disability }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}

\CommentTok{\# Eligible if:}
\CommentTok{\# {-} Senior (65+) or student or has disability}
\CommentTok{\# {-} AND income under 35000}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ (age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{65} \KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ is\_student }\KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ has\_disability) }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ income }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{35000}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Eligible for financial assistance"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Use parentheses to make the precedence clear, even if not strictly
necessary for the logic.

\hypertarget{nested-conditionals-decisions-within-decisions}{%
\section{7. Nested Conditionals: Decisions Within
Decisions}\label{nested-conditionals-decisions-within-decisions}}

Sometimes, you need to make a decision based on the outcome of another
decision. This creates a nested conditional structure:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{has\_ticket }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{True}
\NormalTok{has\_id }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{False}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ has\_ticket:}
    \CommentTok{\# This entire block only runs if has\_ticket is True}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Ticket verified."}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ has\_id:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"ID verified. Welcome to the event!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Sorry, you need ID to enter. Please return with ID."}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You need a ticket to enter. Please purchase one first."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

While nesting can express complex logic, deep nesting (more than 2-3
levels) can make code hard to follow. Often, you can flatten nested
conditions using logical operators:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Instead of nesting:}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ has\_ticket:}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ has\_id:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Welcome to the event!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"ID required"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Ticket required"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# You can use logical operators:}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ has\_ticket }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ has\_id:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Welcome to the event!"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ has\_ticket:  }\CommentTok{\# At this point, we know has\_id is False}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"ID required"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Ticket required"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The flattened version is often easier to read and maintain.

\hypertarget{common-patterns-in-decision-making}{%
\section{8. Common Patterns in Decision
Making}\label{common-patterns-in-decision-making}}

Here are some common decision-making patterns you'll use frequently:

\hypertarget{input-validation}{%
\subsection{Input Validation}\label{input-validation}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{user\_age }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter your age: "}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_age.isdigit():}
\NormalTok{    age }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(user\_age)}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{18}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Access granted"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Sorry, you must be 18 or older"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Please enter a valid number"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{mutually-exclusive-categories}{%
\subsection{Mutually Exclusive
Categories}\label{mutually-exclusive-categories}}

When options are mutually exclusive (only one can be true):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{color }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"red"}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ color }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"red"}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Stop"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ color }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"yellow"}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Caution"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ color }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"green"}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Go"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Unknown signal"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{independent-checks}{%
\subsection{Independent Checks}\label{independent-checks}}

When you need to perform multiple independent checks:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Each check is independent {-} multiple messages can print}
\NormalTok{temperature }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{35}
\NormalTok{humidity }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{80}
\NormalTok{air\_quality }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Poor"}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Heat advisory in effect"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ humidity }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{70}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"High humidity warning"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ air\_quality }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"Poor"}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Air quality alert"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{early-returns-and-guards}{%
\subsection{Early Returns and Guards}\label{early-returns-and-guards}}

In functions, using conditionals to ``guard'' against invalid cases:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ divide(a, b):}
    \CommentTok{\# Guard against division by zero}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ b }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Error: Cannot divide by zero"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{None}  \CommentTok{\# Early return}

    \CommentTok{\# Only reached if b is not zero}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ b}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{state-machines}{%
\subsection{State Machines}\label{state-machines}}

Using conditionals to model different states:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{status }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"pending"}
\NormalTok{days\_active }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ status }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"pending"}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Order is awaiting processing"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ status }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"processing"}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Order is being prepared"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ status }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"shipped"}\NormalTok{:}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ days\_active }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Order recently shipped"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Order in transit"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ status }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"delivered"}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Order has been delivered"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Unknown order status"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{project-corner-making-your-chatbot-intelligent}{%
\section{9. Project Corner: Making Your Chatbot
Intelligent}\label{project-corner-making-your-chatbot-intelligent}}

Now let's apply what we've learned to enhance our chatbot with
conditional logic, giving it the ability to respond intelligently to
different inputs.

\hypertarget{basic-decision-tree-chatbot}{%
\subsection{Basic Decision Tree
Chatbot}\label{basic-decision-tree-chatbot}}

Let's start with a simple decision tree based on keywords:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input, user\_name):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Generate a response based on user input.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        user\_input (str): The user\textquotesingle{}s message}
\CommentTok{        user\_name (str): The user\textquotesingle{}s name}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        str: The chatbot\textquotesingle{}s response}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \CommentTok{\# Convert to lowercase for easier matching}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower()}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for special commands}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"""}
\SpecialStringTok{Hi }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! I can respond to various topics:}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Greetings (hello, hi)}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Questions about myself}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Questions about Python}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Expressions of mood (happy, sad)}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Weather inquiries}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Farewells (bye, goodbye)}

\SpecialStringTok{Just type naturally and I\textquotesingle{}ll try to understand!}
\SpecialStringTok{"""}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for greetings}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"hello"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"hi"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"hey"}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Hello }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! How can I help you today?"}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for questions about the bot}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"your name"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"My name is PyBot. I\textquotesingle{}m a chatbot built as part of your Python learning journey!"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"who are you"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"what are you"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m PyBot, a simple chatbot designed to demonstrate Python conditional statements."}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for Python questions}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"python"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"?"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Python is a versatile programming language known for its readability and ease of use. What specific aspect would you like to know about?"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"function"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"python"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Functions in Python are defined using the \textquotesingle{}def\textquotesingle{} keyword. They help organize and reuse code."}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"conditional"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"if statement"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Conditional statements in Python, like \textquotesingle{}if\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}elif\textquotesingle{}, and \textquotesingle{}else\textquotesingle{}, let your programs make decisions based on conditions."}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for mood expressions}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"happy"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"glad"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"good"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"I\textquotesingle{}m glad you\textquotesingle{}re feeling positive, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! What\textquotesingle{}s made your day good?"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"sad"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"bad"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"terrible"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"I\textquotesingle{}m sorry to hear that, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. Remember that tough times don\textquotesingle{}t last forever."}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for weather inquiries}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"weather"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"hot"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"In hot weather, staying hydrated is important. Drink plenty of water!"}
        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"cold"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"cool"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Cold weather can be invigorating! A hot beverage might be nice."}
        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"rain"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Rainy days are perfect for indoor activities. Maybe some Python practice?"}
        \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Weather affects our daily lives significantly. How\textquotesingle{}s the weather affecting your plans?"}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for farewells}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"bye"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"goodbye"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! It was nice chatting with you. Come back soon!"}

    \CommentTok{\# Default response for unrecognized input}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"That\textquotesingle{}s interesting, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. Tell me more, or type \textquotesingle{}help\textquotesingle{} to see what I can discuss."}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ run\_chatbot():}
    \CommentTok{"""Run the main chatbot interaction loop."""}
\NormalTok{    bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}

    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, your Python learning assistant."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{).strip()}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! Type \textquotesingle{}help\textquotesingle{} for options or \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to exit."}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{).strip()}

        \CommentTok{\# Exit condition}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! Have a great day!"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{break}

        \CommentTok{\# Get and display response}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input, user\_name)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Run the chatbot if this file is executed directly}
\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"\_\_main\_\_"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    run\_chatbot()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This basic chatbot demonstrates several conditional concepts: - Using
\texttt{if}/\texttt{elif}/\texttt{else} for different categories of
input - Nested conditions for subcategories (like weather types) -
Keyword detection with the \texttt{in} operator - Combining conditions
with \texttt{or} for similar triggers

\hypertarget{advanced-context-aware-chatbot}{%
\subsection{Advanced Context-Aware
Chatbot}\label{advanced-context-aware-chatbot}}

Let's enhance our chatbot to remember context and respond more
intelligently:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ context\_aware\_chatbot():}
    \CommentTok{"""A more sophisticated chatbot that maintains conversation context."""}
\NormalTok{    bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}

    \CommentTok{\# Initialize conversation state}
\NormalTok{    context }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
        \StringTok{"user\_name"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{""}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"topics\_discussed"}\NormalTok{: }\BuiltInTok{set}\NormalTok{(),}
        \StringTok{"question\_count"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"mood"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"neutral"}\NormalTok{,  }\CommentTok{\# bot\textquotesingle{}s mood: can be "happy", "neutral", or "tired"}
        \StringTok{"last\_topic"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{None}
\NormalTok{    \}}

    \CommentTok{\# Helper function to update context}
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ update\_context(user\_input):}
        \CommentTok{\# Track topics}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"python"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower():}
\NormalTok{            context[}\StringTok{"topics\_discussed"}\NormalTok{].add(}\StringTok{"python"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"weather"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower():}
\NormalTok{            context[}\StringTok{"topics\_discussed"}\NormalTok{].add(}\StringTok{"weather"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"music"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower():}
\NormalTok{            context[}\StringTok{"topics\_discussed"}\NormalTok{].add(}\StringTok{"music"}\NormalTok{)}

        \CommentTok{\# Track questions}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"?"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
\NormalTok{            context[}\StringTok{"question\_count"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}

        \CommentTok{\# Update mood (bot gets "tired" after many questions)}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"question\_count"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            context[}\StringTok{"mood"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"tired"}

        \CommentTok{\# Track last topic mentioned}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ topic }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"python"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"weather"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"music"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"movies"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"books"}\NormalTok{]:}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ topic }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower():}
\NormalTok{                context[}\StringTok{"last\_topic"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ topic}
                \ControlFlowTok{break}

    \CommentTok{\# Main response function}
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_contextual\_response(user\_input):}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower()}
\NormalTok{        update\_context(user\_input)}

        \CommentTok{\# Special case for greeting {-} depends on bot\textquotesingle{}s mood}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"hello"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"hi"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"mood"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"happy"}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Hello }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{context[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}user\_name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! It\textquotesingle{}s wonderful to see you! How can I help you today?"}
            \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"mood"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"tired"}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Hi }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{context[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}user\_name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{... You\textquotesingle{}ve asked quite a few questions. I\textquotesingle{}ll try to keep up!"}
            \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Hello }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{context[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}user\_name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! How can I help you today?"}

        \CommentTok{\# Check for questions about previous topics}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"tell me more"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"last\_topic"}\NormalTok{]:}
\NormalTok{            topic }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"last\_topic"}\NormalTok{]}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ topic }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"python"}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Python is a versatile language used for web development, data analysis, AI, and more. What specific aspect interests you?"}
            \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ topic }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"weather"}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Weather is the state of the atmosphere, including temperature, humidity, wind, etc. Any specific weather phenomenon you\textquotesingle{}re curious about?"}
            \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ topic }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"music"}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Music comes in countless genres from classical to electronic. Do you have a favorite style?"}
            \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"You wanted to know more about }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{topic}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{? What specific aspect interests you?"}

        \CommentTok{\# Check for topic switching}
\NormalTok{        prev\_topics }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"topics\_discussed"}\NormalTok{].copy()}
\NormalTok{        update\_context(user\_input)  }\CommentTok{\# This adds any new topics}
\NormalTok{        new\_topics }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"topics\_discussed"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ prev\_topics}

        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ new\_topics }\KeywordTok{and} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(prev\_topics) }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            new\_topic }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{list}\NormalTok{(new\_topics)[}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{]}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"I see we\textquotesingle{}re now talking about }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{new\_topic}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. That\textquotesingle{}s an interesting switch from our previous topics!"}

        \CommentTok{\# Check for Python questions with contextual awareness}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"python"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"topics\_discussed"}\NormalTok{]:}
            \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"weather"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"topics\_discussed"}\NormalTok{]:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Python can be used for weather data analysis and forecasting! Libraries like MetPy are specifically designed for meteorological calculations."}
            \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"music"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"topics\_discussed"}\NormalTok{]:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Python has libraries like librosa for music analysis and pygame for playing sounds. You can even create music with Python!"}

        \CommentTok{\# Question counter responses}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"?"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"question\_count"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"That\textquotesingle{}s a good first question! I\textquotesingle{}m here to help with more."}
            \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"question\_count"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{                context[}\StringTok{"mood"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"tired"}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"You ask a lot of questions! That\textquotesingle{}s good for learning, but I\textquotesingle{}m getting a bit tired."}
            \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"question\_count"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{8}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Wow, you\textquotesingle{}re very curious today! So many questions!"}

        \CommentTok{\# If no contextual response matched, fall back to basic responses}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"python"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Python is a powerful programming language. Is there something specific about Python you\textquotesingle{}d like to know?"}
        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"weather"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Weather is always an interesting topic. Are you experiencing good weather today?"}
        \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"bye"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"goodbye"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
\NormalTok{            topics }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(context[}\StringTok{"topics\_discussed"}\NormalTok{])}
\NormalTok{            questions }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ context[}\StringTok{"question\_count"}\NormalTok{]}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{context[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}user\_name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! We discussed }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{topics}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ topics and you asked }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{questions}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ questions. Come back soon!"}
        \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m listening. Feel free to ask about Python, share your thoughts, or discuss other topics like weather or music."}

    \CommentTok{\# Welcome and get user\textquotesingle{}s name}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, a context{-}aware chatbot."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    context[}\StringTok{"user\_name"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{).strip()}
\NormalTok{    context[}\StringTok{"mood"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"happy"}  \CommentTok{\# Start in a happy mood}

    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{context[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}user\_name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! Let\textquotesingle{}s chat about Python, weather, music, or anything else on your mind. Type \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to end our conversation."}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Main conversation loop}
    \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{context[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}user\_name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{).strip()}

        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{get\_contextual\_response(user\_input)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{break}

\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_contextual\_response(user\_input)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Run the context{-}aware chatbot}
\CommentTok{\# context\_aware\_chatbot()  \# Uncomment to run}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This advanced chatbot demonstrates: - Maintaining state with a context
dictionary - Making decisions based on conversation history - Using
nested conditionals for complex logic - Adapting responses based on
multiple factors - Tracking and counting specific events (questions)

Have a nice day."}\NormalTok{)}
