\hypertarget{ai-collaboration-corner-crafting-effective-conditionals}{%
\section{10. AI Collaboration Corner: Crafting Effective
Conditionals}\label{ai-collaboration-corner-crafting-effective-conditionals}}

Let's explore how AI assistants can help you design better conditional
logic in your Python programs.

\hypertarget{before-vague-prompting-4}{%
\subsection{Before: Vague Prompting}\label{before-vague-prompting-4}}

\begin{verbatim}
Help me with Python if statements.
\end{verbatim}

\textbf{AI Response:} \emph{Python if statements let you execute code
conditionally. The basic syntax is:}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ condition:}
    \CommentTok{\# code to run if condition is True}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ other\_condition:}
    \CommentTok{\# code to run if other\_condition is True}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \CommentTok{\# code to run if all conditions are False}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\emph{You can use comparison operators like \texttt{==}, \texttt{!=},
\texttt{\textgreater{}}, \texttt{\textless{}}, \texttt{\textgreater{}=},
and \texttt{\textless{}=} to create conditions. Logical operators
\texttt{and}, \texttt{or}, and \texttt{not} can combine multiple
conditions.}

This response provides basic information but doesn't address specific
design challenges or best practices.

\hypertarget{after-detailed-specific-prompting-4}{%
\subsection{After: Detailed, Specific
Prompting}\label{after-detailed-specific-prompting-4}}

\begin{verbatim}
I'm building a user registration system in Python that needs to validate form
submissions. I need to create conditional logic that:

1. Validates username (3-15 chars, letters/numbers only), password (8+ chars,
   must include a number), and email (must have @ and .)
2. Provides specific error messages for each type of validation failure
3. Handles special cases like admin users with different validation rules
4. Has clean, readable code that avoids deeply nested conditionals

Please show me well-structured code with effective conditional logic and explain
the design principles you're using.
\end{verbatim}

\textbf{AI Response:} \emph{Here's a well-structured approach to
validation with effective conditional logic:}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ validate\_registration(username, password, email, is\_admin}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{    Validate user registration data and return results.}

\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        username (str): Desired username}
\CommentTok{        password (str): Desired password}
\CommentTok{        email (str): User\textquotesingle{}s email address}
\CommentTok{        is\_admin (bool): Whether this is an admin account}

\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        tuple: (is\_valid, error\_message)}
\CommentTok{            is\_valid (bool): True if all validations pass}
\CommentTok{            error\_message (str): Description of the first validation error, or None if valid}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \CommentTok{\# Validate username (3{-}15 chars, letters/numbers only)}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not} \DecValTok{3} \OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(username) }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{15}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Username must be between 3 and 15 characters"}

    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ username.isalnum():}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Username must contain only letters and numbers"}

    \CommentTok{\# Validate password with different rules for admin/regular users}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ is\_admin:}
        \CommentTok{\# Stricter admin password requirements}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(password) }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{12}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Admin passwords must be at least 12 characters"}

        \CommentTok{\# Check for complexity requirements}
\NormalTok{        has\_upper }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{any}\NormalTok{(c.isupper() }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ c }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ password)}
\NormalTok{        has\_lower }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{any}\NormalTok{(c.islower() }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ c }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ password)}
\NormalTok{        has\_digit }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{any}\NormalTok{(c.isdigit() }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ c }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ password)}
\NormalTok{        has\_special }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{any}\NormalTok{(}\KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ c.isalnum() }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ c }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ password)}

        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ (has\_upper }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ has\_lower }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ has\_digit }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ has\_special):}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Admin passwords must include uppercase, lowercase, digits, and special characters"}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Regular user password requirements}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(password) }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{8}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Password must be at least 8 characters"}

        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not} \BuiltInTok{any}\NormalTok{(c.isdigit() }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ c }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ password):}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Password must include at least one number"}

    \CommentTok{\# Validate email (must have @ and .)}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}@\textquotesingle{}} \KeywordTok{not} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Email must contain @"}

    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}.\textquotesingle{}} \KeywordTok{not} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email.split(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}@\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{]:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Email must contain a valid domain with a dot"}

    \CommentTok{\# If we\textquotesingle{}ve reached this point, all validations have passed}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{, }\VariableTok{None}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ register\_user(username, password, email, is\_admin}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{"""Process user registration with appropriate feedback."""}
    \CommentTok{\# First step: validate the input}
\NormalTok{    is\_valid, error\_message }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ validate\_registration(username, password, email, is\_admin)}

    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ is\_valid:}
        \CommentTok{\# Early return pattern {-} handle the error case first}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Registration failed: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{error\_message}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}

    \CommentTok{\# If we get here, validation passed {-} continue with registration}
\NormalTok{    user\_type }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"admin"} \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ is\_admin }\ControlFlowTok{else} \StringTok{"regular"}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Successfully registered }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_type}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ user \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{username}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}"}\NormalTok{)}
    \CommentTok{\# In a real system, you would save the user to a database here}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}

\CommentTok{\# Example usage}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_registration():}
    \CommentTok{\# Test valid regular user}
\NormalTok{    register\_user(}\StringTok{"alice123"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"pass1234"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"alice@example.com"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Test invalid username}
\NormalTok{    register\_user(}\StringTok{"a"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"pass1234"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"short@example.com"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Test invalid password}
\NormalTok{    register\_user(}\StringTok{"bob123"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"password"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"bob@example.com"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Test invalid email}
\NormalTok{    register\_user(}\StringTok{"charlie"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"pass1234"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"not{-}an{-}email"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Test valid admin}
\NormalTok{    register\_user(}\StringTok{"adminuser"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Admin@1234567"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"admin@company.com"}\NormalTok{, is\_admin}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Test invalid admin (password not complex enough)}
\NormalTok{    register\_user(}\StringTok{"adminuser2"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"simple123"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"admin2@company.com"}\NormalTok{, is\_admin}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\emph{This code demonstrates several principles for effective
conditional logic:}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \emph{Early returns for validation:}

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{Each validation check immediately returns when it fails}
  \item
    \emph{This avoids deeply nested conditionals (``arrow code'')}
  \item
    \emph{The error message clearly indicates which specific validation
    failed}
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \emph{Separation of concerns:}

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{Validation logic is separated from registration processing}
  \item
    \emph{The \texttt{validate\_registration} function has a single
    responsibility}
  \item
    \emph{The main \texttt{register\_user} function uses the ``fail
    fast'' pattern}
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \emph{Conditional branching strategies:}

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{Special cases (admin vs.~regular user) are handled with an
    initial branch}
  \item
    \emph{Complex conditions use intermediate boolean variables for
    readability}
  \item
    \emph{Related conditions are grouped together logically}
  \end{itemize}
\item
  \emph{Design patterns for validation:}

  \begin{itemize}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \emph{Return both success status and error message}
  \item
    \emph{Specific, actionable error messages}
  \item
    \emph{Default parameter for optional conditions
    (\texttt{is\_admin=False})}
  \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

\emph{These approaches create conditionals that are easy to read,
maintain, and extend. The validation can be expanded with additional
rules without making the code more complex, and the error handling
provides clear guidance to users.}

\hypertarget{how-to-craft-effective-prompts-for-conditional-logic}{%
\subsection{How to Craft Effective Prompts for Conditional
Logic}\label{how-to-craft-effective-prompts-for-conditional-logic}}

When working with an AI assistant on conditional logic:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  \textbf{Describe the decision-making scenario} in detail (user
  validation, game logic, data processing, etc.)
\item
  \textbf{Specify all the conditions} that need to be evaluated
\item
  \textbf{Ask for specific design patterns} that help manage complexity
\item
  \textbf{Mention your concerns} about readability, maintainability, or
  edge cases
\item
  \textbf{Request examples of alternative approaches} if you're
  considering different designs
\end{enumerate}

For example:

\begin{verbatim}
I'm writing a discount calculator for an e-commerce site. The rules are:
- 10% off orders over $100
- 15% off orders over $200
- Additional 5% for loyalty members
- Extra 3% on weekends
- Maximum discount of 25%

I want to avoid deeply nested if statements. Can you show me 2-3 different
approaches to implement this logic with pros and cons of each design?
\end{verbatim}

This specific prompt will yield practical approaches to a real-world
conditional logic problem, with a discussion of tradeoffs between
different designs.

\hypertarget{using-ai-to-debug-conditional-logic-issues}{%
\subsection{Using AI to Debug Conditional Logic
Issues}\label{using-ai-to-debug-conditional-logic-issues}}

Conditional logic can be tricky to get right. Here's how to use AI
effectively when debugging:

\begin{verbatim}
My Python code isn't working as expected. I have this function to determine
if a user qualifies for free shipping:

def qualifies_for_free_shipping(cart_total, is_member, item_count):
    if cart_total > 50 or is_member and item_count > 1:
        return True
    else:
        return False

It should give free shipping when:
- Cart total exceeds $50, OR
- The user is a member AND has more than 1 item

But members with exactly 1 item are getting free shipping. What's wrong with my logic?
\end{verbatim}

\textbf{AI Response:} \emph{I see the issue in your conditional logic.
There's an operator precedence problem. The current code is being
interpreted as:}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ (cart\_total }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{) }\KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ (is\_member }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ item\_count }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{):}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\emph{But based on your description, you want:}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ (cart\_total }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{) }\KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ (is\_member }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ item\_count }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{):}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\emph{Wait - those look the same, so that's not the issue. Let me check
again\ldots{}}

\emph{Actually, your code logic matches your description correctly. If a
user is a member AND has more than 1 item, they get free shipping. Or if
cart total \textgreater{} \$50, they get free shipping regardless of
membership or item count.}

\emph{The problem must be elsewhere. Let's double-check with some test
cases:}

\emph{Case 1: cart\_total = 40, is\_member = True, item\_count = 1} -
\emph{cart\_total \textgreater{} 50 is False} - \emph{is\_member is
True} - \emph{item\_count \textgreater{} 1 is False} - \emph{So: False
or (True and False) → False or False → False} - \emph{This user should
NOT get free shipping}

\emph{If members with exactly 1 item are getting free shipping, possible
causes include:} 1. \emph{The \texttt{is\_member} value might not be
what you expect (check its type and value)} 2. \emph{The
\texttt{item\_count} might not be what you expect (make sure it's
actually 1, not 2)} 3. \emph{There might be another part of your code
that's overriding this function's result}

\emph{I recommend adding debug statements to verify the values:}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ qualifies\_for\_free\_shipping(cart\_total, is\_member, item\_count):}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Debug {-} cart\_total: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{cart\_total}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, is\_member: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{is\_member}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, item\_count: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{item\_count}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    qualifies }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ cart\_total }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{50} \KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ (is\_member }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ item\_count }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Debug {-} qualifies: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{qualifies}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ qualifies}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\emph{This will help you confirm what's actually happening when the
function runs.}

\hypertarget{creating-complex-decision-trees-with-ai-assistance}{%
\subsection{Creating Complex Decision Trees with AI
Assistance}\label{creating-complex-decision-trees-with-ai-assistance}}

For more complex conditional structures, AI can help design decision
trees:

\begin{verbatim}
I need to create a loan approval system with these conditions:
- Credit score must be 650+ for any loan
- For loans under $10,000: require 1+ year employment
- For loans $10,000-$50,000: require 2+ years employment and debt-to-income < 40%
- For loans over $50,000: require 3+ years employment, debt-to-income < 35%,
  and either a cosigner OR collateral worth at least 30% of loan value

Can you design a function with clean conditional logic for this system, with
detailed rejection reasons?
\end{verbatim}

This specific prompt will yield a comprehensive solution for a complex
decision tree, with clean, maintainable code.

By providing specific context and requirements when asking for help with
conditionals, you can get much more useful and practical assistance from
AI tools.

\hypertarget{common-conditional-logic-pitfalls-to-avoid}{%
\section{11. Common Conditional Logic Pitfalls to
Avoid}\label{common-conditional-logic-pitfalls-to-avoid}}

As you work with conditional statements, watch for these common issues:

\hypertarget{using-assignment-instead-of-equality}{%
\subsection{Using Assignment (=) Instead of Equality
(==)}\label{using-assignment-instead-of-equality}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# INCORRECT {-} accidentally assigns value instead of comparing}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{18}\NormalTok{:  }\CommentTok{\# This is a syntax error in Python}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You\textquotesingle{}re 18!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# CORRECT {-} compares values}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{18}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You\textquotesingle{}re 18!"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Python's syntax prevents this common error, but it's a frequent mistake
in many languages.

\hypertarget{missing-the-colon}{%
\subsection{Missing the Colon}\label{missing-the-colon}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# INCORRECT {-} missing colon}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{18}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You are an adult."}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# CORRECT}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{18}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You are an adult."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{inconsistent-indentation}{%
\subsection{Inconsistent Indentation}\label{inconsistent-indentation}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# INCORRECT {-} inconsistent indentation}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s hot!"}\NormalTok{)}
  \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Drink water."}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# IndentationError}

\CommentTok{\# CORRECT {-} consistent indentation}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"It\textquotesingle{}s hot!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Drink water."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{confusing-andor-logic}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{Confusing \texttt{and}/\texttt{or}
Logic}{Confusing and/or Logic}}\label{confusing-andor-logic}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# INCORRECT {-} inverted logic}
\CommentTok{\# Meant: "If age is at least 18 AND no more than 65"}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{18} \KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{65}\NormalTok{:  }\CommentTok{\# Always True for any age!}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Working age"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# CORRECT}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{18} \KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{65}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Working age"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# ALTERNATIVE (cleaner)}
\ControlFlowTok{if} \DecValTok{18} \OperatorTok{\textless{}=}\NormalTok{ age }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{65}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Working age"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{forgetting-that-else-belongs-to-the-closest-if}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{Forgetting That \texttt{else} Belongs to the
Closest
\texttt{if}}{Forgetting That else Belongs to the Closest if}}\label{forgetting-that-else-belongs-to-the-closest-if}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# MISLEADING {-} the else belongs to the inner if, not the outer one}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ humidity }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{70}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hot and humid"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:  }\CommentTok{\# This else belongs to the humidity check, not the temperature check!}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Not hot and humid"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# CLEARER {-} with proper indentation showing structure}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ temperature }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ humidity }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{70}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hot and humid"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:  }\CommentTok{\# Clearly belongs to the humidity check}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hot but not humid"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:  }\CommentTok{\# Clearly belongs to the temperature check}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Not hot"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{redundant-conditions}{%
\subsection{Redundant Conditions}\label{redundant-conditions}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# REDUNDANT {-} unnecessarily verbose}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ is\_valid }\OperatorTok{==} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Valid"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ has\_permission }\OperatorTok{==} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Access denied"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# CLEANER}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ is\_valid:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Valid"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ has\_permission:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Access denied"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{arrow-code-deeply-nested-conditionals}{%
\subsection{``Arrow Code'' (Deeply Nested
Conditionals)}\label{arrow-code-deeply-nested-conditionals}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# PROBLEMATIC {-} deeply nested "arrow code"}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_order(order):}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ order.is\_valid:}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ order.is\_paid:}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ order.has\_inventory:}
                \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ order.is\_shipped:}
                    \CommentTok{\# Ship the order}
\NormalTok{                    order.ship()}
                    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Shipped"}
                \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
                    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Already shipped"}
            \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"No inventory"}
        \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Not paid"}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Invalid order"}

\CommentTok{\# BETTER {-} early returns}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_order(order):}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ order.is\_valid:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Invalid order"}

    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ order.is\_paid:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Not paid"}

    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ order.has\_inventory:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"No inventory"}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ order.is\_shipped:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Already shipped"}

    \CommentTok{\# If we get here, all conditions are met}
\NormalTok{    order.ship()}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Shipped"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{forgetting-that-multiple-elif-conditions-are-exclusive}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{Forgetting That Multiple \texttt{elif}
Conditions Are
Exclusive}{Forgetting That Multiple elif Conditions Are Exclusive}}\label{forgetting-that-multiple-elif-conditions-are-exclusive}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# MISLEADING {-} only one block will execute, even if multiple conditions are true}
\NormalTok{score }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{95}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{60}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You passed"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# This will print}
\ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{90}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You got an A"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# This won\textquotesingle{}t print, even though it\textquotesingle{}s true}

\CommentTok{\# CORRECT {-} separate independent conditions}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{60}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You passed"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{90}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You got an A"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{real-world-conditional-logic-examples}{%
\section{12. Real-World Conditional Logic
Examples}\label{real-world-conditional-logic-examples}}

Let's examine how conditionals are used in professional applications:

\hypertarget{form-validation}{%
\subsection{Form Validation}\label{form-validation}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ validate\_form\_submission(form\_data):}
    \CommentTok{"""Validate a form submission with multiple fields."""}
\NormalTok{    errors }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{\}}

    \CommentTok{\# Required fields check}
\NormalTok{    required\_fields }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"name"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"email"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"phone"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"message"}\NormalTok{]}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ field }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ required\_fields:}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ field }\KeywordTok{not} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ form\_data }\KeywordTok{or} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ form\_data[field].strip():}
\NormalTok{            errors[field] }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{field}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{capitalize()}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ is required"}

    \CommentTok{\# If any required fields are missing, return early}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ errors:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, errors}

    \CommentTok{\# Email validation}
\NormalTok{    email }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ form\_data[}\StringTok{"email"}\NormalTok{]}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"@"} \KeywordTok{not} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email }\KeywordTok{or} \StringTok{"."} \KeywordTok{not} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ email.split(}\StringTok{"@"}\NormalTok{)[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{]:}
\NormalTok{        errors[}\StringTok{"email"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Please enter a valid email address"}

    \CommentTok{\# Phone validation (simple check for demonstration)}
\NormalTok{    phone }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ form\_data[}\StringTok{"phone"}\NormalTok{]}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ (phone.isdigit() }\KeywordTok{and} \DecValTok{10} \OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(phone) }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{15}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{        errors[}\StringTok{"phone"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Please enter a valid phone number"}

    \CommentTok{\# Message length validation}
\NormalTok{    message }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ form\_data[}\StringTok{"message"}\NormalTok{]}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(message) }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        errors[}\StringTok{"message"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Message must be at least 10 characters"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(message) }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{1000}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        errors[}\StringTok{"message"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Message cannot exceed 1000 characters"}

    \CommentTok{\# Return validation result}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ errors:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, errors}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{, }\VariableTok{None}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{e-commerce-discount-calculation}{%
\subsection{E-commerce Discount
Calculation}\label{e-commerce-discount-calculation}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_discount(order\_total, user, day\_of\_week):}
    \CommentTok{"""Calculate discount based on multiple conditions."""}
    \CommentTok{\# Initialize discount}
\NormalTok{    discount\_percentage }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}

    \CommentTok{\# Base discount based on order total}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ order\_total }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{200}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        discount\_percentage }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{15}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ order\_total }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        discount\_percentage }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ order\_total }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}=} \DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        discount\_percentage }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5}

    \CommentTok{\# Member discount}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user.is\_premium\_member:}
\NormalTok{        discount\_percentage }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{5}

    \CommentTok{\# Weekend discount}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ day\_of\_week }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"Saturday"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Sunday"}\NormalTok{]:}
\NormalTok{        discount\_percentage }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{3}

    \CommentTok{\# Seasonal promotion}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user.last\_purchase\_days }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Incentive for customers who haven\textquotesingle{}t purchased recently}
\NormalTok{        discount\_percentage }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{2}

    \CommentTok{\# Limit maximum discount}
\NormalTok{    discount\_percentage }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{min}\NormalTok{(discount\_percentage, }\DecValTok{25}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Calculate final discount amount}
\NormalTok{    discount\_amount }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ order\_total }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ (discount\_percentage }\OperatorTok{/} \DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ \{}
        \StringTok{"original\_total"}\NormalTok{: order\_total,}
        \StringTok{"discount\_percentage"}\NormalTok{: discount\_percentage,}
        \StringTok{"discount\_amount"}\NormalTok{: discount\_amount,}
        \StringTok{"final\_total"}\NormalTok{: order\_total }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ discount\_amount}
\NormalTok{    \}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{game-character-status}{%
\subsection{Game Character Status}\label{game-character-status}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ update\_character\_status(character):}
    \CommentTok{"""Update a game character\textquotesingle{}s status based on their attributes."""}
    \CommentTok{\# Reset temporary status effects}
\NormalTok{    character.status\_effects }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}

    \CommentTok{\# Health{-}based status}
\NormalTok{    health\_percentage }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ character.current\_health }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ character.max\_health }\OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{100}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ health\_percentage }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        character.status\_effects.append(}\StringTok{"Critical"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        character.movement\_speed }\OperatorTok{*=} \FloatTok{0.5}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ health\_percentage }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        character.status\_effects.append(}\StringTok{"Wounded"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        character.movement\_speed }\OperatorTok{*=} \FloatTok{0.8}

    \CommentTok{\# Environment effects}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ character.current\_biome }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"Desert"}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ character.has\_item(}\StringTok{"Water Flask"}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{            character.status\_effects.append(}\StringTok{"Dehydrated"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{            character.stamina\_regen }\OperatorTok{*=} \FloatTok{0.7}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ character.current\_biome }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"Tundra"}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ character.has\_item(}\StringTok{"Warm Clothing"}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{            character.status\_effects.append(}\StringTok{"Freezing"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{            character.attack\_speed }\OperatorTok{*=} \FloatTok{0.8}

    \CommentTok{\# Special ability conditions}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ character.class\_type }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"Berserker"} \KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ health\_percentage }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        character.status\_effects.append(}\StringTok{"Rage"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        character.attack\_damage }\OperatorTok{*=} \FloatTok{1.5}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for conflicting status effects}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"Stunned"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ character.status\_effects }\KeywordTok{and} \StringTok{"Rage"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ character.status\_effects:}
        \CommentTok{\# Rage overcomes stun}
\NormalTok{        character.status\_effects.remove(}\StringTok{"Stunned"}\NormalTok{)}

    \CommentTok{\# Update character\textquotesingle{}s visual appearance based on status}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ character.status\_effects:}
\NormalTok{        character.update\_visual\_indicators()}

    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ character.status\_effects}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

These examples demonstrate how conditionals are used to implement
complex business logic, multi-factor decisions, and state-based
behaviors in professional applications.

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-9}{%
\section{13. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-9}}

Test your understanding of conditional logic in Python:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  What is the correct syntax for an if statement in Python?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{if\ (condition)\ \{code\}}
  \item
    \texttt{if\ condition:\ code}
  \item
    \texttt{if\ condition\ then\ code}
  \item
    \texttt{if:\ condition\ code}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of these expressions will evaluate to \texttt{False}?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{5\ \textgreater{}\ 3\ and\ 10\ \textgreater{}\ 8}
  \item
    \texttt{5\ \textgreater{}\ 3\ or\ 2\ \textgreater{}\ 4}
  \item
    \texttt{5\ \textgreater{}\ 3\ and\ 2\ \textgreater{}\ 4}
  \item
    \texttt{not\ (5\ \textgreater{}\ 3)}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  If you have multiple conditions to check, which approach is most
  efficient?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Multiple separate \texttt{if} statements
  \item
    A chain of \texttt{if}/\texttt{elif}/\texttt{else} statements
  \item
    Nested \texttt{if} statements inside each other
  \item
    It depends on whether the conditions are related or independent
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What happens when multiple \texttt{elif} conditions are \texttt{True}?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    All the corresponding code blocks execute
  \item
    Only the first \texttt{True} condition's code block executes
  \item
    Only the last \texttt{True} condition's code block executes
  \item
    Python raises an error
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which statement about the \texttt{else} clause is correct?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Every \texttt{if} statement must have an \texttt{else} clause
  \item
    An \texttt{else} clause belongs to the most recent \texttt{if}
    statement that doesn't already have an \texttt{else}
  \item
    You can have multiple \texttt{else} clauses for a single \texttt{if}
    statement
  \item
    An \texttt{else} clause executes if any condition is \texttt{False}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What is the ``early return'' pattern used for?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Optimizing code execution speed
  \item
    Avoiding deeply nested conditional structures
  \item
    Creating recursive functions
  \item
    Implementing event loops
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of these is a best practice for conditional logic?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Using \texttt{==} to compare with \texttt{None} (e.g.,
    \texttt{if\ x\ ==\ None:})
  \item
    Creating deeply nested structures for complex decisions
  \item
    Using descriptive boolean variables for complex conditions
  \item
    Duplicating code in each branch for better performance
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  In the context of a chatbot, what is the advantage of using
  \texttt{elif} chains for response selection?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    It ensures all possible responses are given for a single input
  \item
    It guarantees that exactly one response is selected for each input
  \item
    It is faster than using separate \texttt{if} statements
  \item
    It requires less memory than other conditional structures
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers:} 1. b) \texttt{if\ condition:\ code} - Python uses a
colon and indentation 2. c)
\texttt{5\ \textgreater{}\ 3\ and\ 2\ \textgreater{}\ 4} - Only
evaluates to True if both conditions are True 3. d) It depends on
whether the conditions are related or independent - Use
\texttt{if}/\texttt{elif}/\texttt{else} for related, exclusive
conditions; separate \texttt{if} statements for independent conditions
4. b) Only the first \texttt{True} condition's code block executes -
Python stops checking after finding the first match 5. b) An
\texttt{else} clause belongs to the most recent \texttt{if} statement
that doesn't already have an \texttt{else} - This is an important
scoping rule 6. b) Avoiding deeply nested conditional structures - It
leads to flatter, more readable code 7. c) Using descriptive boolean
variables for complex conditions - This improves readability 8. b) It
guarantees that exactly one response is selected for each input -
Ensuring the chatbot gives a single, appropriate response

\section{16. Summary}\label{summary-9}}

In this chapter, you've learned the essential skills for making your
programs intelligent and responsive through conditional logic:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Using the \texttt{if} statement to execute code selectively based on
  conditions
\item
  Creating alternative paths with \texttt{else} and handling multiple
  options with \texttt{elif}
\item

\item
  Designing clean, readable decision structures that avoid common
  pitfalls
\item

\item

For our chatbot project, you've added the ability to make intelligent
decisions based on user input, creating more natural and engaging
conversations. As we progress through the book, we'll build on this
foundation to create increasingly sophisticated interactions.

Decision-making is one of the most fundamental aspects of programming.
Nearly every non-trivial program uses conditionals in some form, from
simple validations to complex business logic. The skills you've learned
in this chapter will serve you in virtually every program you write.

In the next chapter, we'll explore lists---Python's primary tool for
working with collections of data. Combined with conditionals, lists will
enable us to manage and process multiple pieces of information, further
enhancing our chatbot's capabilities.

\chapter{Chapter 11: Lists - Organizing Collections of
Data}\label{chapter-11-lists---organizing-collections-of-data}}

\hypertarget{chapter-outline-11}{%

\hypertarget{learning-objectives-11}{%
\section{Learning Objectives}\label{learning-objectives-11}}

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: - Create and modify
Python lists - Add, remove, and modify elements in a list - Sort and
organize list data - Access specific elements using indexes - Work with
lists of different data types - Use lists to organize and structure your
data - Implement lists in your programs

\hypertarget{introduction-why-we-need-lists}{%
\section{1. Introduction: Why We Need
Lists}\label{introduction-why-we-need-lists}}

In programming, we often need to work with collections of related data.
Imagine you need to store the names of five friends - without lists,
you'd need five separate variables:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{friend1 }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alice"}
\NormalTok{friend2 }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Bob"}
\NormalTok{friend3 }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Charlie"}
\NormalTok{friend4 }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"David"}
\NormalTok{friend5 }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Eva"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This becomes unwieldy quickly. Lists solve this problem by allowing us
to store multiple values in a single, organized container:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{friends }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Bob"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Charlie"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"David"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Eva"}\NormalTok{]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Lists are ordered, changeable (mutable), and allow duplicate values.
They're one of Python's most versatile and frequently used data
structures.

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: Ask your AI assistant to explain the concept of
lists using real-world analogies like shopping lists, playlists, or
to-do lists.}}

\hypertarget{creating-lists}{%
\section{2. Creating Lists}\label{creating-lists}}

You can create lists in several ways:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Empty list}
\NormalTok{empty\_list }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}

\CommentTok{\# List with initial values}
\NormalTok{numbers }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{]}

\CommentTok{\# List with mixed data types}
\NormalTok{mixed\_list }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{42}\NormalTok{, }\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{3.14}\NormalTok{, [}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]]}

\CommentTok{\# Creating a list from another sequence}
\NormalTok{letters }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{list}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"abcde"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Creates [\textquotesingle{}a\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}b\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}c\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}d\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}e\textquotesingle{}]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Lists are defined using square brackets \texttt{{[}\ {]}}, with elements
separated by commas.

\hypertarget{accessing-list-elements}{%
\section{3. Accessing List Elements}\label{accessing-list-elements}}

Each element in a list has an index - its position in the list. Python
uses zero-based indexing, meaning the first element is at index 0:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{fruits }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"apple"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"banana"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"cherry"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"date"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"elderberry"}\NormalTok{]}

\CommentTok{\# Accessing elements by index}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(fruits[}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{])  }\CommentTok{\# Output: "apple" (first element)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(fruits[}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{])  }\CommentTok{\# Output: "cherry" (third element)}

\CommentTok{\# Negative indexing (counting from the end)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(fruits[}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{])  }\CommentTok{\# Output: "elderberry" (last element)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(fruits[}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{])  }\CommentTok{\# Output: "date" (second{-}to{-}last element)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If you try to access an index that doesn't exist, Python will raise an
\texttt{IndexError}.

\hypertarget{adding-elements-to-lists}{%
\section{4. Adding Elements to Lists}\label{adding-elements-to-lists}}

There are several ways to add elements to a list:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Starting with an empty list}
\NormalTok{my\_list }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}

\CommentTok{\# Append adds a single element to the end}
\NormalTok{my\_list.append(}\DecValTok{20}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_list)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [20]}

\CommentTok{\# Extend adds all elements from another iterable}
\NormalTok{another\_list }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{11}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{22}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{my\_list.extend(another\_list)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_list)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [20, 11, 22]}

\CommentTok{\# Insert adds an element at a specific position}
\NormalTok{my\_list.insert(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{99}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Insert 99 at index 1}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_list)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [20, 99, 11, 22]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The methods have different uses: - \texttt{append()} - Add a single item
to the end - \texttt{extend()} - Add all items from another iterable
(like another list) - \texttt{insert()} - Add an item at a specific
position

\hypertarget{removing-elements-from-lists}{%
\section{5. Removing Elements from
Lists}\label{removing-elements-from-lists}}

Just as there are multiple ways to add elements, there are several ways
to remove them:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{my\_list }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{20}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{40}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{20}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{]}

\CommentTok{\# Remove by value (first occurrence)}
\NormalTok{my\_list.remove(}\DecValTok{20}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_list)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [10, 30, 40, 20, 50]}

\CommentTok{\# Remove by index and get the value}
\NormalTok{element }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ my\_list.pop(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Remove element at index 2}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(element)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 40}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_list)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [10, 30, 20, 50]}

\CommentTok{\# Remove the last element if no index is specified}
\NormalTok{last }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ my\_list.pop()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(last)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 50}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_list)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [10, 30, 20]}

\CommentTok{\# Clear all elements}
\NormalTok{my\_list.clear()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_list)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: []}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Key differences: - \texttt{remove()} - Removes by value (the first
occurrence) - \texttt{pop()} - Removes by index and returns the value -
\texttt{clear()} - Removes all elements

If you try to remove a value that doesn't exist with \texttt{remove()},
Python will raise a \texttt{ValueError}.

\hypertarget{sorting-and-organizing-lists}{%
\section{6. Sorting and Organizing
Lists}\label{sorting-and-organizing-lists}}

Python provides methods to sort and organize lists:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{numbers }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{9}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{6}\NormalTok{]}

\CommentTok{\# Sort the list in place (modifies the original list)}
\NormalTok{numbers.sort()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(numbers)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [1, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9]}

\CommentTok{\# Sort in descending order}
\NormalTok{numbers.sort(reverse}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(numbers)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [9, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 1]}

\CommentTok{\# Reverse the current order}
\NormalTok{numbers.reverse()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(numbers)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [1, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9]}

\CommentTok{\# Create a new sorted list without modifying the original}
\NormalTok{original }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{sorted\_list }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sorted}\NormalTok{(original)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(original)     }\CommentTok{\# Output: [3, 1, 4, 1, 5] (unchanged)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(sorted\_list)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [1, 1, 3, 4, 5]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note the difference between: - \texttt{list.sort()} - Modifies the
original list (in-place sorting) - \texttt{sorted(list)} - Creates a new
sorted list, leaving the original unchanged

\hypertarget{working-with-nested-lists}{%
\section{7. Working with Nested Lists}\label{working-with-nested-lists}}

Lists can contain other lists, creating multi-dimensional structures:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# A 2D list (list of lists)}
\NormalTok{matrix }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}
\NormalTok{    [}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{],}
\NormalTok{    [}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{6}\NormalTok{],}
\NormalTok{    [}\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{8}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{9}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{]}

\CommentTok{\# Accessing elements in a nested list}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(matrix[}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{])     }\CommentTok{\# Output: [1, 2, 3] (first row)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(matrix[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{][}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{])  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 6 (second row, third column)}

\CommentTok{\# Creating a list of lists}
\NormalTok{list1 }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{11}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{111}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1111}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{list2 }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{22}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{222}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2222}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{list\_of\_lists }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [list1, list2]}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(list\_of\_lists)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [[1, 11, 111, 1111], [2, 22, 222, 2222]]}

\CommentTok{\# Accessing nested elements}
\NormalTok{value }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ list\_of\_lists[}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{][}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]  }\CommentTok{\# First list, third element}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(value)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 111}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Nested lists are useful for representing grids, tables, or any data with
multiple dimensions.

\hypertarget{finding-information-about-lists}{%
\section{8. Finding Information About
Lists}\label{finding-information-about-lists}}

Python provides several ways to get information about a list:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{numbers }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]}

\CommentTok{\# Get the length of a list}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers))  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 7}

\CommentTok{\# Count occurrences of a value}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(numbers.count(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 3}

\CommentTok{\# Find the index of a value (first occurrence)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(numbers.index(}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 4}

\CommentTok{\# Check if a value exists in a list}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{3} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ numbers)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: True}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{6} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ numbers)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: False}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

These operations are helpful for analyzing list contents and finding
specific information.

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-10}{%
\section{9. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-10}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Which method adds a single element to the end of a list?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{add()}
  \item
    \texttt{insert()}
  \item
    \texttt{append()}
  \item
    \texttt{extend()}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What is the output of \texttt{print({[}"a",\ "b",\ "c"{]}{[}0{]})}?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{0}
  \item
    \texttt{"a"}
  \item
    \texttt{{[}"a"{]}}
  \item
    Error
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  If \texttt{my\_list\ =\ {[}10,\ 20,\ 30,\ 40{]}}, what is the result
  of \texttt{my\_list.pop(1)}?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{10}
  \item
    \texttt{20}
  \item
    \texttt{30}
  \item
    \texttt{40}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of these correctly creates an empty list?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{my\_list\ =\ \{\}}
  \item
    \texttt{my\_list\ =\ {[}{]}}
  \item
    \texttt{my\_list\ =\ ()}
  \item
    \texttt{my\_list\ =\ list}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What happens if you try to remove a value that doesn't exist in a list
  using \texttt{remove()}?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Nothing happens
  \item
    It removes \texttt{None}
  \item
    Python raises a ValueError
  \item
    The list becomes empty
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers \& Feedback:} 1. c) \texttt{append()} --- This adds a
single element to the end of the list 2. b) \texttt{"a"} --- Lists use
zero-based indexing, so index 0 refers to the first element 3. b)
\texttt{20} --- \texttt{pop(1)} removes and returns the element at index
1, which is 20 4. b) \texttt{my\_list\ =\ {[}{]}} --- Empty lists are
created with square brackets 5. c) Python raises a ValueError --- You
can only remove values that exist in the list

\hypertarget{common-list-mistakes-to-avoid}{%
\section{10. Common List Mistakes to
Avoid}\label{common-list-mistakes-to-avoid}}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Forgetting that list indexing starts at 0, not 1
\item
  Using \texttt{append()} when you mean \texttt{extend()} (resulting in
  nested lists when not intended)
\item
  Modifying a list while iterating over it (can cause unexpected
  behavior)
\item
  Forgetting that \texttt{sort()} modifies the original list
\item
  Not checking if a value exists before calling \texttt{remove()}
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{project-corner-adding-memory-to-your-chatbot}{%
\section{Project Corner: Adding Memory to Your
Chatbot}\label{project-corner-adding-memory-to-your-chatbot}}

Now that you understand lists, we can enhance our chatbot by adding
conversation history:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Creating a list to store conversation history}
\NormalTok{conversation\_history }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ save\_to\_history(speaker, text):}
    \CommentTok{"""Save an utterance to conversation history."""}
\NormalTok{    conversation\_history.append(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{speaker}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ show\_history():}
    \CommentTok{"""Display the conversation history."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{{-}{-}{-}{-}{-} Conversation History {-}{-}{-}{-}{-}"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ entry }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ conversation\_history:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(entry)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Main chat loop}
\NormalTok{bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. Type \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to exit or \textquotesingle{}history\textquotesingle{} to see our conversation."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Save this initial greeting}
\NormalTok{save\_to\_history(bot\_name, }\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    save\_to\_history(user\_name, user\_input)}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        save\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}
        \ControlFlowTok{break}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"history"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        show\_history()}
        \ControlFlowTok{continue}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Simple response generation}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{"hello"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower():}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Hello there, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"how are you"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower():}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m just a computer program, but thanks for asking!"}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif} \StringTok{"name"} \KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower():}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"My name is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m not sure how to respond to that yet."}
    
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    save\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

With this enhancement: 1. Every message is saved to our
\texttt{conversation\_history} list 2. Users can type ``history'' to see
the entire conversation 3. The chatbot now has ``memory'' of what was
said

\textbf{Challenges}: - Add a command to clear the history - Implement a
feature to search the conversation history for keywords - Create a
function to summarize the conversation based on the history - Add
timestamps to each message in the history

\hypertarget{practical-list-applications}{%
\section{Practical List
Applications}\label{practical-list-applications}}

Here are some common real-world applications of lists:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  \textbf{To-do Lists}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{tasks }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"Buy groceries"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Clean house"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Pay bills"}\NormalTok{]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Collection Management}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{books }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"The Hobbit"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Dune"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Foundation"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Neuromancer"}\NormalTok{]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Queue Systems}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{waiting\_list }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"Patient A"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Patient B"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Patient C"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{next\_patient }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ waiting\_list.pop(}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# First in, first out}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Data Analysis}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{temperatures }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\FloatTok{23.5}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{24.1}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{22.8}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{25.0}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{23.9}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{average }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(temperatures) }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(temperatures)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Multi-step Processes}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{recipe\_steps }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}
    \StringTok{"Mix ingredients"}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"Pour into pan"}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"Bake for 30 minutes"}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"Let cool"}
\NormalTok{]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\end{enumerate}

Lists are fundamental building blocks in Python programming - mastering
them opens up countless possibilities for organizing and manipulating
data.

\hypertarget{going-loopy-repeating-code-without-losing-your-mind}{%
\chapter{Going Loopy: Repeating Code Without Losing Your
Mind}\label{going-loopy-repeating-code-without-losing-your-mind}}

\hypertarget{chapter-12-loops---automating-repetitive-tasks}{%
\chapter{Chapter 12: Loops - Automating Repetitive
Tasks}\label{chapter-12-loops---automating-repetitive-tasks}}

\hypertarget{chapter-outline-12}{%
\section{Chapter Outline}\label{chapter-outline-12}}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Understanding loops and iteration
\item
  For loops with lists and ranges
\item
  While loops
\item
  Loop control with break and continue
\item
  Nested loops
\item
