\hypertarget{learning-objectives-14}{%
\section{Learning Objectives}\label{learning-objectives-14}}

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: - Create and initialize
Python dictionaries - Access, add, and modify dictionary values - Remove
elements from dictionaries using various methods - Iterate through
dictionary keys and values - Sort dictionaries by keys or values - Apply
dictionaries to solve real-world problems - Use dictionaries to organize
complex data

\hypertarget{introduction-the-power-of-key-value-pairs}{%
\section{1. Introduction: The Power of Key-Value
Pairs}\label{introduction-the-power-of-key-value-pairs}}

Dictionaries are one of Python's most versatile and powerful data
structures. Unlike lists, which store items in a specific order
accessible by index, dictionaries store data in key-value pairs,
allowing you to access values based on meaningful keys rather than
numerical positions.

Think of a Python dictionary like a real-world dictionary, where you
look up the definition (value) of a word (key). Just as each word in a
dictionary has a unique definition, each key in a Python dictionary must
be unique.

Dictionaries are perfect for: - Storing related pieces of information -
Creating lookup tables - Counting occurrences of items - Representing
real-world objects with attributes - Managing configuration settings -
Building simple databases

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: Ask your AI assistant to suggest dictionary
applications specific to your field of interest or to explain how
dictionaries compare to similar data structures in other programming
languages.}}

\hypertarget{creating-and-initializing-dictionaries}{%
\section{2. Creating and Initializing
Dictionaries}\label{creating-and-initializing-dictionaries}}

There are several ways to create dictionaries in Python:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Empty dictionary}
\NormalTok{empty\_dict }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{\}}

\CommentTok{\# Dictionary with initial values}
\NormalTok{student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{\# Using the dict() constructor}
\NormalTok{contact }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{dict}\NormalTok{(name}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Alice\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, phone}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}555{-}1234\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, email}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}alice@example.com\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Creating from two lists (zip creates pairs from two sequences)}
\NormalTok{keys }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}apple\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}banana\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}cherry\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{values }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\FloatTok{1.99}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.99}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{2.49}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{fruit\_prices }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{dict}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{zip}\NormalTok{(keys, values))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

A few important points to remember: - Dictionary keys must be immutable
(strings, numbers, or tuples, not lists) - Values can be any type
(numbers, strings, lists, other dictionaries, etc.) - Keys are
case-sensitive (\texttt{\textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}} and
\texttt{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}} are different keys) -
Dictionaries are unordered in Python versions before 3.7 (ordered since
3.7)

\hypertarget{accessing-dictionary-elements}{%
\section{3. Accessing Dictionary
Elements}\label{accessing-dictionary-elements}}

You can access dictionary values using their keys in square brackets or
with the \texttt{get()} method:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{\# Using square brackets}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{])  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Michael}

\CommentTok{\# Using get() method}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 23}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The key difference between these methods is how they handle missing
keys:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Using square brackets with a non{-}existent key}
\CommentTok{\# print(student[\textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}])  \# Raises KeyError}

\CommentTok{\# Using get() with a non{-}existent key}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# Output: None}

\CommentTok{\# Using get() with a default value}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Not specified\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Not specified}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The \texttt{get()} method is often preferred for accessing dictionary
values because it provides a safer way to handle missing keys without
causing errors.

\hypertarget{modifying-dictionary-content}{%
\section{4. Modifying Dictionary
Content}\label{modifying-dictionary-content}}

Dictionaries are mutable, meaning you can change, add, or remove their
key-value pairs after creation.

\hypertarget{adding-or-updating-elements}{%
\subsection{Adding or Updating
Elements}\label{adding-or-updating-elements}}

You can add new key-value pairs or update existing values:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{\# Adding a new key{-}value pair}
\NormalTok{student[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \FloatTok{5.8}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: \{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}: \textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}: \textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}: 23, \textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}: 5.8\}}

\CommentTok{\# Updating an existing value}
\NormalTok{student[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{24}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: \{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}: \textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}: \textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}: 24, \textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}: 5.8\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{removing-elements}{%
\subsection{Removing Elements}\label{removing-elements}}

Python provides multiple ways to remove elements from dictionaries:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\FloatTok{5.8}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Occupation\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Student\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{\# del {-} Remove a specific key{-}value pair}
\KeywordTok{del}\NormalTok{ student[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student)  }\CommentTok{\# \{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}: \textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}: 23, \textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}: 5.8, \textquotesingle{}Occupation\textquotesingle{}: \textquotesingle{}Student\textquotesingle{}\}}

\CommentTok{\# pop() {-} Remove a specific key and return its value}
\NormalTok{sex }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ student.pop(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(sex)      }\CommentTok{\# Output: Male}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student)  }\CommentTok{\# \{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}: 23, \textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}: 5.8, \textquotesingle{}Occupation\textquotesingle{}: \textquotesingle{}Student\textquotesingle{}\}}

\CommentTok{\# popitem() {-} Remove the last inserted key{-}value pair}
\NormalTok{item }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ student.popitem()  }\CommentTok{\# In Python 3.7+, removes the last item}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(item)     }\CommentTok{\# Output: (\textquotesingle{}Occupation\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Student\textquotesingle{})}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student)  }\CommentTok{\# \{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}: 23, \textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}: 5.8\}}

\CommentTok{\# clear() {-} Remove all key{-}value pairs}
\NormalTok{student.clear()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: \{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Each removal method has its specific use: - \texttt{del} - When you just
want to remove a key - \texttt{pop()} - When you want to remove a key
and use its value - \texttt{popitem()} - When you want to process items
one by one - \texttt{clear()} - When you want to empty the entire
dictionary

\hypertarget{dictionary-methods-and-operations}{%
\section{5. Dictionary Methods and
Operations}\label{dictionary-methods-and-operations}}

Dictionaries come with a rich set of built-in methods that make them
even more powerful:

\hypertarget{getting-dictionary-information}{%
\subsection{Getting Dictionary
Information}\label{getting-dictionary-information}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\FloatTok{5.8}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Occupation\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Student\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{\# Get all keys}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student.keys())  }\CommentTok{\# Output: dict\_keys([\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Occupation\textquotesingle{}])}

\CommentTok{\# Get all values}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student.values())  }\CommentTok{\# Output: dict\_values([\textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}, 23, 5.8, \textquotesingle{}Student\textquotesingle{}])}

\CommentTok{\# Get all key{-}value pairs as tuples}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(student.items())  }\CommentTok{\# Output: dict\_items([(\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}), (\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}), ...])}

\CommentTok{\# Get the number of key{-}value pairs}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(student))  }\CommentTok{\# Output: 5}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{copying-dictionaries}{%
\subsection{Copying Dictionaries}\label{copying-dictionaries}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{\# Shallow copy (creates a new dictionary with references to the same values)}
\NormalTok{student\_copy }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ student.copy()}

\CommentTok{\# Alternative way to create a shallow copy}
\NormalTok{student\_copy2 }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{dict}\NormalTok{(student)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note that these methods create shallow copies. For nested dictionaries,
you might need a deep copy.

\hypertarget{iterating-through-dictionaries}{%
\section{6. Iterating Through
Dictionaries}\label{iterating-through-dictionaries}}

There are several ways to loop through dictionaries:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\FloatTok{5.8}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Occupation\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Student\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{\# Iterate through keys (default)}
\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ key }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ student:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(key)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Name, Sex, Age, Height, Occupation}

\CommentTok{\# Iterate through keys explicitly}
\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ key }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ student.keys():}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(key)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Name, Sex, Age, Height, Occupation}

\CommentTok{\# Iterate through values}
\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ value }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ student.values():}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(value)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: Michael, Male, 23, 5.8, Student}

\CommentTok{\# Iterate through key{-}value pairs}
\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ key, value }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ student.items():}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{key}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{value}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{sorting-dictionaries}{%
\subsection{Sorting Dictionaries}\label{sorting-dictionaries}}

Dictionaries themselves are not sortable, but you can sort their keys or
items:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\FloatTok{5.8}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Occupation\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Student\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{\# Get sorted keys}
\NormalTok{sorted\_keys }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sorted}\NormalTok{(student.keys())}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(sorted\_keys)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Occupation\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}]}

\CommentTok{\# Get sorted keys in reverse order}
\NormalTok{sorted\_keys\_reverse }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sorted}\NormalTok{(student.keys(), reverse}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(sorted\_keys\_reverse)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: [\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Occupation\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Height\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}]}

\CommentTok{\# Iterate through dictionary in sorted order}
\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ key }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{sorted}\NormalTok{(student.keys()):}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{key}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{student[key]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{dictionary-comprehensions}{%
\section{7. Dictionary Comprehensions}\label{dictionary-comprehensions}}

Just like list comprehensions, Python offers dictionary comprehensions
for creating dictionaries concisely:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Create a dictionary of squares}
\NormalTok{squares }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{x: x}\OperatorTok{**}\DecValTok{2} \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ x }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{range}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{6}\NormalTok{)\}}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(squares)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: \{1: 1, 2: 4, 3: 9, 4: 16, 5: 25\}}

\CommentTok{\# Filter items with a condition}
\NormalTok{even\_squares }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{x: x}\OperatorTok{**}\DecValTok{2} \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ x }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{range}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{11}\NormalTok{) }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ x }\OperatorTok{\%} \DecValTok{2} \OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{\}}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(even\_squares)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: \{2: 4, 4: 16, 6: 36, 8: 64, 10: 100\}}

\CommentTok{\# Transform an existing dictionary}
\NormalTok{student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sex\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{23}\NormalTok{\}}
\NormalTok{uppercase\_dict }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{k.upper(): v }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ k, v }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ student.items()\}}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(uppercase\_dict)  }\CommentTok{\# Output: \{\textquotesingle{}NAME\textquotesingle{}: \textquotesingle{}Michael\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}SEX\textquotesingle{}: \textquotesingle{}Male\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}AGE\textquotesingle{}: 23\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{nested-dictionaries}{%
\section{8. Nested Dictionaries}\label{nested-dictionaries}}

Dictionaries can contain other dictionaries as values, allowing you to
represent complex hierarchical data:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# A dictionary of students}
\NormalTok{students }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}S001\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Alice\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{20}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}grades\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}math\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{85}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}science\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{90}\NormalTok{\}\},}
    \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}S002\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Bob\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{21}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}grades\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}math\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{92}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}science\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{88}\NormalTok{\}\},}
    \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}S003\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Charlie\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{19}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}grades\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}math\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{78}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}science\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{85}\NormalTok{\}\}}
\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{\# Accessing nested values}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(students[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}S001\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{][}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{])              }\CommentTok{\# Output: Alice}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(students[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}S002\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{][}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}grades\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{][}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}math\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{])    }\CommentTok{\# Output: 92}

\CommentTok{\# Modifying nested values}
\NormalTok{students[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}S003\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{][}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}grades\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{][}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}science\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{87}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Nested dictionaries are extremely useful for representing real-world
hierarchical data like organizational structures, product catalogs, or
student records.

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-13}{%
\section{9. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-13}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  What will be the output of the following code?

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{d }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}a\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}b\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{\}}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(d.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}c\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Not found\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    KeyError: `c'
  \item
    None
  \item
    `Not found'
  \item
    False
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which method would you use to remove a key-value pair from a
  dictionary and return the value?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{remove()}
  \item
    \texttt{delete()}
  \item
    \texttt{pop()}
  \item
    \texttt{discard()}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What happens if you try to access a key that doesn't exist in a
  dictionary using square bracket notation (\texttt{dict{[}key{]}})?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    It returns None
  \item
    It returns a default value
  \item
    It raises a KeyError
  \item
    It adds the key with a None value
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of the following is NOT a valid dictionary key type?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Integer
  \item
    String
  \item
    List
  \item
    Tuple
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What will the following code print?

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{d }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}a\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}b\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}c\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{\}}
\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ key }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{sorted}\NormalTok{(d):}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(key, end}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{} \textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    a b c
  \item
    1 2 3
  \item
    a 1 b 2 c 3
  \item
    The code will raise an error
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers \& Feedback:} 1. c) `Not found' --- The get() method
returns the specified default value when the key is not found 2. c)
\texttt{pop()} --- This removes the key and returns its value 3. c) It
raises a KeyError --- Unlike get(), direct access requires the key to
exist 4. c) List --- Lists are mutable, so they can't be dictionary keys
5. a) a b c --- This code sorts the keys alphabetically and prints them

\hypertarget{common-dictionary-pitfalls}{%
\section{10. Common Dictionary
Pitfalls}\label{common-dictionary-pitfalls}}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{KeyError}: Trying to access a non-existent key without using
  \texttt{get()}
\item
  \textbf{Mutating while iterating}: Modifying a dictionary while
  looping through it can lead to unexpected behavior
\item
  \textbf{Confusing keys and values}: Remember that \texttt{keys()}
  gives you keys, not values
\item
  \textbf{Shallow vs.~deep copying}: Be careful with nested
  dictionaries, as shallow copies don't copy nested structures
\item
  \textbf{Dictionary equality}: Two dictionaries are equal if they have
  the same key-value pairs, regardless of order
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{project-corner-upgrading-your-chatbot-with-dictionaries}{%
\section{Project Corner: Upgrading Your Chatbot with
Dictionaries}\label{project-corner-upgrading-your-chatbot-with-dictionaries}}

Let's enhance our chatbot by using dictionaries to organize response
patterns and templates:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ random}

\CommentTok{\# Using dictionaries for more sophisticated response patterns}
\NormalTok{response\_patterns }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hi"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hey"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"howdy"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hola"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"morning"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"evening"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"see you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"cya"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"farewell"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"exit"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"gratitude"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"thanks"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"thank you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"appreciate"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"grateful"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"bot\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"who are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"what are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"your name"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"your purpose"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"user\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"how are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"what\textquotesingle{}s up"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"how do you feel"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"capabilities"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"what can you do"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"functions"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"abilities"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"commands"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{\}}

\NormalTok{response\_templates }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}
        \StringTok{"Hello there! How can I help you today?"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"Hi! Nice to chat with you!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"Hey! How\textquotesingle{}s your day going?"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"Greetings! What\textquotesingle{}s on your mind?"}
\NormalTok{    ],}
    \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}
        \StringTok{"Goodbye! Come back soon!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"See you later! Have a great day!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"Until next time! Take care!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"Farewell! It was nice chatting with you!"}
\NormalTok{    ],}
    \StringTok{"gratitude"}\NormalTok{: [}
        \StringTok{"You\textquotesingle{}re welcome!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"Happy to help!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"My pleasure!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"No problem at all!"}
\NormalTok{    ],}
    \StringTok{"bot\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}
        \SpecialStringTok{f"I\textquotesingle{}m PyBot, a simple chatbot built with Python!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m a demonstration chatbot for the Python Jumpstart book."}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m your friendly Python{-}powered conversation partner!"}
\NormalTok{    ],}
    \StringTok{"user\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}
        \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m functioning well, thanks for asking!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m here and ready to chat!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m operational and at your service!"}
\NormalTok{    ],}
    \StringTok{"capabilities"}\NormalTok{: [}
        \StringTok{"I can chat about basic topics, remember our conversation, and give responses based on patterns I recognize."}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"Try asking me who I am, say hello, or just chat naturally!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"I can respond to greetings, questions about myself, and basic conversation. I\textquotesingle{}m also learning new tricks!"}
\NormalTok{    ],}
    \StringTok{"unknown"}\NormalTok{: [}
        \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m not sure I understand. Can you rephrase that?"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"Hmm, I\textquotesingle{}m still learning and don\textquotesingle{}t quite understand that."}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"That\textquotesingle{}s beyond my current capabilities, but I\textquotesingle{}m always learning!"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"Interesting, tell me more about that."}
\NormalTok{    ]}
\NormalTok{\}}

\CommentTok{\# User stats dictionary to track interaction metrics}
\NormalTok{user\_stats }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"message\_count"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"question\_count"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"greeting\_count"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"command\_count"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"start\_time"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"topics"}\NormalTok{: \{\}  }\CommentTok{\# Count topics discussed}
\NormalTok{\}}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input):}
    \CommentTok{"""Get a response using dictionary{-}based pattern matching."""}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower().strip()}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Update stats}
\NormalTok{    user\_stats[}\StringTok{"message\_count"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.endswith(}\StringTok{"?"}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{        user\_stats[}\StringTok{"question\_count"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Check for special commands}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"stats"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        user\_stats[}\StringTok{"command\_count"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"""}
\SpecialStringTok{Conversation Stats:}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Messages sent: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_stats[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}message\_count\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Questions asked: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_stats[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}question\_count\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Greetings: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_stats[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}greeting\_count\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Commands used: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_stats[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}command\_count\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} Topics mentioned: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{join(user\_stats[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}topics\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{].keys()) }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_stats[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}topics\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{] }\ControlFlowTok{else} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}None\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\}}
\SpecialStringTok{        """}\NormalTok{.strip()}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Check for patterns in our response dictionary}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ category, patterns }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ response\_patterns.items():}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ patterns:}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
                \CommentTok{\# Update stats for this topic/category}
                \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ category }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_stats[}\StringTok{"topics"}\NormalTok{]:}
\NormalTok{                    user\_stats[}\StringTok{"topics"}\NormalTok{][category] }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}
                \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{                    user\_stats[}\StringTok{"topics"}\NormalTok{][category] }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{1}
                
                \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ category }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{                    user\_stats[}\StringTok{"greeting\_count"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}
                
                \CommentTok{\# Return a random response from the matching category}
                \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ random.choice(response\_templates[category])}
    
    \CommentTok{\# No pattern matched, return an unknown response}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ random.choice(response\_templates[}\StringTok{"unknown"}\NormalTok{])}

\CommentTok{\# Main chat loop}
\NormalTok{bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. Type \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to exit or \textquotesingle{}stats\textquotesingle{} for conversation statistics."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{).strip()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ datetime }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ datetime}
\NormalTok{user\_stats[}\StringTok{"start\_time"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.now()}

\NormalTok{conversation\_history }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ save\_to\_history(speaker, text):}
    \CommentTok{"""Save an utterance to conversation history."""}
\NormalTok{    timestamp }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.now().strftime(}\StringTok{"\%H:\%M:\%S"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    conversation\_history.append(\{}
        \StringTok{"speaker"}\NormalTok{: speaker,}
        \StringTok{"text"}\NormalTok{: text,}
        \StringTok{"timestamp"}\NormalTok{: timestamp}
\NormalTok{    \})}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ show\_history():}
    \CommentTok{"""Display the conversation history."""}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{{-}{-}{-}{-}{-} Conversation History {-}{-}{-}{-}{-}"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ entry }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ conversation\_history:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"[}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{entry[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}timestamp\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{] }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{entry[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}speaker\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{entry[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}text\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Save initial greeting}
\NormalTok{save\_to\_history(bot\_name, }\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    save\_to\_history(user\_name, user\_input)}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"exit"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"quit"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{]:}
\NormalTok{        duration }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.now() }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ user\_stats[}\StringTok{"start\_time"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{        minutes }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(duration.total\_seconds() }\OperatorTok{//} \DecValTok{60}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        seconds }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(duration.total\_seconds() }\OperatorTok{\%} \DecValTok{60}\NormalTok{)}
        
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! We chatted for }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{minutes}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ minutes and }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{seconds}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ seconds."}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        save\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}
        \ControlFlowTok{break}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"history"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        show\_history()}
        \ControlFlowTok{continue}
    
\NormalTok{    response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    save\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Our enhanced chatbot now: 1. Uses dictionaries to organize response
patterns and templates 2. Tracks conversation statistics in a dictionary
3. Stores conversation history using dictionaries with timestamps 4.
Provides a stats command to view interaction metrics 5. Measures
conversation duration 6. Has more diverse response categories

\textbf{Challenges}: - Add a ``mood'' system that changes response tone
based on user interaction - Create a knowledge dictionary where the
chatbot can remember facts about the user - Implement a frequency-based
suggestion system for common user questions - Allow the user to teach
the chatbot new response patterns - Create a persistent settings
dictionary that can be saved and loaded

\hypertarget{real-world-dictionary-applications}{%
\section{Real-World Dictionary
Applications}\label{real-world-dictionary-applications}}

Dictionaries are foundational to many programming tasks. Here are some
common real-world applications:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  \textbf{Configuration Settings}: Storing application settings in a
  hierarchical structure.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{app\_config }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"user"}\NormalTok{: \{}
        \StringTok{"name"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"Default User"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"theme"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"dark"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"notifications"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{True}
\NormalTok{    \},}
    \StringTok{"system"}\NormalTok{: \{}
        \StringTok{"max\_threads"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"log\_level"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"info"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"debug\_mode"}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{False}
\NormalTok{    \}}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Data Transformation}: Converting between different data
  formats.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Convert user data to API format}
\NormalTok{user }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{"first\_name"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"John"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"last\_name"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"Doe"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"age"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{\}}
\NormalTok{api\_data }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"user"}\NormalTok{: \{}
        \StringTok{"name"}\NormalTok{: }\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}first\_name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}last\_name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{"metadata"}\NormalTok{: \{}\StringTok{"age"}\NormalTok{: user[}\StringTok{"age"}\NormalTok{]\}}
\NormalTok{    \}}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Caching}: Storing computed results for quick access.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# A simple function memoization}
\NormalTok{fibonacci\_cache }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{\}}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ fibonacci(n):}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ n }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ fibonacci\_cache:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ fibonacci\_cache[n]}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ n }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ n}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ fibonacci(n}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ fibonacci(n}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{    fibonacci\_cache[n] }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ result}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ result}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Counting and Statistics}: Tracking occurrences of items.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Count word frequency in a text}
\NormalTok{text }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog"}
\NormalTok{word\_count }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{\}}

\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ word }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ text.split():}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ word }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ word\_count:}
\NormalTok{        word\_count[word] }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        word\_count[word] }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{1}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Lookup Tables}: Creating mappings for faster operation.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Month name to number mapping}
\NormalTok{month\_to\_num }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"January"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"February"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"March"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"April"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"May"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"June"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{6}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"July"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"August"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{8}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"September"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{9}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{"October"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"November"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{11}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"December"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{12}
\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\end{enumerate}

These examples show why dictionaries are one of Python's most useful and
versatile data structures. As you continue your Python journey, you'll
find countless ways to apply them to make your code more efficient,
readable, and powerful.
