\hypertarget{learning-objectives-15}{%
\section{Learning Objectives}\label{learning-objectives-15}}

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: - Understand how file
operations work in Python - Read data from text files - Write and append
data to files - Safely manage file resources with the with statement -
Work with file paths and different file formats - Create programs that
persist data between runs - Implement file operations in practical
applications

\hypertarget{introduction-why-store-data-in-files}{%
\section{1. Introduction: Why Store Data in
Files?}\label{introduction-why-store-data-in-files}}

So far, all the programs we've written have been ephemeral - the data
exists only while the program is running. Once the program ends, all the
variables, lists, and dictionaries vanish from memory. But what if you
want to save your data for later use? Or what if you want to share data
between different programs?

This is where files come in. Files allow your programs to:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Save data permanently on disk
\item
  Read existing data into your programs
\item
  Share information between different programs
\item
  Process large amounts of data that wouldn't fit in memory
\item
  Import data from external sources
\item
  Export results for other applications to use
\end{itemize}

In this chapter, we'll learn how to read from and write to files, which
is a fundamental skill for creating useful programs.

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: Ask your AI assistant to help you understand the
difference between volatile memory (RAM) and persistent storage (disk)
in computing.}}

\hypertarget{understanding-file-operations}{%
\section{2. Understanding File
Operations}\label{understanding-file-operations}}

Working with files in Python typically follows a three-step process:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Open} the file, which creates a connection to the file and
  prepares it for reading or writing
\item
  \textbf{Read from} or \textbf{write to} the file
\item
  \textbf{Close} the file to save changes and free up system resources
\end{enumerate}

Let's look at the basic syntax:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Step 1: Open the file}
\BuiltInTok{file} \OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}example.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# \textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{} means "read mode"}

\CommentTok{\# Step 2: Read from the file}
\NormalTok{content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(content)}

\CommentTok{\# Step 3: Close the file}
\BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.close()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The \texttt{open()} function takes two arguments: - The filename (or
path) - The mode (how you want to use the file)

Common file modes include: -
\texttt{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}} - Read (default): Open
for reading - \texttt{\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{}} - Write:
Open for writing (creates a new file or truncates an existing one) -
\texttt{\textquotesingle{}a\textquotesingle{}} - Append: Open for
writing, appending to the end of the file -
\texttt{\textquotesingle{}r+\textquotesingle{}} - Read+Write: Open for
both reading and writing -
\texttt{\textquotesingle{}b\textquotesingle{}} - Binary mode (added to
other modes, e.g., \texttt{\textquotesingle{}rb\textquotesingle{}} for
reading binary files)

\hypertarget{using-the-with-statement-a-safer-approach}{%
\section{3. Using the with Statement: A Safer
Approach}\label{using-the-with-statement-a-safer-approach}}

It's crucial to close files after you're done with them, but it's easy
to forget or miss this step if an error occurs. Python provides a
cleaner solution with the \texttt{with} statement, which automatically
closes the file when the block is exited:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# A safer way to work with files}
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}example.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(content)}
\CommentTok{\# File is automatically closed when the block exits}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This approach is preferred because: - It's more concise - The file is
automatically closed, even if an error occurs - It follows Python's
``context manager'' pattern for resource management

Throughout this chapter, we'll use the \texttt{with} statement for all
file operations.

\hypertarget{reading-from-files}{%
\section{4. Reading from Files}\label{reading-from-files}}

Python offers several methods for reading file content:

\hypertarget{reading-the-entire-file}{%
\subsection{Reading the Entire File}\label{reading-the-entire-file}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}example.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()  }\CommentTok{\# Reads the entire file into a single string}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(content)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{reading-line-by-line}{%
\subsection{Reading Line by Line}\label{reading-line-by-line}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}example.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
    \CommentTok{\# Read one line at a time}
\NormalTok{    first\_line }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.readline()}
\NormalTok{    second\_line }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.readline()}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(first\_line.strip())  }\CommentTok{\# .strip() removes the newline character}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(second\_line.strip())}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{reading-all-lines-into-a-list}{%
\subsection{Reading All Lines into a
List}\label{reading-all-lines-into-a-list}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}example.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    lines }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.readlines()  }\CommentTok{\# Returns a list where each element is a line}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ line }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ lines:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(line.strip())}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{iterating-over-a-file}{%
\subsection{Iterating Over a File}\label{iterating-over-a-file}}

The most memory-efficient way to process large files is to iterate
directly over the file object:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}example.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ line }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:  }\CommentTok{\# File objects are iterable}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(line.strip())}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This approach reads only one line at a time into memory, which is ideal
for large files.

\hypertarget{writing-to-files}{%
\section{5. Writing to Files}\label{writing-to-files}}

Writing to files is just as straightforward as reading:

\hypertarget{creating-a-new-file-or-overwriting-an-existing-one}{%
\subsection{Creating a New File or Overwriting an Existing
One}\label{creating-a-new-file-or-overwriting-an-existing-one}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}output.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.write(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Hello, world!}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# \textbackslash{}n adds a newline}
    \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.write(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}This is a new file.\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This creates a new file named \texttt{output.txt} (or overwrites it if
it already exists) with the content ``Hello, world!'' followed by ``This
is a new file.'' on the next line.

\hypertarget{appending-to-an-existing-file}{%
\subsection{Appending to an Existing
File}\label{appending-to-an-existing-file}}

If you want to add content to the end of an existing file without
overwriting it, use the append mode:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}log.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}a\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.write(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}New log entry}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{writing-multiple-lines-at-once}{%
\subsection{Writing Multiple Lines at
Once}\label{writing-multiple-lines-at-once}}

The \texttt{writelines()} method lets you write multiple lines from a
list:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{lines }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}First line}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Second line}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Third line}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}

\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}multiline.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.writelines(lines)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note that \texttt{writelines()} doesn't add newline characters
automatically; you need to include them in your strings.

\hypertarget{working-with-file-paths}{%
\section{6. Working with File Paths}\label{working-with-file-paths}}

So far, we've worked with files in the current directory. To work with
files in other locations, you need to specify the path:

\hypertarget{absolute-paths}{%
\subsection{Absolute Paths}\label{absolute-paths}}

An absolute path specifies the complete location from the root
directory:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Windows example}
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\VerbatimStringTok{r\textquotesingle{}C:\textbackslash{}Users\textbackslash{}Username\textbackslash{}Documents\textbackslash{}file.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}

\CommentTok{\# Mac/Linux example}
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}/home/username/documents/file.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Note the \texttt{r} prefix in the Windows example, which creates a ``raw
string'' that doesn't interpret backslashes as escape characters.

\hypertarget{relative-paths}{%
\subsection{Relative Paths}\label{relative-paths}}

A relative path specifies the location relative to the current
directory:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# File in the current directory}
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}file.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}

\CommentTok{\# File in a subdirectory}
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}data/file.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}

\CommentTok{\# File in the parent directory}
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}../file.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{using-the-os.path-module}{%
\subsection{Using the os.path Module}\label{using-the-os.path-module}}

For platform-independent code, use the \texttt{os.path} module to handle
file paths:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}

\CommentTok{\# Join path components}
\NormalTok{file\_path }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ os.path.join(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}data\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}user\_info\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}profile.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Check if a file exists}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ os.path.exists(file\_path):}
    \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(file\_path, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"File }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{file\_path}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ does not exist"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{common-file-operations}{%
\section{7. Common File Operations}\label{common-file-operations}}

Beyond basic reading and writing, here are some common file operations:

\hypertarget{checking-if-a-file-exists}{%
\subsection{Checking if a File Exists}\label{checking-if-a-file-exists}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}

\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ os.path.exists(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}file.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{):}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"The file exists"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"The file does not exist"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{creating-directories}{%
\subsection{Creating Directories}\label{creating-directories}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}

\CommentTok{\# Create a single directory}
\NormalTok{os.mkdir(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}new\_folder\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Create multiple nested directories}
\NormalTok{os.makedirs(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}parent/child/grandchild\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{listing-files-in-a-directory}{%
\subsection{Listing Files in a
Directory}\label{listing-files-in-a-directory}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}

\CommentTok{\# List all files and directories}
\NormalTok{entries }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ os.listdir(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}.\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# \textquotesingle{}.\textquotesingle{} represents the current directory}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(entries)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{deleting-files}{%
\subsection{Deleting Files}\label{deleting-files}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}

\CommentTok{\# Delete a file}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ os.path.exists(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}unwanted.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{    os.remove(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}unwanted.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{renaming-files}{%
\subsection{Renaming Files}\label{renaming-files}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}

\CommentTok{\# Rename a file}
\NormalTok{os.rename(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}old\_name.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}new\_name.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{working-with-csv-files}{%
\section{8. Working with CSV Files}\label{working-with-csv-files}}

Comma-Separated Values (CSV) files are a common format for storing
tabular data. Python provides the \texttt{csv} module for working with
CSV files:

\hypertarget{reading-csv-files}{%
\subsection{Reading CSV Files}\label{reading-csv-files}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ csv}

\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}data.csv\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    csv\_reader }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ csv.reader(}\BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Skip the header row (if present)}
\NormalTok{    header }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{next}\NormalTok{(csv\_reader)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Column names: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{header}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Process each row}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ row }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ csv\_reader:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(row)  }\CommentTok{\# Each row is a list of values}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{writing-csv-files}{%
\subsection{Writing CSV Files}\label{writing-csv-files}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ csv}

\NormalTok{data }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}
\NormalTok{    [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Age\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}City\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{],  }\CommentTok{\# Header row}
\NormalTok{    [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Alice\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{25}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}New York\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{],}
\NormalTok{    [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Bob\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{30}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}San Francisco\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{],}
\NormalTok{    [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Charlie\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{35}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Los Angeles\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{]}

\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}output.csv\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, newline}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    csv\_writer }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ csv.writer(}\BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Write all rows at once}
\NormalTok{    csv\_writer.writerows(data)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{working-with-json-files}{%
\section{9. Working with JSON Files}\label{working-with-json-files}}

JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) is a popular data format that's
particularly useful for storing hierarchical data. Python's
\texttt{json} module makes it easy to work with JSON files:

\hypertarget{reading-json-files}{%
\subsection{Reading JSON Files}\label{reading-json-files}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ json}

\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}config.json\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    data }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ json.load(}\BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Parses JSON into a Python dictionary}
    
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(data[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{])}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(data[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}settings\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{][}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}theme\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{])}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{writing-json-files}{%
\subsection{Writing JSON Files}\label{writing-json-files}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ json}

\NormalTok{data }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}MyApp\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}version\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}1.0\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{,}
    \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}settings\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: \{}
        \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}theme\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}dark\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}notifications\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: }\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{,}
        \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}users\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Alice\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Bob\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Charlie\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{    \}}
\NormalTok{\}}

\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}config.json\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    json.dump(data, }\BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{, indent}\OperatorTok{=}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# indent for pretty formatting}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-14}{%
\section{10. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-14}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Which file mode would you use to add data to the end of an existing
  file?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}
  \item
    \texttt{\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{}}
  \item
    \texttt{\textquotesingle{}a\textquotesingle{}}
  \item
    \texttt{\textquotesingle{}x\textquotesingle{}}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What is the main advantage of using the \texttt{with} statement when
  working with files?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    It makes the code run faster
  \item
    It automatically closes the file even if an error occurs
  \item
    It allows you to open multiple files at once
  \item
    It compresses the file content
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which method reads the entire content of a file as a single string?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{file.readline()}
  \item
    \texttt{file.readlines()}
  \item
    \texttt{file.read()}
  \item
    \texttt{file.extract()}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What happens if you open a file in write mode
  (\texttt{\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{}}) that already exists?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Python raises an error
  \item
    The existing file is deleted and a new empty file is created
  \item
    Python appends to the existing file
  \item
    Python asks for confirmation before proceeding
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which module would you use to work with CSV files in Python?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{csv}
  \item
    \texttt{excel}
  \item
    \texttt{tabular}
  \item
    \texttt{data}
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers \& Feedback:} 1. c)
\texttt{\textquotesingle{}a\textquotesingle{}} --- Append mode adds new
content to the end of an existing file 2. b) It automatically closes the
file even if an error occurs --- This prevents resource leaks 3. c)
\texttt{file.read()} --- This method reads the entire file into memory
as a string 4. b) The existing file is deleted and a new empty file is
created --- Be careful with write mode! 5. a) \texttt{csv} --- Python's
built-in module for working with CSV files

\hypertarget{common-file-handling-pitfalls}{%
\section{11. Common File Handling
Pitfalls}\label{common-file-handling-pitfalls}}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Not closing files}: Always close files or use the
  \texttt{with} statement to avoid resource leaks
\item
  \textbf{Hardcoding file paths}: Use relative paths or \texttt{os.path}
  functions for more portable code
\item
  \textbf{Assuming file existence}: Check if a file exists before trying
  to read it
\item
  \textbf{Using the wrong mode}: Make sure to use the appropriate mode
  for your intended operation
\item
  \textbf{Loading large files into memory}: Use iterative approaches for
  large files to avoid memory issues
\item
  \textbf{Not handling encoding issues}: Specify the encoding when
  working with text files containing special characters
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{project-corner-persistent-chatbot-with-file-storage}{%
\section{Project Corner: Persistent Chatbot with File
Storage}\label{project-corner-persistent-chatbot-with-file-storage}}

Let's enhance our chatbot by adding the ability to save and load
conversations:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ datetime}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ random}

\CommentTok{\# Using dictionaries for response patterns}
\NormalTok{response\_patterns }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hi"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hey"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"howdy"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hola"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"see you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"cya"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"farewell"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"gratitude"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"thanks"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"thank you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"appreciate"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"bot\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"who are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"what are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"your name"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"user\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"how are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"what\textquotesingle{}s up"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"how do you feel"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{\}}

\NormalTok{response\_templates }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Hello there! How can I help you today?"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Hi! Nice to chat with you!"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Goodbye! Come back soon!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"See you later! Have a great day!"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"gratitude"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"You\textquotesingle{}re welcome!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Happy to help!"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"bot\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m PyBot, a simple chatbot built with Python!"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"user\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m functioning well, thanks for asking!"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{\}}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input):}
    \CommentTok{"""Get a response based on the user input."""}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower()}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Check each category of responses}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ category, patterns }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ response\_patterns.items():}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ patterns:}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
                \CommentTok{\# Return a random response from the appropriate category}
                \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ random.choice(response\_templates[category])}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Default response if no patterns match}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m still learning. Can you tell me more?"}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ save\_conversation():}
    \CommentTok{"""Save the current conversation to a file."""}
    \CommentTok{\# Create \textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{} directory if it doesn\textquotesingle{}t exist}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ os.path.exists(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{        os.makedirs(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Generate a unique filename with timestamp}
\NormalTok{    timestamp }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.datetime.now().strftime(}\StringTok{"\%Y\%m}\SpecialCharTok{\%d}\StringTok{\_\%H\%M\%S"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    filename }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"chats/chat\_with\_}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\_}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{timestamp}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{.txt"}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(filename, }\StringTok{"w"}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
            \CommentTok{\# Write header information}
\NormalTok{            f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Conversation with }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ and }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{            f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Date: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{datetime}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{datetime}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{now()}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{strftime(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\%Y{-}\%m{-}}\SpecialCharTok{\%d}\StringTok{ \%H:\%M:\%S\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            
            \CommentTok{\# Write each line of conversation}
            \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ entry }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ conversation\_history:}
\NormalTok{                f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{entry}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ filename}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Error saving conversation: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ load\_conversation(filename):}
    \CommentTok{"""Load a previous conversation from a file."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(filename, }\StringTok{"r"}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
\NormalTok{            lines }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ f.readlines()}
        
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{{-}{-}{-}{-}{-} Loaded Conversation {-}{-}{-}{-}{-}"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ line }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ lines:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(line.strip())}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{FileNotFoundError}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Sorry, I couldn\textquotesingle{}t find the file \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{filename}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}."}\NormalTok{)}
        \CommentTok{\# Show available files}
\NormalTok{        show\_available\_chats()}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"An error occurred: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ show\_available\_chats():}
    \CommentTok{"""Show a list of available saved conversations."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ os.path.exists(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{):}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"No saved conversations found."}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}
    
\NormalTok{    chat\_files }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ os.listdir(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ chat\_files:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"No saved conversations found."}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}
    
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{Available saved conversations:"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ i, chat\_file }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{enumerate}\NormalTok{(chat\_files, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{):}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{i}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{chat\_file}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{To load a conversation, type \textquotesingle{}load\textquotesingle{} followed by the filename."}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Main chat loop}
\NormalTok{bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. Type \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to exit."}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Special commands:"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-} \textquotesingle{}save\textquotesingle{}: Save the current conversation"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-} \textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{}: Show available saved conversations"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-} \textquotesingle{}load \textless{}filename\textgreater{}\textquotesingle{}: Load a conversation"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{conversation\_history }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ save\_to\_history(speaker, text):}
    \CommentTok{"""Save an utterance to conversation history."""}
\NormalTok{    conversation\_history.append(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{speaker}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Save initial greeting}
\NormalTok{save\_to\_history(bot\_name, }\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    save\_to\_history(user\_name, user\_input)}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Check for special commands}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        save\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}
        \ControlFlowTok{break}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"save"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        filename }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ save\_conversation()}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Conversation saved to }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{filename}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        save\_to\_history(bot\_name, }\SpecialStringTok{f"Conversation saved to }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{filename}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{continue}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"chats"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        show\_available\_chats()}
        \ControlFlowTok{continue}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower().startswith(}\StringTok{"load "}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{        filename }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input[}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{:].strip()}
\NormalTok{        load\_conversation(filename)}
        \ControlFlowTok{continue}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Get and display response}
\NormalTok{    response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    save\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

With these enhancements, our chatbot can now: 1. Save conversations to
text files with timestamps 2. Load and display previous conversations 3.
List available saved conversation files 4. Organize saved chats in a
dedicated directory

This makes the chatbot more useful, as you can review past interactions
and continue conversations later.

\textbf{Challenges}: - Add a feature to save conversations in JSON
format - Implement automatic periodic saving - Create a settings file
that remembers user preferences - Add the ability to search through
saved conversations for specific keywords - Implement a feature to pick
up a conversation where it left off

\hypertarget{real-world-file-applications}{%
\section{Real-World File
Applications}\label{real-world-file-applications}}

Files are fundamental to many programming tasks. Here are some common
real-world applications:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  \textbf{Configuration Files}: Store application settings in a format
  like JSON or INI.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ json}

\CommentTok{\# Load configuration}
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}config.json\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
\NormalTok{    config }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ json.load(f)}

\CommentTok{\# Use configuration}
\NormalTok{theme }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ config[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}theme\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Data Processing}: Read, process, and write large datasets.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Process a CSV file line by line}
\ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}large\_data.csv\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ input\_file:}
    \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}processed\_data.csv\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ output\_file:}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ line }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ input\_file:}
\NormalTok{            processed\_line }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ process\_line(line)  }\CommentTok{\# Your processing function}
\NormalTok{            output\_file.write(processed\_line)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Logging}: Keep track of program execution and errors.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ log\_event(message):}
    \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}app.log\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}a\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ log\_file:}
\NormalTok{        timestamp }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.datetime.now().strftime(}\StringTok{"\%Y{-}\%m{-}}\SpecialCharTok{\%d}\StringTok{ \%H:\%M:\%S"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        log\_file.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{timestamp}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{message}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{User Data Storage}: Save user preferences, history, or created
  content.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ save\_user\_profile(username, profile\_data):}
\NormalTok{    filename }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"users/}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{username}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{.json"}
\NormalTok{    os.makedirs(os.path.dirname(filename), exist\_ok}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(filename, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
\NormalTok{        json.dump(profile\_data, f)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{Caching}: Store results of expensive operations for future
  use.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ json}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_data(query, use\_cache}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{    cache\_file }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"cache/}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{query}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{replace(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{} \textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\_\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{.json"}

    \CommentTok{\# Check for cached result}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ use\_cache }\KeywordTok{and}\NormalTok{ os.path.exists(cache\_file):}
        \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(cache\_file, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ json.load(f)}

    \CommentTok{\# Perform expensive operation}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ expensive\_operation(query)}

    \CommentTok{\# Cache the result}
\NormalTok{    os.makedirs(os.path.dirname(cache\_file), exist\_ok}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(cache\_file, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
\NormalTok{        json.dump(result, f)}

    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ result}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\end{enumerate}

These examples illustrate how file operations are essential for creating
practical, real-world applications that persist data beyond a single
program execution.
