\hypertarget{learning-objectives-16}{%
\section{Learning Objectives}\label{learning-objectives-16}}

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: - Identify the main
types of errors in Python programs - Understand what exceptions are and
how they work - Write try/except blocks to handle runtime errors -
Handle specific exception types appropriately - Make your programs more
resilient to errors - Create user-friendly error messages - Apply
exception handling in practical applications

\hypertarget{introduction-when-things-go-wrong}{%
\section{1. Introduction: When Things Go
Wrong}\label{introduction-when-things-go-wrong}}

Even the most experienced programmers write code with errors. The
difference between novice and expert programmers isn't whether they make
mistakes---it's how they anticipate and handle those mistakes. In Python
(and most programming languages), errors generally fall into three
categories:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Syntax Errors}: Mistakes in the structure of your code that
  prevent it from running
\item
  \textbf{Runtime Errors}: Errors that occur while your program is
  running
\item
  \textbf{Logical Errors}: Your code runs but doesn't do what you expect
\end{enumerate}

This chapter focuses primarily on runtime errors and how Python's
exception handling system allows you to deal with them gracefully.

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: Ask your AI assistant to analyze error messages
you encounter and explain them in simple terms, highlighting exactly
what went wrong and why.}}

\hypertarget{understanding-error-types}{%
\section{2. Understanding Error Types}\label{understanding-error-types}}

\hypertarget{syntax-errors}{%
\subsection{Syntax Errors}\label{syntax-errors}}

Syntax errors occur when you break Python's grammar rules. The Python
interpreter catches these when it tries to parse your code, preventing
your program from running at all.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Syntax error: missing closing parenthesis}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello, world!"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The Python interpreter would respond with something like:

\begin{verbatim}
  File "<stdin>", line 1
    print("Hello, world!"
                        ^
SyntaxError: unexpected EOF while parsing
\end{verbatim}

Syntax errors are usually easy to fix once you understand what's wrong.

\hypertarget{runtime-errors-exceptions}{%
\subsection{Runtime Errors
(Exceptions)}\label{runtime-errors-exceptions}}

Runtime errors, also called exceptions, occur during program execution.
Unlike syntax errors, the code is valid Python, but something goes wrong
when it runs. For example:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# This code is syntactically correct but will cause a runtime error}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}
\NormalTok{y }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ x }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ y  }\CommentTok{\# ZeroDivisionError}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When you run this, Python raises an exception:

\begin{verbatim}
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ZeroDivisionError: division by zero
\end{verbatim}

Common runtime errors include: - \texttt{ZeroDivisionError}: Trying to
divide by zero - \texttt{TypeError}: Performing an operation on
incompatible types - \texttt{ValueError}: Giving a function the right
type but invalid value - \texttt{IndexError}: Trying to access a
non-existent index in a sequence - \texttt{KeyError}: Trying to access a
non-existent key in a dictionary - \texttt{FileNotFoundError}: Trying to
open a file that doesn't exist - \texttt{NameError}: Using a variable
that hasn't been defined

\hypertarget{logical-errors}{%
\subsection{Logical Errors}\label{logical-errors}}

Logical errors are the trickiest to find. Your code runs without raising
exceptions, but it doesn't do what you expect. For example:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Logical error: calculating average incorrectly}
\NormalTok{scores }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{85}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{90}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{78}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{average }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(scores) }\OperatorTok{/} \DecValTok{4}  \CommentTok{\# Should be divided by 3 (the length of the list)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(average)  }\CommentTok{\# Returns 63.25 instead of 84.33}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This chapter focuses on runtime errors (exceptions). For help with
logical errors, see Chapter 17 on Debugging.

\hypertarget{pythons-exception-handling-try-and-except}{%
\section{3. Python's Exception Handling: try and
except}\label{pythons-exception-handling-try-and-except}}

Python provides a powerful mechanism for handling exceptions: the
\texttt{try}/\texttt{except} block. Here's the basic structure:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
    \CommentTok{\# Code that might cause an exception}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10} \OperatorTok{/} \DecValTok{0}
\ControlFlowTok{except}\NormalTok{:}
    \CommentTok{\# Code that runs if an exception occurs}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Something went wrong!"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The code inside the \texttt{try} block is executed. If an exception
occurs, Python immediately jumps to the \texttt{except} block, skipping
any remaining code in the \texttt{try} block.

\hypertarget{a-simple-example}{%
\subsection{A Simple Example}\label{a-simple-example}}

Let's explore a simple example to see how exception handling works:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Without exception handling}
\NormalTok{x }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10}
\NormalTok{y }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\CommentTok{\# result = x / y  \# Program crashes with ZeroDivisionError}

\CommentTok{\# With exception handling}
\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ x }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ y}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"The result is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{result}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{except}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Cannot divide by zero!"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Program continues executing..."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

In the first case, the program would crash. In the second case, it
captures the error, provides a useful message, and continues running.

\hypertarget{handling-specific-exceptions}{%
\section{4. Handling Specific
Exceptions}\label{handling-specific-exceptions}}

The previous example catches any exception, but it's usually better to
catch specific exception types. This allows different handling for
different errors:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    number }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter a number: "}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{100} \OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ number}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"100 divided by }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{number}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{result}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"That\textquotesingle{}s not a valid number!"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ZeroDivisionError}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You cannot divide by zero!"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

You can even catch multiple specific exceptions with a single handler:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
    \CommentTok{\# Code that might raise different exceptions}
    \CommentTok{\# ...}
\ControlFlowTok{except}\NormalTok{ (}\PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{, }\PreprocessorTok{TypeError}\NormalTok{):}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"There was a problem with the data type or value"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{capturing-exception-information}{%
\section{5. Capturing Exception
Information}\label{capturing-exception-information}}

Sometimes you want to display or log the actual error message. You can
capture the exception object using the \texttt{as} keyword:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
    \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"nonexistent\_file.txt"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"r"}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{FileNotFoundError} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ err:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Error: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{err}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \CommentTok{\# Could display: Error: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: \textquotesingle{}nonexistent\_file.txt\textquotesingle{}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This is especially useful for debugging or providing detailed feedback.

\hypertarget{the-else-and-finally-clauses}{%
\section{6. The else and finally
Clauses}\label{the-else-and-finally-clauses}}

Python's exception handling has two additional clauses:

\hypertarget{the-else-clause}{%
\subsection{The else Clause}\label{the-else-clause}}

The \texttt{else} clause runs if the \texttt{try} block completes
without an exception:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    number }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter a number: "}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{100} \OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ number}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"That\textquotesingle{}s not a valid number!"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ZeroDivisionError}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"You cannot divide by zero!"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \CommentTok{\# This runs only if no exceptions occurred}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"The result is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{result}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{the-finally-clause}{%
\subsection{The finally Clause}\label{the-finally-clause}}

The \texttt{finally} clause runs whether an exception occurred or not.
It's useful for cleanup operations:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{file} \OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"data.txt"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"r"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    content }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{FileNotFoundError}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"The file does not exist"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{finally}\NormalTok{:}
    \CommentTok{\# This runs regardless of what happened in the try block}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}file\textquotesingle{}} \KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{locals}\NormalTok{() }\KeywordTok{and} \KeywordTok{not} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.closed:}
        \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.close()}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"File closed successfully"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The \texttt{finally} block is excellent for ensuring resources like
files or network connections are properly closed.

\hypertarget{preventing-errors-vs.-handling-exceptions}{%
\section{7. Preventing Errors vs.~Handling
Exceptions}\label{preventing-errors-vs.-handling-exceptions}}

There are often two approaches to dealing with potential errors:

\hypertarget{lbyl-look-before-you-leap}{%
\subsection{LBYL (Look Before You
Leap)}\label{lbyl-look-before-you-leap}}

Check for potential problems before performing an operation:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# LBYL approach}
\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ divisor }\OperatorTok{!=} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ dividend }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ divisor}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Cannot divide by zero"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{eafp-easier-to-ask-forgiveness-than-permission}{%
\subsection{EAFP (Easier to Ask Forgiveness than
Permission)}\label{eafp-easier-to-ask-forgiveness-than-permission}}

Try the operation and handle any exceptions that occur:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# EAFP approach}
\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ dividend }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ divisor}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ZeroDivisionError}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Cannot divide by zero"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Python generally favors the EAFP approach (using try/except) as it's
usually cleaner and handles rare edge cases better. However, if checking
is simple and the exception would be common, LBYL might be more
appropriate.

\hypertarget{common-error-handling-patterns}{%
\section{8. Common Error Handling
Patterns}\label{common-error-handling-patterns}}

Here are some patterns you'll use frequently:

\hypertarget{input-validation-1}{%
\subsection{Input Validation}\label{input-validation-1}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_integer\_input(prompt):}
    \CommentTok{"""Keep asking until a valid integer is provided."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(prompt))}
        \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Please enter a valid integer."}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{safe-file-operations}{%
\subsection{Safe File Operations}\label{safe-file-operations}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ read\_file\_safely(filename):}
    \CommentTok{"""Attempt to read a file and handle potential errors."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(filename, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}r\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{file}\NormalTok{.read()}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{FileNotFoundError}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"The file \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{filename}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{} was not found."}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{None}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{PermissionError}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"You don\textquotesingle{}t have permission to read \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{filename}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}."}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{None}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"An unexpected error occurred: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{e}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{None}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{graceful-degradation}{%
\subsection{Graceful Degradation}\label{graceful-degradation}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_user\_profile(user\_id):}
    \CommentTok{"""Retrieve user data, falling back to defaults on errors."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Primary data source}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ database.get\_user(user\_id)}
    \ControlFlowTok{except}\NormalTok{ DatabaseError:}
        \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
            \CommentTok{\# Backup data source}
            \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ api.fetch\_user(user\_id)}
        \ControlFlowTok{except}\NormalTok{ APIError:}
            \CommentTok{\# Last resort {-} return default profile}
            \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{"name"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"Guest"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"access\_level"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"minimal"}\NormalTok{\}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-15}{%
\section{9. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-15}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  What is the main difference between a syntax error and an exception?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Syntax errors occur during runtime; exceptions occur during
    compilation
  \item
    Syntax errors occur during parsing; exceptions occur during runtime
  \item
    Syntax errors are always fatal; exceptions can be handled
  \item
    There is no difference; they are different terms for the same thing
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of the following is NOT a common exception type in Python?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{ValueError}
  \item
    \texttt{TypeError}
  \item
    \texttt{SyntaxError}
  \item
    \texttt{MemoryError}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What does the following code print if the user enters ``abc''?

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    num }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter a number: "}\NormalTok{))}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"You entered }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{num}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Not a valid number"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Valid input received"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    ``You entered abc'' followed by ``Valid input received''
  \item
    ``Not a valid number'' followed by ``Valid input received''
  \item
    ``Not a valid number''
  \item
    It raises an unhandled exception
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  In what order are the blocks executed in a try-except-else-finally
  statement when no exception occurs?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    try → except → else → finally
  \item
    try → else → except → finally
  \item
    try → else → finally
  \item
    try → finally → else
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What happens if an exception is raised in the \texttt{except} block of
  a try-except statement?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    The program crashes with an unhandled exception
  \item
    The exception is automatically handled
  \item
    The program continues executing as if nothing happened
  \item
    The \texttt{finally} block handles the new exception
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers \& Feedback:} 1. b) Syntax errors occur during parsing;
exceptions occur during runtime --- Syntax errors prevent your code from
running at all 2. c) \texttt{SyntaxError} --- While this is an error in
Python, it's not considered an exception that you can catch with
try/except 3. c) ``Not a valid number'' --- The else block only runs if
no exception occurs 4. c) try → else → finally --- When no exception
occurs, the except block is skipped 5. a) The program crashes with an
unhandled exception --- Exception handlers don't protect against errors
within themselves

\hypertarget{common-exception-handling-mistakes}{%
\section{10. Common Exception Handling
Mistakes}\label{common-exception-handling-mistakes}}

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Catching too broadly}: Using \texttt{except:} without
  specifying the exception type can catch unexpected errors
\item
  \textbf{Silencing errors}: Catching exceptions but not handling them
  properly can hide bugs
\item
  \textbf{Overusing try/except}: Using exception handling when simple
  conditionals would be clearer
\item
  \textbf{Forgetting cleanup}: Not using \texttt{finally} or
  \texttt{with} statements for resource management
\item
  \textbf{Raising generic exceptions}: Raising \texttt{Exception}
  instead of more specific types
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{project-corner-making-your-chatbot-robust-with-error-handling}{%
\section{Project Corner: Making Your Chatbot Robust with Error
Handling}\label{project-corner-making-your-chatbot-robust-with-error-handling}}

Let's enhance our chatbot to handle errors gracefully, focusing on file
operations:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ datetime}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ random}

\CommentTok{\# Response patterns and templates from Chapter 14}
\NormalTok{response\_patterns }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hi"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hey"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"howdy"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"see you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"cya"}\NormalTok{],}
    \CommentTok{\# other patterns...}
\NormalTok{\}}

\NormalTok{response\_templates }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Hello there!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Hi! Nice to chat with you!"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Goodbye! Come back soon!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"See you later!"}\NormalTok{],}
    \CommentTok{\# other templates...}
\NormalTok{\}}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input):}
    \CommentTok{"""Get a response based on the user input."""}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower()}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ category, patterns }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ response\_patterns.items():}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ patterns:}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
                \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ random.choice(response\_templates[category])}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m still learning. Can you tell me more?"}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ save\_conversation():}
    \CommentTok{"""Save the current conversation to a file with error handling."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Create the chats directory if it doesn\textquotesingle{}t exist}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ os.path.exists(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{            os.makedirs(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
        
\NormalTok{        timestamp }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.datetime.now().strftime(}\StringTok{"\%Y\%m}\SpecialCharTok{\%d}\StringTok{\_\%H\%M\%S"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        filename }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"chats/chat\_with\_}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\_}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{timestamp}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{.txt"}
        
        \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(filename, }\StringTok{"w"}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
\NormalTok{            f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Conversation with }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ and }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{            f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Date: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{datetime}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{datetime}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{now()}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{strftime(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\%Y{-}\%m{-}}\SpecialCharTok{\%d}\StringTok{ \%H:\%M:\%S\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            
            \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ entry }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ conversation\_history:}
\NormalTok{                f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{entry}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Conversation saved to }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{filename}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{PermissionError}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Sorry, I don\textquotesingle{}t have permission to save in that location."}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{OSError} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Error saving conversation: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"An unexpected error occurred: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ load\_conversation(filename):}
    \CommentTok{"""Load a previous conversation from a file with error handling."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Make sure the file is in the chats directory for security}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ filename.startswith(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chats/\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{            filename }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"chats/}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{filename}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
        
        \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(filename, }\StringTok{"r"}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
\NormalTok{            lines }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ f.readlines()}
        
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{{-}{-}{-}{-}{-} Loaded Conversation {-}{-}{-}{-}{-}"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ line }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ lines:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(line.strip())}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{FileNotFoundError}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Sorry, I couldn\textquotesingle{}t find the file \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{filename}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        show\_available\_chats()}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{PermissionError}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} I don\textquotesingle{}t have permission to read that file."}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{UnicodeDecodeError}\NormalTok{:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} That doesn\textquotesingle{}t appear to be a text file I can read."}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} An error occurred: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ show\_available\_chats():}
    \CommentTok{"""Show a list of available saved conversations with error handling."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ os.path.exists(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{):}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"No saved conversations found."}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{return}
        
\NormalTok{        chat\_files }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ os.listdir(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ chat\_files:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"No saved conversations found."}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{return}
        
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{Available saved conversations:"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ i, chat\_file }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{enumerate}\NormalTok{(chat\_files, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{):}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{i}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{chat\_file}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Error listing conversations: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_valid\_input(prompt, validation\_func}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{, error\_message}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{"""Repeatedly prompt the user until valid input is received."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(prompt)}
        
        \CommentTok{\# If no validation function was provided, any input is valid}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ validation\_func }\KeywordTok{is} \VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ user\_input}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Check if the input is valid}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ validation\_func(user\_input):}
            \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ user\_input}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Display error message and try again}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ error\_message:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(error\_message)}

\CommentTok{\# Main chat loop}
\NormalTok{bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. Type \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to exit."}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Special commands:"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-} \textquotesingle{}save\textquotesingle{}: Save the current conversation"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-} \textquotesingle{}chats\textquotesingle{}: Show available saved conversations"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-} \textquotesingle{}load \textless{}filename\textgreater{}\textquotesingle{}: Load a conversation"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Get user name with validation}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ is\_valid\_name(name):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(name.strip()) }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0}

\NormalTok{user\_name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_valid\_input(}
    \StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{,}
\NormalTok{    is\_valid\_name,}
    \StringTok{"Name cannot be empty. Please enter your name."}
\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{conversation\_history }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ save\_to\_history(speaker, text):}
    \CommentTok{"""Save an utterance to conversation history."""}
\NormalTok{    conversation\_history.append(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{speaker}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Save initial greeting}
\NormalTok{save\_to\_history(bot\_name, }\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
    \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        save\_to\_history(user\_name, user\_input)}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Check for special commands}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            response }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{            save\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}
            \ControlFlowTok{break}
            
        \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"save"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ save\_conversation()}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{result}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{            save\_to\_history(bot\_name, result)}
            \ControlFlowTok{continue}
            
        \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"chats"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            show\_available\_chats()}
            \ControlFlowTok{continue}
            
        \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower().startswith(}\StringTok{"load "}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{            filename }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input[}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{:].strip()}
\NormalTok{            load\_conversation(filename)}
            \ControlFlowTok{continue}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Get and display response}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_response(user\_input)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        save\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}
        
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{KeyboardInterrupt}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Handle Ctrl+C gracefully}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Conversation interrupted. Goodbye!"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{break}
        
    \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
        \CommentTok{\# Catch{-}all for unexpected errors to prevent program crashes}
\NormalTok{        error\_msg }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"I encountered an error: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{error\_msg}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        save\_to\_history(bot\_name, error\_msg)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This enhanced chatbot includes:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Error handling for file operations (saving/loading)
\item
  A validation function for user input
\item
  Graceful handling of keyboard interrupts (Ctrl+C)
\item
  Security measures for file access
\item
  A catch-all exception handler to prevent crashes
\item
  Informative error messages
\end{enumerate}

These improvements make the chatbot more robust and user-friendly. When
problems occur, the program doesn't crash - it provides helpful
information and continues running.

\textbf{Challenges}: - Add a log file that records errors for later
review - Implement a system to recover from the last successful state
after an error - Create more specific exception types for different
chatbot-related errors - Add a ``debug mode'' that provides more
detailed error information - Create a validation system for all user
commands

\hypertarget{error-handling-in-the-real-world}{%
\section{Error Handling in the Real
World}\label{error-handling-in-the-real-world}}

Effective error handling is a hallmark of professional-quality code.
Here are some real-world approaches:

\hypertarget{logging-instead-of-printing}{%
\subsection{Logging Instead of
Printing}\label{logging-instead-of-printing}}

In production applications, errors are typically logged rather than
printed:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ logging}

\CommentTok{\# Configure logging}
\NormalTok{logging.basicConfig(}
\NormalTok{    filename}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}app.log\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{,}
\NormalTok{    level}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{logging.ERROR,}
    \BuiltInTok{format}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\%(asctime)s}\StringTok{ {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\%(name)s}\StringTok{ {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\%(levelname)s}\StringTok{ {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\%(message)s}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}
\NormalTok{)}

\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
    \CommentTok{\# Risky code here}
\NormalTok{    result }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{10} \OperatorTok{/} \DecValTok{0}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
    \CommentTok{\# Log the error with traceback information}
\NormalTok{    logging.exception(}\StringTok{"An error occurred during calculation"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{custom-exception-classes}{%
\subsection{Custom Exception Classes}\label{custom-exception-classes}}

For complex applications, custom exceptions can make error handling more
specific:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ InsufficientFundsError(}\PreprocessorTok{Exception}\NormalTok{):}
    \CommentTok{"""Raised when a bank account has insufficient funds for a withdrawal."""}
    
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, account, amount, balance):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.account }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ account}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.amount }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ amount}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.balance }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ balance}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.deficit }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ amount }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ balance}
        \BuiltInTok{super}\NormalTok{().}\FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Cannot withdraw $}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{amount}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ from account }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{account}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. Balance: $}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{balance}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, deficit: $}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{deficit}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Using the custom exception}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ withdraw(account\_id, amount):}
\NormalTok{    balance }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ get\_account\_balance(account\_id)}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ balance }\OperatorTok{\textless{}}\NormalTok{ amount:}
        \ControlFlowTok{raise}\NormalTok{ InsufficientFundsError(account\_id, amount, balance)}
    \CommentTok{\# Process withdrawal if sufficient funds}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{error-recovery-strategies}{%
\subsection{Error Recovery Strategies}\label{error-recovery-strategies}}

Robust systems need strategies for recovering from errors:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Retry with backoff}: When temporary failures occur (like
  network issues)
\item
  \textbf{Fallback to alternatives}: When a primary method fails, try a
  backup
\item
  \textbf{Graceful degradation}: Continue with limited functionality
  rather than failing completely
\item
  \textbf{Checkpointing}: Save progress frequently so you can recover
  from the last good state
\item
  \textbf{Circuit breakers}: Stop trying operations that consistently
  fail
\end{enumerate}

By implementing these strategies, you can create Python programs that
not only handle errors gracefully but also recover from them
effectively---a key skill for developing reliable software.

\hypertarget{debugging-detectives-finding-and-fixing-code-mysteries}{%
\chapter{Debugging Detectives: Finding and Fixing Code
Mysteries}\label{debugging-detectives-finding-and-fixing-code-mysteries}}

\hypertarget{chapter-17-debugging---finding-and-fixing-code-mysteries}{%
\chapter{Chapter 17: Debugging - Finding and Fixing Code
Mysteries}\label{chapter-17-debugging---finding-and-fixing-code-mysteries}}
