\hypertarget{learning-objectives-17}{%
\section{Learning Objectives}\label{learning-objectives-17}}

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: - Understand the
debugging mindset and process - Use print statements to inspect your
program's state - Apply systematic debugging techniques to find errors -
Recognize and fix common bug patterns - Use Python's built-in debugging
tools - Apply debugging strategies for different types of errors -
Develop habits that prevent bugs in your code

\hypertarget{introduction-the-art-of-debugging}{%
\section{1. Introduction: The Art of
Debugging}\label{introduction-the-art-of-debugging}}

Every programmer, from beginner to expert, writes code with bugs.
Debugging is the process of finding and fixing these errors, and it's a
crucial skill that often separates novice programmers from experienced
ones. As software pioneer Brian Kernighan said:

\begin{quote}
``Debugging is twice as hard as writing the code in the first place.
Therefore, if you write the code as cleverly as possible, you are, by
definition, not smart enough to debug it.''
\end{quote}

In the previous chapter, we looked at how to handle runtime errors
(exceptions) that Python detects and reports. In this chapter, we'll
focus on a more challenging type of error: logical errors where the code
runs without crashing but doesn't produce the expected results.

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: When you're stuck on a bug, explain your code line
by line to your AI assistant. The process of explaining often helps you
spot the issue yourself, a technique known as ``rubber duck
debugging.''}}

\hypertarget{understanding-debugging-fundamentals}{%
\section{2. Understanding Debugging
Fundamentals}\label{understanding-debugging-fundamentals}}

\hypertarget{types-of-errors-revisited}{%
\subsection{Types of Errors Revisited}\label{types-of-errors-revisited}}

As a reminder, there are three main types of errors in programming:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Syntax Errors}: Code doesn't follow language rules (Python
  catches these automatically)
\item
  \textbf{Runtime Errors/Exceptions}: Code runs but fails during
  execution (covered in Chapter 16)
\item
  \textbf{Logical Errors/Bugs}: Code runs without errors but produces
  incorrect results
\end{enumerate}

Debugging primarily focuses on the third type, which is the most
challenging. These errors don't trigger exceptions but produce
unexpected or incorrect behaviors.

\hypertarget{the-debugging-mindset}{%
\subsection{The Debugging Mindset}\label{the-debugging-mindset}}

Effective debugging requires a particular mindset:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Be systematic}: Follow a methodical approach rather than
  making random changes
\item
  \textbf{Be curious}: Ask ``why'' repeatedly to get to the root cause
\item
  \textbf{Be patient}: Some bugs take time to find and fix
\item
  \textbf{Be scientific}: Form hypotheses, test them, and analyze
  results
\item
  \textbf{Be persistent}: Don't give up when the solution isn't
  immediately obvious
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{the-debugging-process}{%
\subsection{The Debugging Process}\label{the-debugging-process}}

A systematic debugging process typically follows these steps:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Reproduce the bug}: Find reliable steps to make the problem
  occur
\item
  \textbf{Isolate the problem}: Narrow down where the bug might be
\item
  \textbf{Inspect the state}: Examine variables and program flow
\item
  \textbf{Form a hypothesis}: Make an educated guess about the cause
\item
  \textbf{Test the fix}: Apply a solution and verify it works
\item
  \textbf{Review the code}: Look for similar issues elsewhere in your
  code
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{the-print-statement-your-first-debugging-tool}{%
\section{3. The Print Statement: Your First Debugging
Tool}\label{the-print-statement-your-first-debugging-tool}}

The simplest and often most effective debugging technique is using print
statements to see what's happening in your code:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(numbers):}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Input to calculate\_average: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{numbers}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    total }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Sum of numbers: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{total}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    average }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ total }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Calculated average: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{average}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ average}

\CommentTok{\# Bug: This will return the wrong average}
\NormalTok{scores }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{85}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{90}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{78}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{avg }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(scores)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Average score: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{avg}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Strategic print statements can reveal: - Input values (what data is the
function receiving?) - Intermediate values (what calculations are
happening?) - Output values (what is being returned?)

\hypertarget{enhancing-print-statements}{%
\subsection{Enhancing Print
Statements}\label{enhancing-print-statements}}

Make your print statements more useful by:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Include context in your print messages}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"DEBUG {-} calculate\_average() {-} received input: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{numbers}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Use visual separators for important information}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"="}\OperatorTok{*}\DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"CRITICAL VALUE:"}\NormalTok{, result)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"="}\OperatorTok{*}\DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Print variable types when values look correct but operations fail}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Value: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{value}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, Type: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{type}\NormalTok{(value)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{temporary-debugging-code}{%
\subsection{Temporary Debugging Code}\label{temporary-debugging-code}}

Remember to remove or comment out debugging print statements when you're
done:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(numbers):}
    \CommentTok{\# DEBUG print(f"Input: \{numbers\}")}
\NormalTok{    total }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
    \CommentTok{\# DEBUG print(f"Sum: \{total\}")}
\NormalTok{    average }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ total }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ average}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Adding \texttt{\#\ DEBUG} makes it easier to find and remove these
statements later.

\hypertarget{debugging-with-pythons-built-in-tools}{%
\section{4. Debugging with Python's Built-in
Tools}\label{debugging-with-pythons-built-in-tools}}

\hypertarget{the-pdb-module}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{The \texttt{pdb}
Module}{The pdb Module}}\label{the-pdb-module}}

Python includes a built-in debugger called \texttt{pdb} (Python
DeBugger) that lets you pause code execution and inspect variables:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ pdb}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(numbers):}
\NormalTok{    total }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
\NormalTok{    pdb.set\_trace()  }\CommentTok{\# Code execution pauses here}
\NormalTok{    average }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ total }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ average}

\NormalTok{scores }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{85}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{90}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{78}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{avg }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(scores)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

When the \texttt{set\_trace()} function runs, the program pauses and
gives you a special prompt where you can: - Inspect variable values -
Execute Python statements - Step through the code line by line -
Continue execution

\hypertarget{common-pdb-commands}{%
\subsection{Common pdb Commands}\label{common-pdb-commands}}

In the debugger prompt, you can use: - \texttt{p\ variable\_name} -
Print a variable's value - \texttt{n} - Execute the next line (step
over) - \texttt{s} - Step into a function call - \texttt{c} - Continue
execution until the next breakpoint - \texttt{q} - Quit the debugger -
\texttt{h} - Help on debugger commands

\hypertarget{using-breakpoints-in-python-3.7}{%
\subsection{Using Breakpoints in Python
3.7+}\label{using-breakpoints-in-python-3.7}}

In newer Python versions, you can use a simpler breakpoint function:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(numbers):}
\NormalTok{    total }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
    \BuiltInTok{breakpoint}\NormalTok{()  }\CommentTok{\# Equivalent to pdb.set\_trace()}
\NormalTok{    average }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ total }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ average}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{common-bug-patterns-and-how-to-find-them}{%
\section{5. Common Bug Patterns and How to Find
Them}\label{common-bug-patterns-and-how-to-find-them}}

\hypertarget{off-by-one-errors}{%
\subsection{Off-by-One Errors}\label{off-by-one-errors}}

These occur when your loop iterates one too many or too few times:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Bug: This only processes the first n{-}1 items}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ process\_items(items):}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ i }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{range}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(items) }\OperatorTok{{-}} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{):  }\CommentTok{\# Should be range(len(items))}
\NormalTok{        process\_item(items[i])}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\textbf{Debugging Tip}: Print loop indices and boundary values to check
iteration ranges.

\hypertarget{type-mismatches}{%
\subsection{Type Mismatches}\label{type-mismatches}}

These bugs happen when a value's type is different from what you expect:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Bug: user\_age from input() is a string, not an integer}
\NormalTok{user\_age }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter your age: "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{years\_until\_retirement }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{65} \OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ user\_age  }\CommentTok{\# TypeError: can\textquotesingle{}t subtract string}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\textbf{Debugging Tip}: Print both the value and type of suspicious
variables, e.g.,
\texttt{print(f"user\_age:\ \{user\_age\},\ type:\ \{type(user\_age)\}")}.

\hypertarget{logic-errors}{%
\subsection{Logic Errors}\label{logic-errors}}

Errors in the code's logic that give incorrect results:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Bug: Logic error in calculating average}
\NormalTok{scores }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\DecValTok{85}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{90}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{78}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{average }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(scores) }\OperatorTok{/} \DecValTok{4}  \CommentTok{\# Should divide by len(scores), which is 3}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\textbf{Debugging Tip}: Break complex expressions into smaller parts and
print each part.

\hypertarget{missing-initialization}{%
\subsection{Missing Initialization}\label{missing-initialization}}

Failing to initialize a variable before using it:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Bug: total is not initialized before the loop}
\CommentTok{\# total = 0  \# This line is missing}
\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ num }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ numbers:}
\NormalTok{    total }\OperatorTok{+=}\NormalTok{ num  }\CommentTok{\# NameError: name \textquotesingle{}total\textquotesingle{} is not defined}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\textbf{Debugging Tip}: Use print statements at the beginning of
functions to verify variable initialization.

\hypertarget{scope-issues}{%
\subsection{Scope Issues}\label{scope-issues}}

Using variables from the wrong scope:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_total(items):}
    \CommentTok{\# Bug: Trying to access a global variable that doesn\textquotesingle{}t exist}
    \CommentTok{\# or using a variable before defining it}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ items\_count }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ average\_price  }\CommentTok{\# NameError}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\textbf{Debugging Tip}: Print all variables used in a calculation to
verify they exist in the current scope.

\hypertarget{debugging-strategies-for-different-error-types}{%
\section{6. Debugging Strategies for Different Error
Types}\label{debugging-strategies-for-different-error-types}}

\hypertarget{strategy-for-logical-errors}{%
\subsection{Strategy for Logical
Errors}\label{strategy-for-logical-errors}}

When your code runs but gives incorrect results:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Add print statements} at key points to track variable values
\item
  \textbf{Compare expected vs.~actual values} at each step
\item
  \textbf{Check boundary conditions} (first iteration, last iteration,
  empty collections)
\item
  \textbf{Break down complex expressions} into simpler parts
\item
  \textbf{Test with simple inputs} where you can calculate the correct
  result by hand
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{strategy-for-intermittent-bugs}{%
\subsection{Strategy for Intermittent
Bugs}\label{strategy-for-intermittent-bugs}}

When bugs only appear sometimes:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Look for race conditions} or timing issues
\item
  \textbf{Check for random inputs or behaviors}
\item
  \textbf{Search for hidden dependencies} on external factors
\item
  \textbf{Add extensive logging} to capture the state when the bug
  occurs
\item
  \textbf{Try to make the bug reproducible} with specific inputs
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{strategy-for-it-worked-yesterday-bugs}{%
\subsection{Strategy for ``It Worked Yesterday''
Bugs}\label{strategy-for-it-worked-yesterday-bugs}}

When code that used to work suddenly breaks:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Review recent changes} to the code
\item
  \textbf{Check for changes in dependencies} or external resources
\item
  \textbf{Verify input data} hasn't changed
\item
  \textbf{Roll back changes} one by one to find the breaking change
\item
  \textbf{Look for environmental differences} between systems
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{debugging-in-practice-a-real-example}{%
\section{7. Debugging in Practice: A Real
Example}\label{debugging-in-practice-a-real-example}}

Let's debug a function with a problem:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ find\_highest\_scorer(student\_scores):}
\NormalTok{    highest\_score }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
\NormalTok{    highest\_scorer }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ student, score }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ student\_scores.items():}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ highest\_score:}
\NormalTok{            highest\_score }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ score}
\NormalTok{            highest\_scorer }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ student}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ highest\_scorer}

\CommentTok{\# Test case}
\NormalTok{scores }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{85}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Bob"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{92}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Charlie"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{78}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Diana"}\NormalTok{: }\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{\}}
\NormalTok{top\_student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ find\_highest\_scorer(scores)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"The highest scorer is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{top\_student}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Should be "Bob"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If we add a student with a negative score, we need to handle that case:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Bug: If all scores are negative, this function fails}
\NormalTok{scores }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{: }\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Bob"}\NormalTok{: }\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Charlie"}\NormalTok{: }\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{20}\NormalTok{\}}
\NormalTok{top\_student }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ find\_highest\_scorer(scores)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"The highest scorer is }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{top\_student}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Should be "Bob" but returns None}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{debugging-the-example}{%
\subsection{Debugging the Example}\label{debugging-the-example}}

Let's add print statements to investigate:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ find\_highest\_scorer(student\_scores):}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Scores received: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{student\_scores}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    highest\_score }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}  \CommentTok{\# Bug is here {-} this should be initialized differently}
\NormalTok{    highest\_scorer }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ student, score }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ student\_scores.items():}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Checking }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{student}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ with score }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{score}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Current highest: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{highest\_score}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ by }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{highest\_scorer}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ highest\_score:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"New highest score found: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{score}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{            highest\_score }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ score}
\NormalTok{            highest\_scorer }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ student}
    
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Final highest scorer: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{highest\_scorer}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ with }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{highest\_score}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ highest\_scorer}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The output reveals our bug:

\begin{verbatim}
Scores received: {'Alice': -10, 'Bob': -5, 'Charlie': -20}
Checking Alice with score -10
Current highest: 0 by None
Checking Bob with score -5
Current highest: 0 by None
Checking Charlie with score -20
Current highest: 0 by None
Final highest scorer: None with 0
\end{verbatim}

The issue is that we initialized \texttt{highest\_score} to 0, but all
scores are negative, so none pass the
\texttt{score\ \textgreater{}\ highest\_score} check. Here's the fix:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ find\_highest\_scorer(student\_scores):}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ student\_scores:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{None}
        
    \CommentTok{\# Initialize with the first student\textquotesingle{}s score}
\NormalTok{    students }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{list}\NormalTok{(student\_scores.keys())}
\NormalTok{    highest\_scorer }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ students[}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{    highest\_score }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ student\_scores[highest\_scorer]}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ student, score }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ student\_scores.items():}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ score }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ highest\_score:}
\NormalTok{            highest\_score }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ score}
\NormalTok{            highest\_scorer }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ student}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ highest\_scorer}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-16}{%
\section{8. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-16}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  What is the primary difference between debugging and exception
  handling?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Debugging is for syntax errors; exception handling is for runtime
    errors
  \item
    Debugging is for finding errors; exception handling is for
    responding to known errors
  \item
    Debugging is a development activity; exception handling is a runtime
    activity
  \item
    All of the above
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of these is NOT a common debugging technique?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Adding print statements
  \item
    Using a debugger like pdb
  \item
    Adding try/except blocks
  \item
    Rubber duck debugging (explaining code to an inanimate object)
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  In the Python debugger (pdb), which command continues execution until
  the next breakpoint?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{n}
  \item
    \texttt{s}
  \item
    \texttt{c}
  \item
    \texttt{r}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What is an ``off-by-one'' error?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    A mathematical error where calculations are off by one unit
  \item
    A loop iteration error where the loop runs one too many or too few
    times
  \item
    An indexing error where you access the wrong element in a sequence
  \item
    All of the above
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What's the best first step when encountering a bug in your code?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Immediately start changing code to try to fix it
  \item
    Reproduce the bug with a simple, reliable test case
  \item
    Add print statements everywhere
  \item
    Ask someone else to fix it
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers \& Feedback:} 1. d) All of the above --- Debugging and
exception handling serve different purposes and occur at different times
2. c) Adding try/except blocks --- This is error handling, not debugging
3. c) \texttt{c} --- This continues execution until a breakpoint or the
program ends 4. d) All of the above --- Off-by-one errors can manifest
in various ways 5. b) Reproduce the bug with a simple, reliable test
case --- Always start by making sure you can reliably recreate the issue

\hypertarget{debugging-tools-beyond-print-statements}{%
\section{9. Debugging Tools Beyond Print
Statements}\label{debugging-tools-beyond-print-statements}}

\hypertarget{logging}{%
\subsection{Logging}\label{logging}}

For more sophisticated debugging, use Python's \texttt{logging} module:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ logging}

\CommentTok{\# Configure logging}
\NormalTok{logging.basicConfig(}
\NormalTok{    level}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{logging.DEBUG,}
    \BuiltInTok{format}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\%(asctime)s}\StringTok{ {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\%(name)s}\StringTok{ {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\%(levelname)s}\StringTok{ {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\%(message)s}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{,}
\NormalTok{    filename}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}debug.log\textquotesingle{}}
\NormalTok{)}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(numbers):}
\NormalTok{    logging.debug(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Calculate\_average called with }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{numbers}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ numbers:}
\NormalTok{        logging.warning(}\StringTok{"Empty list provided, returning 0"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \DecValTok{0}
        
\NormalTok{    total }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
\NormalTok{    logging.debug(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Sum calculated: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{total}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    average }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ total }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
\NormalTok{    logging.debug(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Average calculated: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{average}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ average}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Advantages of logging over print statements: - Log to a file instead of
the console - Use different severity levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING,
ERROR, CRITICAL) - Include timestamps and other metadata - Can be
enabled/disabled without removing code

\hypertarget{assertions}{%
\subsection{Assertions}\label{assertions}}

Use assertions to verify assumptions in your code:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(numbers):}
    \ControlFlowTok{assert} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers) }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Cannot calculate average of empty list"}
\NormalTok{    total }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
\NormalTok{    average }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ total }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ average}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If the condition after \texttt{assert} is False, Python raises an
\texttt{AssertionError} with the provided message.

\hypertarget{project-corner-debugging-your-chatbot}{%
\section{Project Corner: Debugging Your
Chatbot}\label{project-corner-debugging-your-chatbot}}

Let's apply debugging techniques to enhance our chatbot's reliability:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ random}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ logging}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ datetime}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}

\CommentTok{\# Configure logging}
\NormalTok{logging.basicConfig(}
\NormalTok{    level}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{logging.DEBUG,}
    \BuiltInTok{format}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\%(asctime)s}\StringTok{ {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\%(levelname)s}\StringTok{ {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\%(message)s}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{,}
\NormalTok{    filename}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chatbot\_debug.log\textquotesingle{}}
\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Response patterns}
\NormalTok{response\_patterns }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hi"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hey"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"howdy"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hola"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"see you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"cya"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"farewell"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"gratitude"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"thanks"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"thank you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"appreciate"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"bot\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"who are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"what are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"your name"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"user\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"how are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"what\textquotesingle{}s up"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"how do you feel"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{\}}

\NormalTok{response\_templates }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
    \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Hello there!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Hi! Nice to chat with you!"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Goodbye! Come back soon!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"See you later!"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"gratitude"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"You\textquotesingle{}re welcome!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Happy to help!"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"bot\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m PyBot, a simple chatbot built with Python!"}\NormalTok{],}
    \StringTok{"user\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m functioning well, thanks for asking!"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{\}}

\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ DebugChatbot:}
    \CommentTok{"""A chatbot with enhanced debugging capabilities."""}
    
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, name}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"PyBot"}\NormalTok{):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ name}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_patterns }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ response\_patterns}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_templates }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ response\_templates}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_mode }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{False}
\NormalTok{        logging.info(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Chatbot }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ initialized"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ toggle\_debug(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Toggle debug mode on/off."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_mode }\OperatorTok{=} \KeywordTok{not} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_mode}
\NormalTok{        status }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"ON"} \ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_mode }\ControlFlowTok{else} \StringTok{"OFF"}
\NormalTok{        logging.info(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Debug mode turned }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{status}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Debug mode is now }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{status}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ debug\_print(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, message):}
        \CommentTok{"""Print debug messages if debug mode is on."""}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_mode:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"DEBUG: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{message}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        logging.debug(message)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, user\_input):}
        \CommentTok{"""Generate a response with debugging information."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_print(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Processing input: \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_input}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}"}\NormalTok{)}
        
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_print(}\StringTok{"Empty input received"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I didn\textquotesingle{}t catch that. Could you please say something?"}
            
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower()}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_print(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Lowercase input: \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_input}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}"}\NormalTok{)}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Check if this is a debug command}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"debug"}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.toggle\_debug()}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Check each category of responses}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ category, patterns }\KeywordTok{in} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_patterns.items():}
            \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_print(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Checking category: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{category}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            
            \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ patterns:}
                \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
                    \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_print(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Pattern match found: \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{pattern}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}"}\NormalTok{)}
                    
                    \CommentTok{\# Get response templates for this category}
\NormalTok{                    templates }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_templates.get(category)}
                    \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_print(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Found }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(templates)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ possible responses"}\NormalTok{)}
                    
                    \CommentTok{\# Select a random response}
\NormalTok{                    response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ random.choice(templates)}
                    \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_print(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Selected response: \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}"}\NormalTok{)}
                    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ response}
        
        \CommentTok{\# No pattern matched}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_print(}\StringTok{"No pattern matches found"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m still learning. Can you tell me more?"}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ run(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Run the chatbot with error tracing."""}
        \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Hello! I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. Type \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to exit or \textquotesingle{}debug\textquotesingle{} to toggle debug mode."}\NormalTok{)}
            \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{            logging.info(}\SpecialStringTok{f"User identified as }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}
            
            \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.add\_to\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.name, }\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}
            
            \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
                \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{                    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{)}
                    \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.add\_to\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.user\_name, user\_input)}
                    
                    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"exit"}\NormalTok{]:}
\NormalTok{                        response }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}
                        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
                        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.add\_to\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.name, response)}
                        \ControlFlowTok{break}
                    
\NormalTok{                    response }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.get\_response(user\_input)}
                    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
                    \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.add\_to\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.name, response)}
                
                \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
\NormalTok{                    error\_msg }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Error in conversation loop: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
\NormalTok{                    logging.error(error\_msg, exc\_info}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)}
                    \ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_mode:}
                        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"DEBUG ERROR: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{error\_msg}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
                    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} Sorry, I encountered a problem. Let\textquotesingle{}s continue."}\NormalTok{)}
        
        \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
\NormalTok{            logging.critical(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Critical error in chatbot: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{, exc\_info}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Critical error: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Check the log file for details."}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add\_to\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, speaker, text):}
        \CommentTok{"""Add a message to conversation history with timestamp."""}
\NormalTok{        timestamp }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.datetime.now().strftime(}\StringTok{"\%H:\%M:\%S"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        entry }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
            \StringTok{"speaker"}\NormalTok{: speaker,}
            \StringTok{"text"}\NormalTok{: text,}
            \StringTok{"timestamp"}\NormalTok{: timestamp}
\NormalTok{        \}}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history.append(entry)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.debug\_print(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Added to history: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{entry}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Create and run the chatbot}
\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"\_\_main\_\_"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    chatbot }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ DebugChatbot()}
\NormalTok{    chatbot.run()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This enhanced chatbot includes:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Logging}: Records detailed information for later analysis
\item
  \textbf{Debug Mode}: Toggleable detailed output with the ``debug''
  command
\item
  \textbf{Error Handling}: Catches and logs exceptions without crashing
\item
  \textbf{Detailed Tracing}: Tracks the processing of each user input
\item
  \textbf{Structured History}: Stores conversations with timestamps
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Debugging Challenges}: - Add assertions to verify the integrity
of the conversation history - Implement a ``replay'' command that shows
the exact steps of how a response was generated - Create a ``why''
command that explains why the bot gave a particular response - Add more
detailed logging for file operations - Create a visual representation of
the chatbot's decision tree

\hypertarget{cross-references-16}{%
\section{Cross-References}\label{cross-references-16}}

  \protect\hyperlink{error-embassy-understanding-and-handling-exceptions-with-grace}{Errors

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: When debugging, describe your expectations, what
actually happened, and the code you're working with to your AI
assistant. It can often spot patterns and suggest debugging approaches
you might not have considered.}}

\hypertarget{preventing-bugs-the-best-debugging-is-no-debugging}{%
\section{Preventing Bugs: The Best Debugging is No
Debugging}\label{preventing-bugs-the-best-debugging-is-no-debugging}}

While debugging skills are essential, preventing bugs in the first place
is even better:

\hypertarget{write-clear-simple-code}{%
\subsection{Write Clear, Simple Code}\label{write-clear-simple-code}}

The more complex your code, the more places for bugs to hide:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Hard to debug}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{([x }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ x }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ data }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ x }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ threshold]) }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{([y }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ y }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ data }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ y }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{])}

\CommentTok{\# Easier to debug {-} break it down}
\NormalTok{valid\_values }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [x }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ x }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ data }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ x }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ threshold]}
\NormalTok{total }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(valid\_values)}
\NormalTok{positive\_count }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{([y }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ y }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ data }\ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ y }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{])}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ total }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ positive\_count}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{document-your-assumptions}{%
\subsection{Document Your Assumptions}\label{document-your-assumptions}}

Make implicit assumptions explicit through comments and assertions:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average(numbers):}
    \CommentTok{"""Calculate the average of a list of numbers.}
\CommentTok{    }
\CommentTok{    Args:}
\CommentTok{        numbers: A non{-}empty list of numeric values}
\CommentTok{        }
\CommentTok{    Returns:}
\CommentTok{        The arithmetic mean of the numbers}
\CommentTok{        }
\CommentTok{    Raises:}
\CommentTok{        ZeroDivisionError: If the input list is empty}
\CommentTok{    """}
    \CommentTok{\# Assumption: numbers is a non{-}empty list}
    \ControlFlowTok{assert} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers) }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"numbers list cannot be empty"}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(numbers) }\OperatorTok{/} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(numbers)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{write-tests}{%
\subsection{Write Tests}\label{write-tests}}

Testing (covered in the next chapter) helps you catch bugs early:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_calculate\_average():}
    \ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average([}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{2}
    \ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average([}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}
    \ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average([}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}
    \CommentTok{\# Test edge cases too}
    \ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ calculate\_average([}\DecValTok{1000000}\NormalTok{]) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{1000000}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{use-consistent-conventions}{%
\subsection{Use Consistent
Conventions}\label{use-consistent-conventions}}

Consistent code style reduces confusion and errors:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Consistent naming makes code more predictable}
\CommentTok{\# Variables in snake\_case}
\NormalTok{user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Alice"}
\NormalTok{total\_amount }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{100}

\CommentTok{\# Constants in UPPERCASE}
\NormalTok{MAX\_ATTEMPTS }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{3}
\NormalTok{DEFAULT\_TIMEOUT }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{30}

\CommentTok{\# Functions in snake\_case}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ calculate\_total(items):}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}

\CommentTok{\# Classes in CamelCase}
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ UserAccount:}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

By combining effective debugging techniques with preventative practices,
you'll find and fix bugs faster---and create fewer of them in the first
place. Remember that debugging is a skill that improves with practice,
so don't get discouraged when you encounter challenging bugs. Each one
you solve makes you a better programmer.

\hypertarget{test-kitchen-ensuring-your-code-works-as-intended}{%
\chapter{Test Kitchen: Ensuring Your Code Works as
Intended}\label{test-kitchen-ensuring-your-code-works-as-intended}}

\hypertarget{chapter-18-testing---ensuring-your-code-works-as-intended}{%
\chapter{Chapter 18: Testing - Ensuring Your Code Works as
Intended}\label{chapter-18-testing---ensuring-your-code-works-as-intended}}

\hypertarget{chapter-outline-18}{%
\section{Chapter Outline}\label{chapter-outline-18}}

\tightlist
