\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{learning-objectives-18}{%
\section{Learning Objectives}\label{learning-objectives-18}}

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: - Understand why
testing is crucial for reliable software - Create simple tests to verify
your code's functionality - Use assertions to check code behavior -
Write basic unit tests with Python's unittest framework - Apply
test-driven development principles - Know when and what to test -
Integrate testing into your development workflow

\hypertarget{introduction-why-test-your-code}{%
\section{1. Introduction: Why Test Your
Code?}\label{introduction-why-test-your-code}}

Imagine you're building a bridge. Would you let people drive across it
without first testing that it can hold weight? Of course not! The same
principle applies to software. Testing helps ensure your code works
correctly and continues to work as you make changes.

Testing provides several key benefits:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Bug detection}: Finds issues before your users do
\item
  \textbf{Prevention}: Prevents new changes from breaking existing
  functionality
\item
  \textbf{Documentation}: Shows how your code is meant to be used
\item
  \textbf{Design improvement}: Leads to more modular, testable code
\item
  \textbf{Confidence}: Gives you peace of mind when changing your code
\end{itemize}

Even for small programs, testing can save you time and frustration by
catching bugs early when they're easiest to fix.

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: When you're unsure what to test, ask your AI
assistant to suggest test cases for your function or class, including
edge cases you might not have considered.}}

\hypertarget{testing-fundamentals}{%
\section{2. Testing Fundamentals}\label{testing-fundamentals}}

Before diving into code, let's understand some basic testing concepts.

\hypertarget{types-of-tests}{%
\subsection{Types of Tests}\label{types-of-tests}}

There are several types of tests, each with a different purpose:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Unit tests}: Test individual components (functions, methods,
  classes) in isolation
\item
  \textbf{Integration tests}: Test how components work together
\item
  \textbf{Functional tests}: Test complete features or user workflows
\item
  \textbf{Regression tests}: Ensure new changes don't break existing
  functionality
\item
  \textbf{Performance tests}: Measure speed, resource usage, and
  scalability
\end{enumerate}

In this chapter, we'll focus primarily on unit tests, which are the
foundation of a good testing strategy.

\hypertarget{testing-vocabulary}{%
\subsection{Testing Vocabulary}\label{testing-vocabulary}}

Here are some key terms you'll encounter:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Test case}: A specific scenario being tested
\item
  \textbf{Test fixture}: Setup code that creates a consistent testing
  environment
\item
  \textbf{Test suite}: A collection of related test cases
\item
  \textbf{Assertion}: A statement that verifies a condition is true
\item
  \textbf{Mocking}: Replacing real objects with simulated ones for
  testing
\item
  \textbf{Test coverage}: The percentage of your code that's tested
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{simple-testing-with-assertions}{%
\section{3. Simple Testing with
Assertions}\label{simple-testing-with-assertions}}

The simplest form of testing uses assertions - statements that verify a
condition is true. If the condition is false, Python raises an
\texttt{AssertionError}.

Let's start with a simple function and test it:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ b}

\CommentTok{\# Test the function with assertions}
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ add(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{5}
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ add(}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ add(}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

If all assertions pass, you'll see no output. If one fails, you'll get
an error:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ add(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{5}  \CommentTok{\# This will fail}
\CommentTok{\# AssertionError}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{writing-effective-assertions}{%
\subsection{Writing Effective
Assertions}\label{writing-effective-assertions}}

Assertions should be:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Specific}: Test one thing at a time
\item
  \textbf{Descriptive}: Include a message explaining what's being tested
\item
  \textbf{Complete}: Cover normal cases, edge cases, and error cases
\end{enumerate}

Let's improve our assertions:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# More descriptive assertions}
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ add(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Basic positive number addition failed"}
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ add(}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Addition with negative number failed"}
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ add(}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Addition with zeros failed"}
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ add(}\FloatTok{0.1}\NormalTok{, }\FloatTok{0.2}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==}\NormalTok{ pytest.approx(}\FloatTok{0.3}\NormalTok{), }\StringTok{"Floating point addition failed"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{testing-more-complex-functions}{%
\subsection{Testing More Complex
Functions}\label{testing-more-complex-functions}}

Let's test a more complex function that calculates factorial:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ factorial(n):}
    \CommentTok{"""Calculate the factorial of n (n!)."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not} \BuiltInTok{isinstance}\NormalTok{(n, }\BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{) }\KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ n }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{raise} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Input must be a non{-}negative integer"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ n }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0} \KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ n }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \DecValTok{1}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ n }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ factorial(n }\OperatorTok{{-}} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Test normal cases}
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ factorial(}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Factorial of 0 should be 1"}
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ factorial(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Factorial of 1 should be 1"}
\ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ factorial(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{120}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Factorial of 5 should be 120"}

\CommentTok{\# Test error cases}
\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    factorial(}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{assert} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Should have raised ValueError for negative input"}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{:}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}  \CommentTok{\# This is expected}

\ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    factorial(}\FloatTok{1.5}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{assert} \VariableTok{False}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Should have raised ValueError for non{-}integer input"}
\ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{:}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}  \CommentTok{\# This is expected}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{structured-testing-with-unittest}{%
\section{4. Structured Testing with
unittest}\label{structured-testing-with-unittest}}

While assertions are useful for simple tests, Python provides the
\texttt{unittest} framework for more structured testing. Here's how to
use it:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ unittest}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ b}

\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ TestAddFunction(unittest.TestCase):}
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_positive\_numbers(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(add(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{), }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)}
        
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_negative\_numbers(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(add(}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{), }\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{)}
        
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_mixed\_numbers(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(add(}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{), }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)}
        
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_zeros(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(add(}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{), }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Run the tests}
\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\_\_main\_\_\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    unittest.main()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{unittest-assertions}{%
\subsection{unittest Assertions}\label{unittest-assertions}}

The \texttt{unittest} framework provides many assertion methods:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \texttt{assertEqual(a,\ b)}: Verify a equals b
\item
  \texttt{assertNotEqual(a,\ b)}: Verify a doesn't equal b
\item
  \texttt{assertTrue(x)}: Verify x is True
\item
  \texttt{assertFalse(x)}: Verify x is False
\item
  \texttt{assertIs(a,\ b)}: Verify a is b (same object)
\item
  \texttt{assertIsNot(a,\ b)}: Verify a is not b
\item
  \texttt{assertIsNone(x)}: Verify x is None
\item
  \texttt{assertIsNotNone(x)}: Verify x is not None
\item
  \texttt{assertIn(a,\ b)}: Verify a is in b
\item
  \texttt{assertNotIn(a,\ b)}: Verify a is not in b
\item
  \texttt{assertRaises(exception,\ callable,\ *args,\ **kwargs)}: Verify
  the function raises the exception
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{test-fixtures-with-setup-and-teardown}{%
\subsection{Test Fixtures with setUp and
tearDown}\label{test-fixtures-with-setup-and-teardown}}

When tests need common setup or cleanup, use the \texttt{setUp} and
\texttt{tearDown} methods:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ unittest}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}

\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ TestFileOperations(unittest.TestCase):}
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ setUp(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{\# This runs before each test}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.filename }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"test\_file.txt"}
        \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.filename, }\StringTok{"w"}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
\NormalTok{            f.write(}\StringTok{"Test content"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ tearDown(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{\# This runs after each test}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ os.path.exists(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.filename):}
\NormalTok{            os.remove(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.filename)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_file\_exists(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertTrue(os.path.exists(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.filename))}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_file\_content(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.filename, }\StringTok{"r"}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
\NormalTok{            content }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ f.read()}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(content, }\StringTok{"Test content"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{test-driven-development-tdd}{%
\section{5. Test-Driven Development
(TDD)}\label{test-driven-development-tdd}}

Test-Driven Development is a development methodology where you write
tests before writing the actual code. The process follows a cycle often
called ``Red-Green-Refactor'':

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Red}: Write a test for a feature that doesn't exist yet (the
  test will fail)
\item
  \textbf{Green}: Write just enough code to make the test pass
\item
  \textbf{Refactor}: Improve the code while keeping the tests passing
\end{enumerate}

Let's practice TDD by developing a function to check if a number is
prime:

\hypertarget{step-1-write-the-test-first}{%
\subsection{Step 1: Write the test
first}\label{step-1-write-the-test-first}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ unittest}

\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ TestPrimeChecker(unittest.TestCase):}
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_prime\_numbers(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that prime numbers return True."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertTrue(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertTrue(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertTrue(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertTrue(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertTrue(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{11}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertTrue(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{13}\NormalTok{))}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_non\_prime\_numbers(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that non{-}prime numbers return False."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertFalse(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# 1 is not considered prime}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertFalse(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertFalse(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{6}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertFalse(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{8}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertFalse(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{9}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertFalse(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{))}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_negative\_and\_zero(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that negative numbers and zero return False."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertFalse(is\_prime(}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertFalse(is\_prime(}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{))}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertFalse(is\_prime(}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{))}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{step-2-write-the-implementation}{%
\subsection{Step 2: Write the
implementation}\label{step-2-write-the-implementation}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ is\_prime(n):}
    \CommentTok{"""Check if a number is prime."""}
    \CommentTok{\# Handle special cases}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ n }\OperatorTok{\textless{}=} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Check for divisibility}
    \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ i }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{range}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\BuiltInTok{int}\NormalTok{(n}\OperatorTok{**}\FloatTok{0.5}\NormalTok{) }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{):}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ n }\OperatorTok{\%}\NormalTok{ i }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}
    
    \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{step-3-refactor-if-needed}{%
\subsection{Step 3: Refactor if
needed}\label{step-3-refactor-if-needed}}

Our implementation is already pretty efficient with the \texttt{n**0.5}
optimization, but we might add some comments or clearer variable names
if needed.

\hypertarget{benefits-of-tdd}{%
\subsection{Benefits of TDD}\label{benefits-of-tdd}}

TDD provides several benefits: - Clarifies requirements before coding -
Prevents over-engineering - Ensures all code is testable - Creates a
safety net for future changes - Leads to more modular design

\hypertarget{testing-strategies-what-and-when-to-test}{%
\section{6. Testing Strategies: What and When to
Test}\label{testing-strategies-what-and-when-to-test}}

\hypertarget{what-to-test}{%
\subsection{What to Test}\label{what-to-test}}

Focus on testing:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Core functionality}: The main features of your program
\item
  \textbf{Edge cases}: Boundary conditions where errors often occur
\item
  \textbf{Error handling}: How your code responds to invalid inputs
\item
  \textbf{Complex logic}: Areas with complex calculations or decisions
\item
  \textbf{Bug fixes}: When you fix a bug, write a test to prevent
  regression
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{when-to-test}{%
\subsection{When to Test}\label{when-to-test}}

Ideally, you should:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Write tests early}: Either before or alongside your
  implementation
\item
  \textbf{Run tests frequently}: After every significant change
\item
  \textbf{Automate testing}: Set up continuous integration if possible
\item
  \textbf{Update tests}: When requirements change, update tests first
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{best-practices-for-effective-testing}{%
\section{7. Best Practices for Effective
Testing}\label{best-practices-for-effective-testing}}

Here are some practical tips for writing good tests:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Keep tests small and focused}: Each test should verify one
  specific behavior
\item
  \textbf{Make tests independent}: Tests shouldn't depend on each other
\item
  \textbf{Use descriptive test names}: Names should explain what's being
  tested
\item
  \textbf{Organize tests logically}: Group related tests into classes or
  modules
\item
  \textbf{Test both positive and negative cases}: Check that errors are
  handled correctly
\item
  \textbf{Avoid testing implementation details}: Test behavior, not how
  it's implemented
\item
  \textbf{Automate tests}: Make them easy to run with a single command
\item
  \textbf{Maintain your tests}: Keep them up to date as your code
  evolves
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-17}{%
\section{8. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-17}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  What is the primary purpose of unit testing?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    To check how components work together
  \item
    To verify individual components work correctly in isolation
  \item
    To measure application performance
  \item
    To detect security vulnerabilities
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of the following is NOT an assertion method in unittest?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{assertEqual()}
  \item
    \texttt{assertTruthy()}
  \item
    \texttt{assertRaises()}
  \item
    \texttt{assertIn()}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  In Test-Driven Development (TDD), what is the correct order of steps?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Write code, test code, refactor code
  \item
    Write test, write code, refactor code
  \item
    Design interface, write test, write code
  \item
    Write code, refactor code, write test
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What happens when an assertion fails?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    The program continues running but logs a warning
  \item
    An AssertionError is raised
  \item
    The test is automatically skipped
  \item
    The program just stops silently
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which method in unittest runs before each test method?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{beforeEach()}
  \item
    \texttt{initialize()}
  \item
    \texttt{setUp()}
  \item
    \texttt{prepare()}
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers \& Feedback:} 1. b) To verify individual components work
correctly in isolation --- Unit tests focus on testing components in
isolation 2. b) \texttt{assertTruthy()} --- This is not a real unittest
method. JavaScript has \texttt{truthy} values, but Python has
\texttt{assertTrue()} 3. b) Write test, write code, refactor code ---
This is the classic Red-Green-Refactor cycle of TDD 4. b) An
AssertionError is raised --- Failed assertions raise exceptions that
stop execution 5. c) \texttt{setUp()} --- This method is automatically
called before each test method runs

\hypertarget{project-corner-testing-your-chatbot}{%
\section{Project Corner: Testing Your
Chatbot}\label{project-corner-testing-your-chatbot}}

Let's create tests for the core functionality of our chatbot:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ unittest}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ unittest.mock }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ patch}

\CommentTok{\# Import your chatbot or include minimal implementation for testing}
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ Chatbot:}
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, name}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"PyBot"}\NormalTok{):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ name}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_patterns }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
            \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hi"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hey"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"exit"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"commands"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"options"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{        \}}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_templates }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
            \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Hello there!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Hi! Nice to chat with you!"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Goodbye!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"See you later!"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Here are my commands..."}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"I can help with..."}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"default"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m not sure about that."}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Can you tell me more?"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{        \}}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, user\_input):}
        \CommentTok{"""Generate a response based on user input."""}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I didn\textquotesingle{}t catch that. Can you try again?"}
            
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower()}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Check each category of responses}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ category, patterns }\KeywordTok{in} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_patterns.items():}
            \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ patterns:}
                \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
                    \CommentTok{\# In a real implementation, you might pick randomly}
                    \CommentTok{\# but for testing, we\textquotesingle{}ll use the first template}
                    \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_templates[category][}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{]}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Default response if no patterns match}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_templates[}\StringTok{"default"}\NormalTok{][}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{]}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add\_to\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, speaker, text):}
        \CommentTok{"""Add a message to conversation history."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history.append(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{speaker}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history)}

\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ TestChatbot(unittest.TestCase):}
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ setUp(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Create a fresh chatbot for each test."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Chatbot(name}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"TestBot"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_initialization(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that chatbot initializes with correct default values."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.name, }\StringTok{"TestBot"}\NormalTok{)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertIsNone(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.user\_name)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.conversation\_history), }\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertIn(}\StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{, }\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.response\_patterns)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertIn(}\StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{, }\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.response\_templates)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_greeting\_response(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that chatbot responds to greetings."""}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.get\_response(}\StringTok{"hello there"}\NormalTok{)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(response, }\StringTok{"Hello there!"}\NormalTok{)}
        
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.get\_response(}\StringTok{"HI everyone"}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Testing case insensitivity}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(response, }\StringTok{"Hello there!"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_farewell\_response(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that chatbot responds to farewells."""}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.get\_response(}\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(response, }\StringTok{"Goodbye!"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_default\_response(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that chatbot gives default response for unknown input."""}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.get\_response(}\StringTok{"blah blah random text"}\NormalTok{)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(response, }\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m not sure about that."}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_empty\_input(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that chatbot handles empty input."""}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.get\_response(}\StringTok{""}\NormalTok{)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(response, }\StringTok{"I didn\textquotesingle{}t catch that. Can you try again?"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_conversation\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that messages are added to conversation history."""}
\NormalTok{        initial\_length }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.conversation\_history)}
\NormalTok{        new\_length }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.add\_to\_history(}\StringTok{"User"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Test message"}\NormalTok{)}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Check that length increased by 1}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(new\_length, initial\_length }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Check that message was added correctly}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.conversation\_history[}\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{], }\StringTok{"User: Test message"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_multiple\_patterns\_in\_input(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that chatbot handles input with multiple patterns."""}
        \CommentTok{\# If input contains both greeting and farewell, it should match the first one found}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.chatbot.get\_response(}\StringTok{"hello and goodbye"}\NormalTok{)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertEqual(response, }\StringTok{"Hello there!"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Run the tests}
\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\_\_main\_\_\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    unittest.main()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This test suite verifies: 1. Proper initialization of the chatbot 2.
Correct responses to different types of input 3. Handling of empty input
4. Conversation history functionality 5. Pattern matching behavior

\hypertarget{mock-testing}{%
\subsection{Mock Testing}\label{mock-testing}}

For features like saving to files or API calls, we can use mocks:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ TestChatbotWithMocks(unittest.TestCase):}
    \AttributeTok{@patch}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}builtins.open\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, new\_callable}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{unittest.mock.mock\_open)}
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_save\_conversation(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, mock\_open):}
        \CommentTok{"""Test that conversation is saved to a file."""}
\NormalTok{        chatbot }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Chatbot()}
\NormalTok{        chatbot.add\_to\_history(}\StringTok{"User"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Hello"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        chatbot.add\_to\_history(}\StringTok{"Bot"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Hi there!"}\NormalTok{)}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Call the save method}
\NormalTok{        chatbot.save\_conversation(}\StringTok{"test\_file.txt"}\NormalTok{)}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Check that open was called with the right file}
\NormalTok{        mock\_open.assert\_called\_once\_with(}\StringTok{"test\_file.txt"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"w"}\NormalTok{)}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Check what was written to the file}
\NormalTok{        written\_data }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{.join(call.args[}\DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{] }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ call }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ mock\_open().write.call\_args\_list)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertIn(}\StringTok{"User: Hello"}\NormalTok{, written\_data)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.assertIn(}\StringTok{"Bot: Hi there!"}\NormalTok{, written\_data)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\textbf{Challenges}: - Create tests for your chatbot's file handling
operations - Test the response generation with various input patterns -
Add tests for error handling and edge cases - Create a test suite that
covers all core functionality - Implement a continuous integration
system that runs tests automatically

Test coverage measures how much of your code is executed during tests:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Install coverage (pip install coverage)}

\hypertarget{property-based-testing}{%
\subsection{Property-Based Testing}\label{property-based-testing}}

Instead of specific test cases, property-based testing checks that
properties hold for all inputs:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Using the hypothesis library}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ hypothesis }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ given}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ hypothesis }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ strategies }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ st}

\AttributeTok{@given}\NormalTok{(st.integers(), st.integers())}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ test\_addition\_commutative(a, b):}
    \CommentTok{"""Test that a + b == b + a for all integers."""}
    \ControlFlowTok{assert}\NormalTok{ add(a, b) }\OperatorTok{==}\NormalTok{ add(b, a)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{behavior-driven-development-bdd}{%
\subsection{Behavior-Driven Development
(BDD)}\label{behavior-driven-development-bdd}}

BDD uses natural language to describe tests, making them accessible to
non-programmers:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Using pytest{-}bdd}
\CommentTok{"""}
\CommentTok{Feature: Chatbot responses}
\CommentTok{  Scenario: User greets the chatbot}
\CommentTok{    When the user says "hello"}
\CommentTok{    Then the chatbot should respond with a greeting}
\CommentTok{"""}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

These advanced testing practices help teams build robust, maintainable
software. As your projects grow in complexity, you may find it valuable
to incorporate some of these techniques into your workflow.

\hypertarget{introduction-the-power-of-modular-code}{%
\section{1. Introduction: The Power of Modular
Code}\label{introduction-the-power-of-modular-code}}

One of Python's greatest strengths is summed up in the phrase
``batteries included.'' This means Python comes with a rich standard
library containing modules for a wide range of tasks. Beyond that, a
vast ecosystem of third-party packages extends Python's capabilities
even further.

But what exactly are modules and packages, and why should you care about
them?

A \textbf{module} is simply a Python file containing code that can be
imported and reused. A \textbf{package} is a collection of related
modules organized in directories. Together, they enable several crucial
benefits:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Reuse}: Write code once, use it in multiple projects
\item
  \textbf{Organization}: Structure large codebases logically
\item
  \textbf{Maintenance}: Update code in one place that's used everywhere
\item
  \textbf{Collaboration}: Teams can work on different modules
  simultaneously
\item
  \textbf{Abstraction}: Use sophisticated functionality without
  understanding every detail
\end{itemize}

As your programs grow more complex, proper modularization becomes
essential for managing that complexity. It's like building with LEGO®
blocks instead of sculpting from a single block of clay---modular code
is easier to build, modify, and repair.

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: When you're stuck solving a problem, ask your AI
assistant ``Is there a Python module in the standard library that
handles {[}your task{]}?'' You might discover that the solution already
exists!}}

\hypertarget{importing-modules-the-import-statement}{%
\section{\texorpdfstring{2. Importing Modules: The \texttt{import}
Statement}{2. Importing Modules: The import Statement}}\label{importing-modules-the-import-statement}}

Python provides several ways to import modules using the \texttt{import}
statement. Let's explore each approach from most recommended to least
recommended.

\hypertarget{explicit-module-import}{%
\subsection{2.1 Explicit Module Import}\label{explicit-module-import}}

The standard way to import a module is with a simple \texttt{import}
statement. This preserves the module's content in its own namespace,
accessed with dot notation:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ math}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ math.cos(math.pi)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(result)  }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: {-}1.0}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This approach is preferred because it: - Makes it clear where functions
and variables come from - Avoids namespace conflicts with your own code
- Keeps your global namespace clean

\hypertarget{explicit-module-import-with-alias}{%
\subsection{2.2 Explicit Module Import with
Alias}\label{explicit-module-import-with-alias}}

For modules with longer names, it's common to use aliases for
convenience:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ numpy }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ np}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ np.cos(np.pi)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(result)  }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: {-}1.0}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This pattern is especially common for frequently used libraries like: -
\texttt{numpy} as \texttt{np} - \texttt{pandas} as \texttt{pd} -
\texttt{matplotlib.pyplot} as \texttt{plt} - \texttt{tensorflow} as
\texttt{tf}

\hypertarget{explicit-import-of-module-contents}{%
\subsection{2.3 Explicit Import of Module
Contents}\label{explicit-import-of-module-contents}}

Sometimes you may want to import specific items from a module directly
into your namespace:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ math }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ cos, pi}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ cos(pi)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(result)  }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: {-}1.0}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This makes your code more concise but has some drawbacks: - It's less
clear where functions come from - Potential name conflicts if different
modules have functions with the same name - May cause confusion when
reading unfamiliar code

\hypertarget{implicit-import-of-module-contents-use-sparingly}{%
\subsection{2.4 Implicit Import of Module Contents (Use
Sparingly!)}\label{implicit-import-of-module-contents-use-sparingly}}

Python also allows importing everything from a module:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ math }\ImportTok{import} \OperatorTok{*}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ sin(pi)}\OperatorTok{**}\DecValTok{2} \OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ cos(pi)}\OperatorTok{**}\DecValTok{2}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(result)  }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: 1.0}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This approach should be used sparingly because:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  It makes your code less readable by hiding where functions come from
\item
  It can cause unexpected name conflicts and overwrite built-in
  functions
\end{enumerate}

Here's an example of what can go wrong:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Python\textquotesingle{}s built{-}in sum function}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{range}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{), }\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: 9}
\CommentTok{\# This sums numbers 0{-}4, starting from {-}1}

\CommentTok{\# After importing everything from numpy}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ numpy }\ImportTok{import} \OperatorTok{*}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{range}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{), }\OperatorTok{{-}}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: 10}
\CommentTok{\# The meaning changed! Now {-}1 refers to the axis parameter}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This happens because \texttt{numpy.sum} replaces Python's built-in
\texttt{sum} function, and they have different parameters. This type of
subtle bug can be difficult to track down.

\hypertarget{exploring-pythons-standard-library}{%
\section{3. Exploring Python's Standard
Library}\label{exploring-pythons-standard-library}}

Python's standard library is a treasure trove of useful modules for
common tasks. Here are some especially valuable modules to know about:

\hypertarget{essential-standard-library-modules}{%
\subsection{Essential Standard Library
Modules}\label{essential-standard-library-modules}}

\begin{itemize}
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{os} and \texttt{sys}}: Operating system interfaces,
  file paths, and system information

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}

\CommentTok{\# Get current directory}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(os.getcwd())}

\CommentTok{\# List files in a directory}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(os.listdir(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}.\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{))}

\CommentTok{\# Join path components properly}
\NormalTok{path }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ os.path.join(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}folder\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}subfolder\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}file.txt\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{math} and \texttt{cmath}}: Mathematical functions for
  real and complex numbers

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ math}

\CommentTok{\# Basic mathematical operations}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(math.sqrt(}\DecValTok{16}\NormalTok{))     }\CommentTok{\# Square root: 4.0}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(math.factorial(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)) }\CommentTok{\# 5!: 120}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(math.gcd(}\DecValTok{24}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{36}\NormalTok{))  }\CommentTok{\# Greatest common divisor: 12}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{random}}: Generate random numbers and make random
  selections

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ random}

\CommentTok{\# Random integer between 1 and 10}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(random.randint(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{))}

\CommentTok{\# Random choice from a list}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(random.choice([}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}apple\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}banana\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}cherry\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]))}

\CommentTok{\# Shuffle a list in place}
\NormalTok{cards }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}ace\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}king\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}queen\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}jack\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{random.shuffle(cards)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(cards)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{datetime}}: Working with dates and times

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ datetime }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ datetime, timedelta}

\CommentTok{\# Current date and time}
\NormalTok{now }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.now()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(now)}

\CommentTok{\# Adding time}
\NormalTok{tomorrow }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ now }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ timedelta(days}\OperatorTok{=}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(tomorrow)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{json} and \texttt{csv}}: Working with common data
  formats

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ json}

\CommentTok{\# Parse JSON}
\NormalTok{data }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\{"name": "John", "age": 30\}\textquotesingle{}}
\NormalTok{person }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ json.loads(data)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(person[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{])  }\CommentTok{\# John}

\CommentTok{\# Convert Python object to JSON}
\NormalTok{new\_json }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ json.dumps(\{}\StringTok{"city"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"New York"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"population"}\NormalTok{: }\DecValTok{8400000}\NormalTok{\})}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(new\_json)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{re}}: Regular expressions for text pattern matching

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ re}

\CommentTok{\# Find all email addresses in text}
\NormalTok{text }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Contact us at support@example.com or info@example.org"}
\NormalTok{emails }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ re.findall(}\VerbatimStringTok{r\textquotesingle{}\textbackslash{}b[A{-}Za{-}z0{-}9.\_\%+{-}]+@[A{-}Za{-}z0{-}9.{-}]+\textbackslash{}.[A{-}Z|a{-}z]\{2,\}\textbackslash{}b\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, text)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(emails)  }\CommentTok{\# [\textquotesingle{}support@example.com\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}info@example.org\textquotesingle{}]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{collections}}: Specialized container datatypes

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ collections }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ Counter}

\CommentTok{\# Count occurrences of elements}
\NormalTok{colors }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ [}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}red\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}blue\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}red\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}green\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}blue\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}blue\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{color\_counts }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Counter(colors)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(color\_counts)  }\CommentTok{\# Counter(\{\textquotesingle{}blue\textquotesingle{}: 3, \textquotesingle{}red\textquotesingle{}: 2, \textquotesingle{}green\textquotesingle{}: 1\})}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\item
  \textbf{\texttt{itertools}}: Functions for efficient iteration

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ itertools}

\CommentTok{\# Generate all combinations}
\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{list}\NormalTok{(itertools.combinations([}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{], }\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{))}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(result)  }\CommentTok{\# [(1, 2), (1, 3), (2, 3)]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}
\end{itemize}

This is just a small sample of what's available. The complete standard
library documentation is available at
\href{https://docs.python.org/3/library/}{Python's official
documentation}.

\hypertarget{using-third-party-packages}{%
\section{4. Using Third-Party
Packages}\label{using-third-party-packages}}

While the standard library is extensive, the Python ecosystem's true
power comes from third-party packages. These modules extend Python's
capabilities for specific domains like data science, web development,
machine learning, and more.

\hypertarget{finding-and-installing-packages}{%
\subsection{Finding and Installing
Packages}\label{finding-and-installing-packages}}

The standard repository for Python packages is the Python Package Index
(PyPI) at \url{https://pypi.org/}.

Python comes with a package installer called \texttt{pip} that makes it
easy to install packages from PyPI:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Basic installation}
\ExtensionTok{pip}\NormalTok{ install package\_name}

\CommentTok{\# Install specific version}
\ExtensionTok{pip}\NormalTok{ install package\_name==1.2.3}

\CommentTok{\# Upgrade existing package}
\ExtensionTok{pip}\NormalTok{ install }\AttributeTok{{-}{-}upgrade}\NormalTok{ package\_name}

\CommentTok{\# Install multiple packages}
\ExtensionTok{pip}\NormalTok{ install package1 package2 package3}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{popular-third-party-packages}{%
\subsection{Popular Third-Party
Packages}\label{popular-third-party-packages}}

Here are some widely-used third-party packages:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{NumPy}: Numerical computing with powerful array operations
\item
  \textbf{Pandas}: Data analysis and manipulation with DataFrame objects
\item
  \textbf{Matplotlib} and \textbf{Seaborn}: Data visualization
\item
  \textbf{Requests}: Simplified HTTP requests
\item
  \textbf{Flask} and \textbf{Django}: Web frameworks
\item
  \textbf{SQLAlchemy}: Database toolkit and ORM
\item
  \textbf{PyTorch} and \textbf{TensorFlow}: Machine learning frameworks
\item
  \textbf{Pillow}: Image processing
\item
  \textbf{Beautiful Soup}: HTML and XML parsing
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{virtual-environments}{%
\subsection{Virtual Environments}\label{virtual-environments}}

When working with third-party packages, it's best practice to use
virtual environments to isolate dependencies for different projects:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Create virtual environment}
\ExtensionTok{python} \AttributeTok{{-}m}\NormalTok{ venv myproject\_env}

\CommentTok{\# Activate environment (Windows)}
\ExtensionTok{myproject\_env\textbackslash{}Scripts\textbackslash{}activate}

\CommentTok{\# Activate environment (macOS/Linux)}
\BuiltInTok{source}\NormalTok{ myproject\_env/bin/activate}

\CommentTok{\# Install packages}
\ExtensionTok{pip}\NormalTok{ install numpy pandas matplotlib}

\CommentTok{\# Deactivate when done}
\ExtensionTok{deactivate}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This keeps your projects isolated, preventing package conflicts between
different projects.

\hypertarget{creating-your-own-modules}{%
\section{5. Creating Your Own Modules}\label{creating-your-own-modules}}

As your projects grow, you'll want to organize your code into reusable
modules. Creating a module is as simple as saving Python code in a
\texttt{.py} file.

\hypertarget{basic-module-creation}{%
\subsection{Basic Module Creation}\label{basic-module-creation}}

Let's create a simple module for calculator functions:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# calculator.py}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ b}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ subtract(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ b}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ multiply(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ b}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ divide(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ b }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{raise} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Cannot divide by zero"}\NormalTok{)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ b}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To use this module, import it like any other:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ calculator}

\NormalTok{result }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ calculator.add(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(result)  }\CommentTok{\# 15}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{module-scope-and-the-if-__name__-__main__-pattern}{%
\subsection{\texorpdfstring{Module Scope and the
\texttt{if\ \_\_name\_\_\ ==\ "\_\_main\_\_"}
Pattern}{Module Scope and the if \_\_name\_\_ == "\_\_main\_\_" Pattern}}\label{module-scope-and-the-if-__name__-__main__-pattern}}

Every Python module has a special variable called \texttt{\_\_name\_\_}.
When a module is run directly, \texttt{\_\_name\_\_} is set to
\texttt{"\_\_main\_\_"}. When imported, \texttt{\_\_name\_\_} is set to
the module's name.

This lets you include code that only runs when the module is executed
directly:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# calculator.py}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ b}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ subtract(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ b}

\CommentTok{\# More functions...}

\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"\_\_main\_\_"}\NormalTok{:}
    \CommentTok{\# This code only runs when calculator.py is executed directly}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Calculator module test"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"5 + 3 = }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{add(}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"10 {-} 4 = }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{subtract(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This pattern is useful for including test code or example usage in your
modules.

\hypertarget{creating-packages}{%
\subsection{Creating Packages}\label{creating-packages}}

A package is a directory containing multiple module files and a special
\texttt{\_\_init\_\_.py} file (which can be empty):

\begin{verbatim}
my_package/
    __init__.py
    module1.py
    module2.py
    subpackage/
        __init__.py
        module3.py
\end{verbatim}

The \texttt{\_\_init\_\_.py} file indicates that the directory should be
treated as a package. It can also contain initialization code that runs
when the package is imported.

To import from a package:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Import a specific module}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ my\_package.module1}

\CommentTok{\# Import a specific function}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ my\_package.module2 }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ some\_function}

\CommentTok{\# Import from a subpackage}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ my\_package.subpackage.module3 }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ another\_function}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{organizing-real-world-python-projects}{%
\section{6. Organizing Real-World Python
Projects}\label{organizing-real-world-python-projects}}

As your projects grow more complex, a clear organization becomes
crucial. Here's a common structure for medium-sized Python projects:

\begin{verbatim}
project_name/
    README.md
    LICENSE
    requirements.txt
    setup.py
    project_name/
        __init__.py
        main.py
        core/
            __init__.py
            module1.py
            module2.py
        utils/
            __init__.py
            helpers.py
    tests/
        __init__.py
        test_module1.py
        test_module2.py
    docs/
        documentation.md
    examples/
        example1.py
\end{verbatim}

This structure separates your core code, tests, documentation, and
examples, making the project easier to navigate and maintain.

\hypertarget{module-and-package-best-practices}{%
\section{7. Module and Package Best
Practices}\label{module-and-package-best-practices}}

Follow these guidelines for creating effective modules and packages:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Single Responsibility Principle}: Each module should have one
  primary purpose
\item
  \textbf{Clear Interfaces}: Provide well-documented functions with
  clear parameters and return values
\item
  \textbf{Avoid Side Effects}: Functions should not unexpectedly modify
  global state
\item
  \textbf{Limit Public API}: Use underscore prefixes
  (\texttt{\_function\_name}) for internal helper functions
\item
  \textbf{Include Documentation}: Add docstrings to explain what your
  modules and functions do
\item
  \textbf{Consider Dependency Direction}: Lower-level modules should not
  import higher-level ones
\item
  \textbf{Test Your Modules}: Create unit tests to ensure your modules
  work correctly
\item
  \textbf{Use Relative Imports}: Within packages, use relative imports
  (\texttt{.module} instead of \texttt{package.module})
\end{enumerate}

By following these practices, your code will be more maintainable,
reusable, and easier to understand.

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-18}{%
\section{8. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-18}}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  What's the preferred way to import the \texttt{random} module's
  \texttt{choice} function?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{import\ random.choice}
  \item
    \texttt{from\ random\ import\ choice}
  \item
    \texttt{import\ choice\ from\ random}
  \item
    \texttt{from\ random\ import\ *}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which statement is true about the \texttt{from\ math\ import\ *}
  import style?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    It's the recommended way to import mathematical functions
  \item
    It's efficient because it only imports what you need
  \item
    It should be used sparingly due to namespace pollution
  \item
    It makes your code more readable
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What is the purpose of the \texttt{\_\_init\_\_.py} file in a
  directory?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    It initializes the Python interpreter
  \item
    It marks the directory as a package
  \item
    It's required in every Python project folder
  \item
    It creates a new instance of each module
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which tool is commonly used to install third-party packages in Python?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{installer}
  \item
    \texttt{pip}
  \item
    \texttt{package}
  \item
    \texttt{pyinstall}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What does the \texttt{if\ \_\_name\_\_\ ==\ "\_\_main\_\_":} pattern
  allow you to do?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Make your module importable by other modules
  \item
    Run code only when the module is executed directly
  \item
    Define the main function of your program
  \item
    Check if your module has been imported correctly
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers \& Feedback:} 1. b)
\texttt{from\ random\ import\ choice} --- This is the proper syntax for
importing a specific function 2. c) It should be used sparingly due to
namespace pollution --- This style imports everything into your
namespace which can cause conflicts 3. b) It marks the directory as a
package --- This special file tells Python to treat the directory as a
package 4. b) \texttt{pip} --- pip is Python's package installer 5. b)
Run code only when the module is executed directly --- This pattern
distinguishes between direct execution and being imported

\hypertarget{project-corner-modularizing-your-chatbot}{%
\section{Project Corner: Modularizing Your
Chatbot}\label{project-corner-modularizing-your-chatbot}}

Now that you understand modules and packages, let's apply this knowledge
to our chatbot project. We'll organize the chatbot into a proper modular
structure:

\begin{verbatim}
chatbot/
    __init__.py
    main.py
    response_manager.py
    history_manager.py
    ui_manager.py
\end{verbatim}

Here's how we'll implement these modules:

\hypertarget{response_manager.py}{%
\subsection{response\_manager.py}\label{response_manager.py}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{"""Functions for generating chatbot responses."""}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ random}

\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ ResponseManager:}
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, bot\_name):}
        \CommentTok{"""Initialize with response patterns and templates."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ bot\_name}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_patterns }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
            \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hi"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hey"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"howdy"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hola"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"see you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"cya"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"farewell"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"gratitude"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"thanks"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"thank you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"appreciate"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"bot\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"who are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"what are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"your name"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"user\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"how are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"what\textquotesingle{}s up"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"how do you feel"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{        \}}
        
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_templates }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
            \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Hello, }\SpecialCharTok{\{user\_name\}}\StringTok{!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Hi there, }\SpecialCharTok{\{user\_name\}}\StringTok{!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Great to see you again!"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"Goodbye!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"See you later!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Until next time!"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"gratitude"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"You\textquotesingle{}re welcome!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Happy to help!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"No problem at all."}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"bot\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\SpecialStringTok{f"I\textquotesingle{}m }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{, your chatbot assistant!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m just a simple Python chatbot."}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"user\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m just a program, but I\textquotesingle{}m working well!"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m here and ready to chat!"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"default"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m not sure how to respond to that yet."}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Can you tell me more?"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Interesting, tell me more!"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{        \}}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, user\_input, user\_name):}
        \CommentTok{"""Generate a response to user input."""}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"I didn\textquotesingle{}t catch that. Could you try again?"}
            
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower()}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Check each category of responses}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ category, patterns }\KeywordTok{in} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_patterns.items():}
            \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ patterns:}
                \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ pattern }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
                    \CommentTok{\# Get a random response from the matching category}
\NormalTok{                    templates }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_templates[category]}
\NormalTok{                    response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ random.choice(templates)}
                    
                    \CommentTok{\# Format with user name if needed}
                    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ response.}\BuiltInTok{format}\NormalTok{(user\_name}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{user\_name)}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Default response if no patterns match}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ random.choice(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_templates[}\StringTok{"default"}\NormalTok{])}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{history_manager.py}{%
\subsection{history\_manager.py}\label{history_manager.py}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{"""Functions for managing conversation history."""}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ datetime}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ os}

\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ HistoryManager:}
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Initialize with empty history."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add\_to\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, speaker, text):}
        \CommentTok{"""Add a message to conversation history."""}
\NormalTok{        timestamp }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.datetime.now().strftime(}\StringTok{"\%H:\%M:\%S"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        entry }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"[}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{timestamp}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{] }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{speaker}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history.append(entry)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history)}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ show\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Return formatted conversation history."""}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"No conversation history yet."}
            
\NormalTok{        history }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{{-}{-}{-}{-}{-} Conversation History {-}{-}{-}{-}{-}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ entry }\KeywordTok{in} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history:}
\NormalTok{            history }\OperatorTok{+=} \SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{entry}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}
\NormalTok{        history }\OperatorTok{+=} \StringTok{"{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}"}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ history}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ save\_conversation(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, user\_name, bot\_name):}
        \CommentTok{"""Save conversation history to a file."""}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"No conversation to save."}
            
        \CommentTok{\# Create a timestamped filename}
\NormalTok{        timestamp }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.datetime.now().strftime(}\StringTok{"\%Y\%m}\SpecialCharTok{\%d}\StringTok{\_\%H\%M\%S"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        filename }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"chat\_with\_}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\_}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{timestamp}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{.txt"}
        
        \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(filename, }\StringTok{"w"}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
\NormalTok{                f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Conversation between }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ and }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{                f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Date: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{datetime}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{datetime}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{now()}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{strftime(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\%Y{-}\%m{-}}\SpecialCharTok{\%d}\StringTok{ \%H:\%M:\%S\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
                
                \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ entry }\KeywordTok{in} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history:}
\NormalTok{                    f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{entry}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Conversation saved to }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{filename}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
        \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Error saving conversation: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ load\_conversation(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, filename):}
        \CommentTok{"""Load a previous conversation from a file."""}
        \ControlFlowTok{try}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{with} \BuiltInTok{open}\NormalTok{(filename, }\StringTok{"r"}\NormalTok{) }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ f:}
\NormalTok{                content }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ f.read()}
            \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ content}
        \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{FileNotFoundError}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Could not find file: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{filename}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
        \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{Exception} \ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ e:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"Error loading conversation: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{str}\NormalTok{(e)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{ui_manager.py}{%
\subsection{ui\_manager.py}\label{ui_manager.py}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{"""Functions for user interface and interaction."""}

\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ UIManager:}
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, bot\_name):}
        \CommentTok{"""Initialize with bot name."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ bot\_name}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ display\_welcome(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Display welcome message."""}
\NormalTok{        welcome }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"""}
\SpecialStringTok{╔════════════════════════════════════════╗}
\SpecialStringTok{║ Welcome to }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{center(}\DecValTok{28}\NormalTok{)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ ║}
\SpecialStringTok{║                                        ║}
\SpecialStringTok{║  Type \textquotesingle{}help\textquotesingle{} for available commands    ║}
\SpecialStringTok{║  Type \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{} to exit the conversation   ║}
\SpecialStringTok{╚════════════════════════════════════════╝}
\SpecialStringTok{"""}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ welcome}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ display\_help(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, user\_name):}
        \CommentTok{"""Display help information."""}
\NormalTok{        help\_text }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"""}
\SpecialStringTok{Available Commands:}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} \textquotesingle{}help\textquotesingle{}: Display this help message}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} \textquotesingle{}history\textquotesingle{}: Show conversation history}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} \textquotesingle{}save\textquotesingle{}: Save this conversation to a file}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} \textquotesingle{}load [filename]\textquotesingle{}: Load a previous conversation}
\SpecialStringTok{{-} \textquotesingle{}bye\textquotesingle{}: End the conversation}

\SpecialStringTok{You can also just chat with me normally, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!}
\SpecialStringTok{"""}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ help\_text}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ format\_bot\_response(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, text):}
        \CommentTok{"""Format the bot\textquotesingle{}s response for display."""}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{bot\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{text}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}
    
    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ format\_user\_prompt(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, user\_name):}
        \CommentTok{"""Format the user\textquotesingle{}s input prompt."""}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}

\hypertarget{main.py}{%
\subsection{main.py}\label{main.py}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{"""Main chatbot interface."""}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ chatbot.response\_manager }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ ResponseManager}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ chatbot.history\_manager }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ HistoryManager}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ chatbot.ui\_manager }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ UIManager}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ run\_chatbot():}
    \CommentTok{"""Run the main chatbot program."""}
    \CommentTok{\# Initialize components}
\NormalTok{    bot\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"PyBot"}
\NormalTok{    response\_manager }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ ResponseManager(bot\_name)}
\NormalTok{    history\_manager }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ HistoryManager()}
\NormalTok{    ui\_manager }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ UIManager(bot\_name)}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Display welcome and get user name}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(ui\_manager.display\_welcome())}
\NormalTok{    user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Main interaction loop}
    \ControlFlowTok{while} \VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{:}
        \CommentTok{\# Get user input}
\NormalTok{        user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(ui\_manager.format\_user\_prompt(user\_name))}
\NormalTok{        history\_manager.add\_to\_history(user\_name, user\_input)}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Process commands}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            response }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Goodbye, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{! I hope to chat again soon."}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(ui\_manager.format\_bot\_response(response))}
\NormalTok{            history\_manager.add\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}
            \ControlFlowTok{break}
            
        \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ ui\_manager.display\_help(user\_name)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(response)}
            \ControlFlowTok{continue}
            
        \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"history"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ history\_manager.show\_history()}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(response)}
            \ControlFlowTok{continue}
            
        \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"save"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ history\_manager.save\_conversation(user\_name, bot\_name)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(ui\_manager.format\_bot\_response(response))}
\NormalTok{            history\_manager.add\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}
            \ControlFlowTok{continue}
            
        \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower().startswith(}\StringTok{"load "}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{            filename }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input[}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{:].strip()}
\NormalTok{            response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ history\_manager.load\_conversation(filename)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(response)}
            \ControlFlowTok{continue}
        
        \CommentTok{\# Get and display response for normal conversation}
\NormalTok{        response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ response\_manager.get\_response(user\_input, user\_name)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(ui\_manager.format\_bot\_response(response))}
\NormalTok{        history\_manager.add\_to\_history(bot\_name, response)}

\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"\_\_main\_\_"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    run\_chatbot()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{benefits-of-this-modular-design}{%
\section{Benefits of This Modular
Design}\label{benefits-of-this-modular-design}}

This modular organization offers several advantages:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Separation of Concerns}: Each module has a specific
  responsibility
\item
  \textbf{Readability}: Code is organized into logical units
\item
  \textbf{Maintainability}: Changes to one aspect don't affect others
\item
  \textbf{Testability}: Each module can be tested independently
\item
  \textbf{Reusability}: Modules can be reused in other projects
\item
  \textbf{Collaborative Development}: Multiple people can work on
  different modules
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{how-to-use-the-modular-chatbot}{%
\subsection{How to Use the Modular
Chatbot}\label{how-to-use-the-modular-chatbot}}

To run the chatbot with this modular structure:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Create the directory structure and files as shown above
\item
  Run \texttt{python\ -m\ chatbot.main} from the parent directory
\end{enumerate}

Try enhancing it further with: - Additional response patterns - More
sophisticated response generation - Integration with web APIs for
information - Natural language processing capabilities - Database
storage for conversation history
