\section{Real-World Applications of Python
Modules}\label{real-world-applications-of-python-modules}}

Python's modular design is key to its success in diverse fields:

\hypertarget{web-development}{%
\subsection{Web Development}\label{web-development}}

Frameworks like Django and Flask are built from modules for routing,
templates, databases, and more:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ flask }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ Flask, render\_template, request}

\NormalTok{app }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Flask(}\VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_}\NormalTok{)}

\AttributeTok{@app.route}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}/\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ home():}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ render\_template(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}index.html\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{data-science}{%
\subsection{Data Science}\label{data-science}}

Libraries like pandas make complex data operations simple:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ pandas }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ pd}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ matplotlib.pyplot }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ plt}

\CommentTok{\# Load and analyze data}
\NormalTok{df }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ pd.read\_csv(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}data.csv\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{df.groupby(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}category\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{).mean().plot(kind}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}bar\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{plt.show()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

TensorFlow and PyTorch provide modular building blocks for AI:

\NormalTok{    tf.keras.layers.Dense(}\DecValTok{128}\NormalTok{, activation}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}relu\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{),}
\NormalTok{    tf.keras.layers.Dense(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, activation}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}softmax\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{])}

\chapter{Orientating Your Objects: Building Digital Models of Real-World

\hypertarget{chapter-20-object-oriented-programming-in-python}{%
\chapter{Chapter 20: Object-Oriented Programming in
Python}\label{chapter-20-object-oriented-programming-in-python}}

\hypertarget{learning-objectives-20}{%
\section{Learning Objectives}\label{learning-objectives-20}}

By the end of this chapter, you will be able to: - Understand the
concept of objects and object-oriented programming - Design and
implement classes in Python - Create objects (instances) from classes -
Define and work with object attributes and methods - Apply encapsulation
in your code - Structure a program using object-oriented principles -
Apply object-oriented design to enhance your chatbot project

\hypertarget{introduction-what-are-objects}{%
\section{1. Introduction: What Are
Objects?}\label{introduction-what-are-objects}}

You've probably heard the term ``object'' in a programming context
before, but what does it really mean? Let's start by looking at some
real-world objects like pens, books, smartphones, and computers.

Objects come in different forms and shapes, but we can classify
different versions of the same item into categories or groups. It's why
you can go to a furniture store and recognize different items as chairs
even if they look very different from one another.

Our brains naturally recognize objects, notice commonalities between
them, collect information, and create mental representations for
categories. This cognitive process mirrors what we do in object-oriented
programming.

In programming, objects can be used to model entities from the real
world. Since programs are designed to work and be used in the real
world, it helps to mirror reality. Additionally, using objects is a
useful way of grouping related data and functionality together.

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: When designing classes, ask your AI assistant to
help you identify the essential attributes and behaviors that should be
included based on your problem description. It can help distinguish
between what's necessary and what's optional for your specific use
case.}}

\hypertarget{understanding-abstraction}{%
\section{2. Understanding Abstraction}\label{understanding-abstraction}}

Abstraction serves to hide complex mechanisms within an object, exposing
only the information that we need to interact with it. For example,
consider books - they all have titles, authors, covers, page counts,
binding types, genres, languages, topics, publishers, publication years,
and many other attributes.

However, for a specific programming problem, we want to abstract the
most relevant details. The important attributes will emerge from
requirements or discussions with clients. Let's say our client only
wants to track the title, author, number of pages, and publisher.

This selective focus on essential details is the heart of abstraction.
It allows us to:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Simplify complexity}: Focus only on what matters for the
  problem at hand
\item
  \textbf{Hide implementation details}: Users of our code don't need to
  know how it works internally
\item
  \textbf{Create clear interfaces}: Define how other code should
  interact with our objects
\end{enumerate}

In Python, abstraction is implemented through classes. A class serves as
a blueprint or template that defines what attributes and behaviors
objects of that type will have.

\hypertarget{designing-classes}{%
\section{3. Designing Classes}\label{designing-classes}}

To see how to design a class, let's continue with our book example.
We've identified a sample of information that could describe any book:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Title
\item
  Author
\item
  Number of pages
\item
  Publisher
\end{itemize}

These are attributes of books in real life. In Python classes, they're
also called attributes - essentially variables that belong to an object!

When designing a class, ask yourself:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  What data does this object need to store? (attributes)
\item
  What actions can this object perform? (methods)
\item
  How will other parts of my program interact with this object?
  (interface)
\end{enumerate}

Let's start designing our Book class.

\hypertarget{class-declaration}{%
\section{4. Class Declaration}\label{class-declaration}}

To declare a class in Python, we use the \texttt{class} keyword followed
by a custom name and a colon:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ Book:}
    \ControlFlowTok{pass}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The \texttt{pass} statement is a placeholder that does nothing - it's
used here because Python requires at least one statement in a class
definition. Later we'll replace it with meaningful code.

\begin{quote}
\textbf{What is \texttt{pass}?} In Python, the \texttt{pass} keyword is
a statement that does nothing - it's discarded during byte-compilation.
Though it seems useless, it's quite handy as a placeholder during
development when you want to define a structure but haven't implemented
the details yet.
\end{quote}

\hypertarget{class-naming-conventions}{%
\section{5. Class Naming Conventions}\label{class-naming-conventions}}

Similar to naming variables, class names must be descriptive and fully
spelled out (avoid abbreviations). However, instead of using
snake\_case, Python class names follow CamelCase convention - the first
letter of each word should be capitalized.

Examples: - Good: \texttt{Book}, \texttt{LibraryMember},
\texttt{ShoppingCart} - Not recommended: \texttt{book},
\texttt{libraryMember}, \texttt{shopping\_cart}

\hypertarget{attributes-and-the-constructor-method}{%
\section{6. Attributes and the Constructor
Method}\label{attributes-and-the-constructor-method}}

To create a class with attributes, we define what's called a constructor
method. In Python, this special method is named \texttt{\_\_init\_\_}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ Book:}
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, title, author, number\_of\_pages, publisher):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.title }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ title}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.author }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ author}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.number\_of\_pages }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ number\_of\_pages}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.publisher }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ publisher}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The \texttt{\_\_init\_\_} method is automatically called when a new
object is created. The first parameter is always \texttt{self}, which
represents the object being created. The other parameters are values
that must be provided when creating a new \texttt{Book} object.

Inside the method, we assign these values to object attributes using the
pattern \texttt{self.attribute\_name\ =\ value}. \#\# 7. Creating
Objects from Classes

Now that we've defined our \texttt{Book} class, what can we do with it?
A class is an abstract blueprint, but to use it, we need to create
concrete objects (also called instances).

When you're looking for a book, you don't just search for any ``book'' -
you want a specific one like ``Harry Potter'' or ``Python Crash
Course.'' Similarly, in programming, we need specific instances of our
classes.

To create an object from a class, we call the class name as if it were a
function:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{my\_book }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Book(}\StringTok{"Python for Business"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Michael Borck"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{321}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"OC"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This code: 1. Declares a variable named \texttt{my\_book} 2. Creates a
new \texttt{Book} object with the provided attributes 3. Assigns this
object to the \texttt{my\_book} variable

We've now instantiated an object of the \texttt{Book} class! We can
create as many different book objects as we need, each with its own set
of attributes.

\hypertarget{working-with-object-attributes}{%
\section{8. Working with Object
Attributes}\label{working-with-object-attributes}}

Once we have an object, we often need to access or modify its
attributes. In Python, we use dot notation for this:
\texttt{object\_name.attribute\_name}.

\hypertarget{accessing-attributes}{%
\subsection{Accessing Attributes}\label{accessing-attributes}}

To read an attribute's value:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_book.title)       }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: Python for Business}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_book.author)      }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: Michael Borck}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_book.number\_of\_pages)  }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: 321}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{modifying-attributes}{%
\subsection{Modifying Attributes}\label{modifying-attributes}}

To change an attribute's value:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{my\_book.title }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Coding in Python"}
\NormalTok{my\_book.author }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"James Borck"}
\NormalTok{my\_book.number\_of\_pages }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{10}  \CommentTok{\# Add 10 pages}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_book.title)       }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: Coding in Python}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_book.author)      }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: James Borck}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(my\_book.number\_of\_pages)  }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: 331}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Object attributes behave like variables - you can assign new values to
them, use them in expressions, and pass them to functions.

\hypertarget{adding-behavior-object-methods}{%
\section{9. Adding Behavior: Object
Methods}\label{adding-behavior-object-methods}}

So far, our objects can store data (attributes) but can't do anything.
Real-world objects have behaviors: books can be read, cars can be
driven, doors can be opened. In programming, we implement behaviors as
methods.

A method is simply a function that belongs to a class. Let's add a
\texttt{read\_book} method to our \texttt{Book} class:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ Book:}
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, title, author, number\_of\_pages, publisher):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.title }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ title}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.author }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ author}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.number\_of\_pages }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ number\_of\_pages}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.publisher }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ publisher}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ read\_book(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Reading }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ by }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{author}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

To call a method on an object, we use the same dot notation:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{my\_book }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Book(}\StringTok{"Python for Beginners"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"John Smith"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{250}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Tech Press"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{my\_book.read\_book()  }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: Reading Python for Beginners by John Smith}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Methods can also take parameters beyond \texttt{self}:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ Book:}
    \CommentTok{\# Constructor and other methods...}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ read\_pages(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, start\_page, end\_page):}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ start\_page }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{1} \KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ end\_page }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.number\_of\_pages:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Invalid page range!"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{return}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Reading pages }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{start\_page}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ to }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{end\_page}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ of }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Using this method:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{my\_book.read\_pages(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{25}\NormalTok{)  }\CommentTok{\# Outputs: Reading pages 10 to 25 of Python for Beginners}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Methods can also return values, just like regular functions:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ Book:}
    \CommentTok{\# Constructor and other methods...}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_reading\_time(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, reading\_speed}\OperatorTok{=}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Estimate reading time in minutes based on pages and reading speed."""}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.number\_of\_pages }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ reading\_speed}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Using this method:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{time }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ my\_book.get\_reading\_time()}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Estimated reading time: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{time}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ minutes"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{building-a-more-complete-book-class}{%
\section{10. Building a More Complete Book
Class}\label{building-a-more-complete-book-class}}

Let's bring everything together into a more useful \texttt{Book} class
with multiple attributes and methods:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ Book:}
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, title, author, number\_of\_pages, publisher, year}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{, genre}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{None}\NormalTok{):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.title }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ title}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.author }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ author}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.number\_of\_pages }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ number\_of\_pages}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.publisher }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ publisher}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.year }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ year}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.genre }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ genre}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_page }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{0}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.bookmarked\_pages }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ read\_to\_page(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, page):}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ page }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \DecValTok{1} \KeywordTok{or}\NormalTok{ page }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.number\_of\_pages:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Error: Page must be between 1 and }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{number\_of\_pages}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}

        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Reading }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ from page }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{current\_page }\OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{1}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ to page }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{page}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_page }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ page}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ bookmark\_current\_page(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_page }\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
            \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.bookmarked\_pages.append(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_page)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Bookmarked page }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{current\_page}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
        \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"No page to bookmark yet. Start reading first!"}\NormalTok{)}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_bookmarks(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.bookmarked\_pages}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_reading\_progress(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_page }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \DecValTok{0}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ (}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_page }\OperatorTok{/} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.number\_of\_pages) }\OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{100}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_info(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
\NormalTok{        info }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Title: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}
\NormalTok{        info }\OperatorTok{+=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Author: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{author}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}
\NormalTok{        info }\OperatorTok{+=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Pages: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{number\_of\_pages}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}
\NormalTok{        info }\OperatorTok{+=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Publisher: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{publisher}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}

        \ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.year:}
\NormalTok{            info }\OperatorTok{+=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Year: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{year}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.genre:}
\NormalTok{            info }\OperatorTok{+=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Genre: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{genre}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}

\NormalTok{        info }\OperatorTok{+=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Reading progress: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{get\_reading\_progress()}\SpecialCharTok{:.1f\}}\SpecialStringTok{\%"}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ info}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Now we can interact with our improved \texttt{Book} class:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Create a book}
\NormalTok{python\_book }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Book(}\StringTok{"Python Crash Course"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Eric Matthes"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{544}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"No Starch Press"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{2019}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Programming"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Get book info}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(python\_book.get\_info())}

\CommentTok{\# Read some pages}
\NormalTok{python\_book.read\_to\_page(}\DecValTok{50}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Bookmark the page}
\NormalTok{python\_book.bookmark\_current\_page()}

\CommentTok{\# Read more}
\NormalTok{python\_book.read\_to\_page(}\DecValTok{100}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Check progress}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Reading progress: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{python\_book}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{get\_reading\_progress()}\SpecialCharTok{:.1f\}}\SpecialStringTok{\%"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# View bookmarks}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Bookmarked pages: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{python\_book}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{get\_bookmarks()}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{encapsulation-bundling-data-and-methods}{%
\section{11. Encapsulation: Bundling Data and
Methods}\label{encapsulation-bundling-data-and-methods}}

You may have noticed how our \texttt{Book} class bundles together
related data (title, author, pages) with the methods that operate on
that data (\texttt{read\_to\_page}, \texttt{get\_reading\_progress}).
This bundling of data and methods is called \textbf{encapsulation}.

Encapsulation is a fundamental principle of object-oriented programming
that:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Organizes code}: Keeps related functionality together
\item
  \textbf{Hides complexity}: Exposes only what's necessary
\item
  \textbf{Protects data}: Controls how data can be accessed and modified
\item
  \textbf{Reduces dependencies}: Minimizes the impact of changes
\end{enumerate}

In our \texttt{Book} class, users don't need to know how reading
progress is calculated or how bookmarks are stored - they just call the
appropriate methods, and the implementation details are hidden.

\hypertarget{creating-a-library-management-system}{%
\section{12. Creating a Library Management
System}\label{creating-a-library-management-system}}

Let's extend our example to build a simple library management system.
This will show how objects can interact with each other:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ Library:}
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, name):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ name}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.books }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.members }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add\_book(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, book):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.books.append(book)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Added \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{book}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{} to }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ library"}\NormalTok{)}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add\_member(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, member):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.members.append(member)}
        \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Added }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{member}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ as a library member"}\NormalTok{)}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ search\_books(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, search\_term):}
\NormalTok{        results }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ book }\KeywordTok{in} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.books:}
            \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ (search\_term.lower() }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ book.title.lower() }\KeywordTok{or}
\NormalTok{                search\_term.lower() }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ book.author.lower()):}
\NormalTok{                results.append(book)}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ results}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_library\_info(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ Library has }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.books)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ books and }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.members)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ members"}


\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ LibraryMember:}
    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, name, member\_id):}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ name}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.member\_id }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ member\_id}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.borrowed\_books }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ borrow\_book(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, book, library):}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ book }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ library.books:}
            \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.borrowed\_books.append(book)}
\NormalTok{            library.books.remove(book)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ borrowed \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{book}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}
        \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Sorry, \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{book}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{} is not available"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ return\_book(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, book, library):}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ book }\KeywordTok{in} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.borrowed\_books:}
            \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.borrowed\_books.remove(book)}
\NormalTok{            library.books.append(book)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ returned \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{book}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{}"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{True}
        \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Error: \textquotesingle{}}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{book}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textquotesingle{} was not borrowed by }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{False}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_borrowed\_books(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ [book.title }\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ book }\KeywordTok{in} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.borrowed\_books]}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

And here's how we might use these classes:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Create books}
\NormalTok{book1 }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Book(}\StringTok{"Python Crash Course"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Eric Matthes"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{544}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"No Starch Press"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{book2 }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Book(}\StringTok{"Automate the Boring Stuff"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Al Sweigart"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{504}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"No Starch Press"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{book3 }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Book(}\StringTok{"Clean Code"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Robert Martin"}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{464}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Prentice Hall"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Create library}
\NormalTok{central\_library }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Library(}\StringTok{"Central"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Add books}
\NormalTok{central\_library.add\_book(book1)}
\NormalTok{central\_library.add\_book(book2)}
\NormalTok{central\_library.add\_book(book3)}

\CommentTok{\# Create and add members}
\NormalTok{alice }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ LibraryMember(}\StringTok{"Alice Smith"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"M001"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{bob }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ LibraryMember(}\StringTok{"Bob Johnson"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"M002"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{central\_library.add\_member(alice)}
\NormalTok{central\_library.add\_member(bob)}

\CommentTok{\# Search for books}
\NormalTok{python\_books }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ central\_library.search\_books(}\StringTok{"Python"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Found }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(python\_books)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ Python books:"}\NormalTok{)}
\ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ book }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ python\_books:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"{-} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{book}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{title}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ by }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{book}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{author}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Borrow and return books}
\NormalTok{alice.borrow\_book(book1, central\_library)}
\NormalTok{bob.borrow\_book(book2, central\_library)}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Alice\textquotesingle{}s borrowed books: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{alice}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{get\_borrowed\_books()}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Bob\textquotesingle{}s borrowed books: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bob}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{get\_borrowed\_books()}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{alice.return\_book(book1, central\_library)}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(central\_library.get\_library\_info())}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-19}{%
\section{13. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-19}}

Test your understanding of object-oriented programming in Python:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  What is a class in Python?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    A module containing functions
  \item
    A blueprint for creating objects
  \item
    A built-in data structure
  \item
    A type of loop structure
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What naming convention is used for Python classes?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    snake\_case (lowercase with underscores)
  \item
    camelCase (first word lowercase, subsequent words capitalized)
  \item
    PascalCase/CamelCase (each word capitalized)
  \item
    ALL\_CAPS (all uppercase with underscores)
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What is the purpose of the \texttt{\_\_init\_\_} method in a Python
  class?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    To initialize class variables
  \item
    To create a constructor for the class
  \item
    To define the methods available in the class
  \item
    To import required modules
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  How do you access an attribute of an object in Python?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    object{[}attribute{]}
  \item
    object-\textgreater attribute
  \item
    object.attribute
  \item
    attribute(object)
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What is encapsulation in object-oriented programming?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    The process of hiding implementation details
  \item
    The bundling of data and methods that operate on that data
  \item
    The ability of a class to inherit from another class
  \item
    The process of converting a class to an object
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers:} 1. b) A blueprint for creating objects 2. c)
PascalCase/CamelCase (each word capitalized) 3. b) To create a
constructor for the class 4. c) object.attribute 5. b) The bundling of
data and methods that operate on that data

\hypertarget{project-corner-enhancing-your-chatbot-with-object-oriented-design}{%
\section{14. Project Corner: Enhancing Your Chatbot with Object-Oriented
Design}\label{project-corner-enhancing-your-chatbot-with-object-oriented-design}}

Let's apply object-oriented principles to our chatbot project by
creating a well-organized class structure. This approach will make our
code more maintainable and extensible.

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ Chatbot:}
    \CommentTok{"""A simple chatbot that becomes smarter as you learn Python."""}

    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, name}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"PyBot"}\NormalTok{):}
        \CommentTok{"""Initialize the chatbot with a name and empty conversation history."""}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ name}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.user\_name }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{None}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.conversation\_history }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}
        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_patterns }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}
            \StringTok{"greetings"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"hello"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hi"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hey"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"howdy"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"hola"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"farewells"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"bye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"goodbye"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"see you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"cya"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"farewell"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"gratitude"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"thanks"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"thank you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"appreciate"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"bot\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"who are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"what are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"your name"}\NormalTok{],}
            \StringTok{"user\_questions"}\NormalTok{: [}\StringTok{"how are you"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"what\textquotesingle{}s up"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"how do you feel"}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{        \}}

        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.response\_templates }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ \{}

\NormalTok{        history }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{{-}{-}{-}{-}{-} Conversation History {-}{-}{-}{-}{-}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ save\_conversation(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}

\NormalTok{        timestamp }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ datetime.now().strftime(}\StringTok{"\%Y\%m}\SpecialCharTok{\%d}\StringTok{\_\%H\%M\%S"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{        filename }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"chat\_with\_}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\_}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{timestamp}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{.txt"}

\NormalTok{                f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Conversation between }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ and }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{                f.write(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Date: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{datetime}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{now()}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{strftime(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\%Y{-}\%m{-}}\SpecialCharTok{\%d}\StringTok{ \%H:\%M:\%S\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{            user\_input }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{user\_name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} "}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{                response }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.save\_conversation()}
                \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
                \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.add\_to\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.name, response)}

\NormalTok{            response }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.get\_response(user\_input)}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{\textgreater{} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
            \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.add\_to\_history(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.name, response)}

\hypertarget{extending-the-chatbot-with-inheritance}{%
\section{15. Extending the Chatbot with

Now that we have a solid object-oriented foundation, let's extend our

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ WeatherChatbot(Chatbot):}

\NormalTok{        temperatures }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{range}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{35}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{        condition }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ random.choice(conditions)}
\NormalTok{        temperature }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ random.choice(temperatures)}

\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ QuizChatbot(Chatbot):}

\NormalTok{            \{}
                \StringTok{"question"}\NormalTok{: }\StringTok{"What is the output of print(2 + 2)?"}\NormalTok{,}

                            \StringTok{"Converts to a list"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Creates a range"}\NormalTok{],}

\NormalTok{            \}}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ start\_quiz(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_next\_question(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{):}

Your score: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\VariableTok{self}\SpecialCharTok{.}\NormalTok{score}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{/}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.quiz\_questions)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}

\NormalTok{        q }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.quiz\_questions[}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_question]}
\NormalTok{        question\_text }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ q[}\StringTok{"question"}\NormalTok{] }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{"}

        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ i, option }\KeywordTok{in} \BuiltInTok{enumerate}\NormalTok{(q[}\StringTok{"options"}\NormalTok{]):}
\NormalTok{            question\_text }\OperatorTok{+=} \SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{i}\OperatorTok{+}\DecValTok{1}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{option}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\SpecialStringTok{"}

        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ question\_text }\OperatorTok{+} \StringTok{"}\CharTok{\textbackslash{}n}\StringTok{Type the number of your answer."}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ check\_answer(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, user\_input):}

            \ControlFlowTok{if} \DecValTok{0} \OperatorTok{\textless{}=}\NormalTok{ choice }\OperatorTok{\textless{}} \BuiltInTok{len}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.quiz\_questions[}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_question][}\StringTok{"options"}\NormalTok{]):}
\NormalTok{                selected }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.quiz\_questions[}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_question][}\StringTok{"options"}\NormalTok{][choice]}
            \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}

        \ControlFlowTok{except} \PreprocessorTok{ValueError}\NormalTok{:}

\NormalTok{            selected }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ user\_input}

\NormalTok{        correct }\OperatorTok{=} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.quiz\_questions[}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_question][}\StringTok{"answer"}\NormalTok{]}

        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ selected }\OperatorTok{==}\NormalTok{ correct:}
            \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.score }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}
\NormalTok{            result }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{"Correct! "}
        \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{            result }\OperatorTok{=} \SpecialStringTok{f"Incorrect. The correct answer is: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{correct}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{. "}

        \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.current\_question }\OperatorTok{+=} \DecValTok{1}

        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"start quiz"}\NormalTok{:}

\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{multiple-inheritance-and-method-override}{%
\section{16. Multiple Inheritance and Method
Override}\label{multiple-inheritance-and-method-override}}

Python supports multiple inheritance, allowing a class to inherit from
more than one parent class. Let's create a ``super'' chatbot that
combines both weather and quiz capabilities:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{class}\NormalTok{ SuperChatbot(WeatherChatbot, QuizChatbot):}
    \CommentTok{"""A chatbot that combines weather and quiz capabilities."""}

    \KeywordTok{def} \FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, name}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"SuperBot"}\NormalTok{):}
        \BuiltInTok{super}\NormalTok{().}\FunctionTok{\_\_init\_\_}\NormalTok{(name)}

    \KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_response(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, user\_input):}
        \CommentTok{"""Process responses with priority handling."""}
        \CommentTok{\# Handle quiz mode first if active}
        \ControlFlowTok{if} \BuiltInTok{hasattr}\NormalTok{(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}quiz\_active\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{) }\KeywordTok{and} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.quiz\_active:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.check\_answer(user\_input)}

        \CommentTok{\# Then check for special commands}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ user\_input.lower() }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"start quiz"}\NormalTok{:}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.start\_quiz()}

        \CommentTok{\# Then check for weather requests}
        \ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ re}
\NormalTok{        weather\_match }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ re.search(}\VerbatimStringTok{r\textquotesingle{}weather in (\textbackslash{}w+)\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, user\_input.lower())}
        \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ weather\_match:}
\NormalTok{            location }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ weather\_match.group(}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{)}
            \ControlFlowTok{return} \VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{.get\_weather(location)}

        \CommentTok{\# Finally, fall back to standard chatbot responses}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ Chatbot.get\_response(}\VariableTok{self}\NormalTok{, user\_input)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{object-oriented-benefits-for-our-chatbot}{%
\section{17. Object-Oriented Benefits for Our
Chatbot}\label{object-oriented-benefits-for-our-chatbot}}

This object-oriented approach provides several advantages:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Modularity}: Each class handles one aspect of functionality
\item
  \textbf{Extensibility}: New features can be added by creating new
  subclasses
\item
  \textbf{Code reuse}: Inheritance allows sharing common functionality
\item
  \textbf{Clarity}: The code is organized in a logical, structured way
\item
  \textbf{Maintenance}: Changes to one feature don't affect others
\item
  \textbf{Testability}: Each class can be tested independently
\end{enumerate}

These advantages become increasingly important as your projects grow in
complexity. Our chatbot can now be extended with new features simply by
creating new subclasses, without modifying the existing code.

\hypertarget{key-object-oriented-concepts-demonstrated}{%
\section{18. Key Object-Oriented Concepts
Demonstrated}\label{key-object-oriented-concepts-demonstrated}}

In our chatbot examples, we've demonstrated several important
object-oriented concepts:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Encapsulation}: Bundling data (attributes) and behaviors
  (methods) together
\item
  \textbf{Inheritance}: Creating specialized classes (WeatherChatbot,
  QuizChatbot) from a base class (Chatbot)
\item
  \textbf{Polymorphism}: Overriding methods (get\_response) to provide
  specialized behavior while maintaining the same interface
\item
  \textbf{Composition}: Building complex objects that contain other
  objects (Chatbot contains conversation history, response patterns,
  etc.)
\item
  \textbf{Method Override}: Customizing inherited behavior by providing
  a new implementation in the subclass
\item
  \textbf{Multiple Inheritance}: Combining features from multiple parent
  classes (SuperChatbot)
\end{enumerate}

\hypertarget{running-the-object-oriented-chatbot}{%
\section{19. Running the Object-Oriented
Chatbot}\label{running-the-object-oriented-chatbot}}

Let's see how we might run our object-oriented chatbot:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ main():}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Welcome to the Chatbot Selector!"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Choose a chatbot type:"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"1: Basic Chatbot"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"2: Weather{-}Aware Chatbot"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"3: Quiz Chatbot"}\NormalTok{)}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"4: Super Chatbot (Weather + Quiz)"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{    choice }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter your choice (1{-}4): "}\NormalTok{)}

    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ choice }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"2"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        bot }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ WeatherChatbot()}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ choice }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"3"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        bot }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ QuizChatbot()}
    \ControlFlowTok{elif}\NormalTok{ choice }\OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"4"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        bot }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ SuperChatbot()}
    \ControlFlowTok{else}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{        bot }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Chatbot()}

    \CommentTok{\# All chatbots use the same run method, but each will behave differently}
    \CommentTok{\# This is polymorphism in action!}
\NormalTok{    bot.run()}

\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"\_\_main\_\_"}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    main()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{further-enhancements}{%
\section{20. Further Enhancements}\label{further-enhancements}}

You can continue to extend this object-oriented chatbot with additional
features:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{VoiceChatbot}: A chatbot that can convert text to speech
\item
  \textbf{TranslatorChatbot}: A chatbot that can translate messages
  between languages
\item
  \textbf{RememberingChatbot}: A chatbot that remembers facts about the
  user
\item
  \textbf{MathChatbot}: A chatbot that can solve math problems
\item
  \textbf{JokeChatbot}: A chatbot that tells jokes
\end{enumerate}

Each of these can be implemented as a separate class that inherits from
the base Chatbot class, adding its own specialized functionality.

\hypertarget{learning-objectives-21}{%
\section{Learning Objectives}\label{learning-objectives-21}}

\hypertarget{introduction-many-ways-to-run-python}{%
\section{1. Introduction: Many Ways to Run
Python}\label{introduction-many-ways-to-run-python}}

One of Python's greatest strengths is its flexibility - there are
multiple ways to write and execute Python code depending on your
specific needs and preferences. Whether you're quickly testing an idea,
developing a complex application, or creating an interactive data
analysis, Python offers execution environments suited to each task.

Python is an \emph{interpreted} language, as opposed to a
\emph{compiled} language like C, Java, or Rust. This fundamental
characteristic makes Python highly interactive and accessible,
especially for beginners. Let's explore what this means and how it
shapes the ways you can run Python code.

\hypertarget{interpreted-vs.-compiled-languages}{%
\section{2. Interpreted vs.~Compiled
Languages}\label{interpreted-vs.-compiled-languages}}

Before diving into Python's execution methods, it's helpful to
understand the distinction between interpreted and compiled languages:

\hypertarget{compiled-languages}{%
\subsection{Compiled Languages}\label{compiled-languages}}

In compiled languages like C++, Java, or Rust: 1. The entire source code
is translated to machine code (or bytecode) before execution 2. The
compilation process creates an executable file 3. The resulting program
runs independently of the original source code 4. Errors are detected
during the compilation phase 5. The program typically runs faster but
requires a compilation step before each execution

\hypertarget{interpreted-languages}{%
\subsection{Interpreted Languages}\label{interpreted-languages}}

In interpreted languages like Python, JavaScript, or Ruby: 1. The code
is executed line by line at runtime 2. No separate compilation step is
required 3. The interpreter reads and executes the source code directly
4. Errors may not be detected until the specific line is executed 5. The
program can be more interactive but might run slower than compiled code

This distinction is why Python allows for interactive execution
environments where you can type code and see results immediately - a
significant advantage for learning, prototyping, and data exploration.

\textbf{\emph{AI Tip: When debugging Python code, use the interactive
interpreter to test small sections of your code in isolation. You can
copy and paste snippets directly to verify they're working as expected
before integrating them into your larger program.}}

\hypertarget{the-python-interpreter}{%
\section{3. The Python Interpreter}\label{the-python-interpreter}}

The most basic way to execute Python code is line by line within the
standard Python interpreter. After installing Python, you can start the
interpreter by typing \texttt{python} at your system's command prompt:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ExtensionTok{$}\NormalTok{ python}
\ExtensionTok{Python}\NormalTok{ 3.10.4 }\ErrorTok{(}\ExtensionTok{default,}\NormalTok{ Jun 5 2023, 09:35:24}\KeywordTok{)}
\ExtensionTok{[GCC}\NormalTok{ 11.3.0] on linux}
\ExtensionTok{Type} \StringTok{"help"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"copyright"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"credits"}\NormalTok{ or }\StringTok{"license"}\NormalTok{ for more information.}
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Once the interpreter is running (indicated by the
\texttt{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}} prompt), you can
type Python commands directly and see immediate results:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}} \DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{1}
\DecValTok{2}
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ x }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5}
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ x }\OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{3}
\DecValTok{15}
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}} \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello, Python!"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{Hello, Python}\OperatorTok{!}
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}} \ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ math}
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ math.sqrt(}\DecValTok{16}\NormalTok{)}
\FloatTok{4.0}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

The Python interpreter is excellent for: - Testing quick ideas -
Exploring language features - Experimenting with libraries - Learning
Python syntax - Debugging small code segments

To exit the Python interpreter, type \texttt{exit()} or press Ctrl+D (on
Unix/Linux/Mac) or Ctrl+Z followed by Enter (on Windows).

\hypertarget{the-enhanced-ipython-interpreter}{%
\section{4. The Enhanced IPython
Interpreter}\label{the-enhanced-ipython-interpreter}}

While the standard Python interpreter works well for basic needs, the
IPython interpreter offers many enhancements that make interactive
Python work more productive and enjoyable. IPython (Interactive Python)
is included with most Python distributions like Anaconda, or can be
installed separately with \texttt{pip\ install\ ipython}.

Launch IPython by typing \texttt{ipython} at the command prompt:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ExtensionTok{$}\NormalTok{ ipython}
\ExtensionTok{Python}\NormalTok{ 3.10.4 }\ErrorTok{(}\ExtensionTok{default,}\NormalTok{ Jun 5 2023, 09:35:24}\KeywordTok{)}
\ExtensionTok{Type} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}copyright\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}credits\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{ or }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}license\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{ for more information}
\ExtensionTok{IPython}\NormalTok{ 8.4.0 }\AttributeTok{{-}{-}}\NormalTok{ An enhanced Interactive Python. Type }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}?\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{ for help.}

\ExtensionTok{In} \PreprocessorTok{[}\SpecialStringTok{1}\PreprocessorTok{]}\NormalTok{: }
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

IPython offers numerous improvements over the standard interpreter:

\hypertarget{enhanced-inputoutput}{%
\subsection{Enhanced Input/Output}\label{enhanced-inputoutput}}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{In [}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{]: }\DecValTok{1} \OperatorTok{+} \DecValTok{1}
\NormalTok{Out[}\DecValTok{1}\NormalTok{]: }\DecValTok{2}

\NormalTok{In [}\DecValTok{2}\NormalTok{]: x }\OperatorTok{=} \DecValTok{5}

\NormalTok{In [}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{]: x }\OperatorTok{*} \DecValTok{3}
\NormalTok{Out[}\DecValTok{3}\NormalTok{]: }\DecValTok{15}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{tab-completion}{%
\subsection{Tab Completion}\label{tab-completion}}

Start typing a command or variable name and press Tab to auto-complete:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{In [}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{]: }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ mat[TAB]}
\NormalTok{         math     matplotlib     matrices     ...}

\NormalTok{In [}\DecValTok{4}\NormalTok{]: math.s[TAB]}
\NormalTok{         math.sin    math.sqrt    math.sinh    ...}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{rich-help-system}{%
\subsection{Rich Help System}\label{rich-help-system}}

Add a question mark to get help on any object:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{In [}\DecValTok{5}\NormalTok{]: math.sqrt?}
\NormalTok{Signature: math.sqrt(x, }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{Docstring: Return the square root of x.}
\NormalTok{Type:      builtin\_function\_or\_method}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{system-shell-access}{%
\subsection{System Shell Access}\label{system-shell-access}}

Run shell commands with a leading exclamation mark:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{In [}\DecValTok{6}\NormalTok{]: }\OperatorTok{!}\NormalTok{ls}
\NormalTok{data.csv    myprogram.py    images}\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{   README.md}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{magic-commands}{%
\subsection{Magic Commands}\label{magic-commands}}

Special commands prefixed with \texttt{\%} (line magics) or
\texttt{\%\%} (cell magics):

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\NormalTok{In [}\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{]: }\OperatorTok{\%}\NormalTok{time }\BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{range}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{1000000}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{CPU times: user }\FloatTok{24.5}\NormalTok{ ms, sys: }\FloatTok{0.03}\NormalTok{ ms, total: }\FloatTok{24.6}\NormalTok{ ms}
\NormalTok{Wall time: }\FloatTok{24.6}\NormalTok{ ms}
\NormalTok{Out[}\DecValTok{7}\NormalTok{]: }\DecValTok{499999500000}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

IPython is ideal for: - Interactive data exploration - More productive
development sessions - Learning complex libraries - Quick system
operations without leaving Python

To exit IPython, type \texttt{exit()} or press Ctrl+D.

\hypertarget{self-contained-python-scripts}{%
\section{5. Self-Contained Python
Scripts}\label{self-contained-python-scripts}}

For more complex programs or code you want to reuse, you'll want to save
your Python code in files rather than typing it interactively. By
convention, Python scripts use the \texttt{.py} file extension.

Here's how to create and run a simple Python script:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Create a text file named \texttt{hello.py} with the following content:
\end{enumerate}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# hello.py {-} A simple Python script}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Hello from Python script!"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{name }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"What\textquotesingle{}s your name? "}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"Nice to meet you, }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{name}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{!"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\setcounter{enumi}{1}
\tightlist
\item
  Run the script from the command line:
\end{enumerate}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ExtensionTok{$}\NormalTok{ python hello.py}
\ExtensionTok{Hello}\NormalTok{ from Python script!}
\ExtensionTok{What}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}s your name? Alice}
\StringTok{Nice to meet you, Alice!}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

You can also create more complex scripts with multiple functions,
classes, and modules:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# calculator.py {-} A simple calculator script}

\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ add(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{+}\NormalTok{ b}
    
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ subtract(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{{-}}\NormalTok{ b}
    
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ multiply(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{*}\NormalTok{ b}
    
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ divide(a, b):}
    \ControlFlowTok{if}\NormalTok{ b }\OperatorTok{==} \DecValTok{0}\NormalTok{:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return} \StringTok{"Error: Division by zero"}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ a }\OperatorTok{/}\NormalTok{ b}

\CommentTok{\# Main program}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Simple Calculator"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}{-}"}\NormalTok{)}

\NormalTok{first }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{float}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter first number: "}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{second }\OperatorTok{=} \BuiltInTok{float}\NormalTok{(}\BuiltInTok{input}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Enter second number: "}\NormalTok{))}

\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{first}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ + }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{second}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ = }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{add(first, second)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{first}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ {-} }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{second}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ = }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{subtract(first, second)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{first}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ * }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{second}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ = }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{multiply(first, second)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\SpecialStringTok{f"}\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{first}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ / }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{second}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{ = }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{divide(first, second)}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Python scripts are excellent for: - Programs meant to be run repeatedly
- Code shared with others - Command-line utilities - Automation tasks -
Applications with defined inputs and outputs

\hypertarget{making-python-scripts-executable-on-unix-like-systems}{%
\subsection{Making Python Scripts Executable on Unix-Like
Systems}\label{making-python-scripts-executable-on-unix-like-systems}}

On Linux, macOS, and other Unix-like systems, you can make Python
scripts directly executable:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Add a ``shebang'' line at the top of your script:
\end{enumerate}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\#!/usr/bin/env python3}
\CommentTok{\# rest of your script follows...}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\setcounter{enumi}{1}
\tightlist
\item
  Make the script executable:
\end{enumerate}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ExtensionTok{$}\NormalTok{ chmod +x hello.py}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\setcounter{enumi}{2}
\tightlist
\item
  Run it directly:
\end{enumerate}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ExtensionTok{$}\NormalTok{ ./hello.py}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{working-with-jupyter-notebooks}{%
\section{6. Working with Jupyter
Notebooks}\label{working-with-jupyter-notebooks}}

Jupyter notebooks represent a revolutionary way to combine code, text,
multimedia, and visualizations in a single interactive document.
Originally developed for Python (as ``IPython notebooks''), they now
support many programming languages and have become essential tools for
data science, teaching, and interactive computing.

A Jupyter notebook consists of a sequence of cells, which can contain: -
Executable code (in Python or other languages) - Formatted text using
Markdown - Mathematical equations using LaTeX - Interactive
visualizations - Images, videos, and other media

\hypertarget{starting-jupyter}{%
\subsection{Starting Jupyter}\label{starting-jupyter}}

If you have Anaconda installed, you can start Jupyter with:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ExtensionTok{$}\NormalTok{ jupyter notebook}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Or for the newer Jupyter Lab interface:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ExtensionTok{$}\NormalTok{ jupyter lab}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

This will open a web browser interface where you can create, edit, and
run notebooks.

\hypertarget{using-notebooks}{%
\subsection{Using Notebooks}\label{using-notebooks}}

A typical workflow in a Jupyter notebook might look like:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Create a markdown cell to explain your analysis:
\end{enumerate}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\FunctionTok{\# Data Analysis Example}
\NormalTok{This notebook demonstrates loading and analyzing a CSV file of sales data.}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\setcounter{enumi}{1}
\tightlist
\item
  Add a code cell to load and explore data:
\end{enumerate}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ pandas }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ pd}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ matplotlib.pyplot }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ plt}

\CommentTok{\# Load data}
\NormalTok{sales }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ pd.read\_csv(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}sales\_data.csv\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Display first few rows}
\NormalTok{sales.head()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\setcounter{enumi}{2}
\tightlist
\item
  Add a visualization:
\end{enumerate}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# Create a bar chart of sales by region}
\NormalTok{plt.figure(figsize}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{(}\DecValTok{10}\NormalTok{, }\DecValTok{6}\NormalTok{))}
\NormalTok{sales.groupby(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}region\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}amount\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{].}\BuiltInTok{sum}\NormalTok{().plot(kind}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}bar\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{plt.title(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Sales by Region\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{plt.ylabel(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}Total Sales ($)\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{plt.tight\_layout()}
\NormalTok{plt.show()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\setcounter{enumi}{3}
\tightlist
\item
  Add more explanatory text:
\end{enumerate}

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\FunctionTok{\#\# Findings}
\NormalTok{The Northeast region shows the highest sales volume, followed by the West.}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Jupyter notebooks are ideal for: - Data analysis and exploration -
Scientific research - Teaching and learning - Creating rich, interactive
narratives - Sharing reproducible research - Documenting code with
context

\hypertarget{saving-and-sharing-notebooks}{%
\subsection{Saving and Sharing
Notebooks}\label{saving-and-sharing-notebooks}}

Jupyter notebooks are saved with the \texttt{.ipynb} extension. They can
be shared in several ways: - As \texttt{.ipynb} files (requires Jupyter
to view) - Exported to HTML, PDF, or other formats - Via notebook
sharing platforms like GitHub or Google Colab - Using nbviewer
(https://nbviewer.org/)

\hypertarget{choosing-the-right-environment}{%
\section{7. Choosing the Right
Environment}\label{choosing-the-right-environment}}

Each Python execution environment has its strengths and ideal use cases.
Here's a quick guide to help you choose:

\begin{longtable}[]{@{}
  >{\raggedright\arraybackslash}p{(\columnwidth - 4\tabcolsep) * \real{0.3421}}
  >{\raggedright\arraybackslash}p{(\columnwidth - 4\tabcolsep) * \real{0.2632}}
  >{\raggedright\arraybackslash}p{(\columnwidth - 4\tabcolsep) * \real{0.3947}}@{}}
\toprule\noalign{}
\begin{minipage}[b]{\linewidth}\raggedright
Environment
\end{minipage} & \begin{minipage}[b]{\linewidth}\raggedright
Best for
\end{minipage} & \begin{minipage}[b]{\linewidth}\raggedright
Not ideal for

Python Interpreter & Quick tests, learning, exploring & Complex
programs, saving work \\
IPython & Interactive exploration, enhanced development & Production
code, sharing with non-technical users \\

analysis, visualization \\

\end{longtable}

Consider these factors when choosing: - Are you exploring or building? -
Do you need to save and reuse your code? - Is visualization important? -
Will you share your work with others? - Do you need to incorporate
documentation with your code? - Is your task one-time or recurring?

\hypertarget{self-assessment-quiz-20}{%
\section{8. Self-Assessment Quiz}\label{self-assessment-quiz-20}}

Test your understanding of Python execution environments:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\tightlist
\item
  Which of the following describes Python as an interpreted language?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Python code must be compiled before running
  \item
    Python code is executed line by line at runtime
  \item
    Python code cannot be saved to files
  \item
    Python code runs faster than compiled languages
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  In the standard Python interpreter, which prompt indicates the
  interpreter is ready for input?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{In\ {[}1{]}:}
  \item
    \texttt{\$}
  \item
    \texttt{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}}
  \item
    \texttt{Python\textgreater{}}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of these is a feature of IPython that isn't available in the
  standard Python interpreter?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    The ability to define functions
  \item
    Tab completion
  \item
    Running arithmetic operations
  \item
    Importing modules
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  What file extension is conventionally used for Python script files?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    \texttt{.pyc}
  \item
    \texttt{.python}
  \item
    \texttt{.py}
  \item
    \texttt{.ipy}
  \end{enumerate}
\item
  Which of the following is NOT a typical component of a Jupyter
  notebook?

  \begin{enumerate}
  \def\labelenumii{\alph{enumii})}
  \tightlist
  \item
    Markdown cells for documentation
  \item
    Code cells that can be executed
  \item
    Compiled binary output
  \item
    Interactive visualizations
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Answers:} 1. b) Python code is executed line by line at runtime
2. c) \texttt{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}} 3. b) Tab
completion 4. c) \texttt{.py} 5. c) Compiled binary output

\hypertarget{project-corner-running-your-chatbot-in-different-environments}{%
\section{Project Corner: Running Your Chatbot in Different
Environments}\label{project-corner-running-your-chatbot-in-different-environments}}

Now that you understand the various ways to run Python code, let's see
how we can adapt our chatbot project to work in different environments.

\hypertarget{chatbot-in-the-python-interpreter}{%
\subsection{Chatbot in the Python
Interpreter}\label{chatbot-in-the-python-interpreter}}

The interpreter is great for testing small parts of your chatbot:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}} \ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ chatbot.response\_manager }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ ResponseManager}
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ bot }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ ResponseManager(}\StringTok{"TestBot"}\NormalTok{)}
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ bot.get\_response(}\StringTok{"hello there"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{\textquotesingle{}Hi there, Alice!\textquotesingle{}}
\OperatorTok{\textgreater{}\textgreater{}\textgreater{}}\NormalTok{ bot.get\_response(}\StringTok{"what\textquotesingle{}s your name"}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{"Alice"}\NormalTok{)}
\CommentTok{"I\textquotesingle{}m TestBot, your chatbot assistant!"}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{chatbot-as-a-script}{%
\subsection{Chatbot as a Script}\label{chatbot-as-a-script}}

Create a self-contained script that runs the chatbot from the command
line:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# chatbot\_cli.py}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ chatbot.main }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ run\_chatbot}

\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{"\_\_main\_\_"}\NormalTok{:}
    \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{"Starting Chatbot CLI"}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    run\_chatbot()}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

Run it with:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\ExtensionTok{$}\NormalTok{ python chatbot\_cli.py}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{chatbot-in-a-jupyter-notebook}{%
\subsection{Chatbot in a Jupyter
Notebook}\label{chatbot-in-a-jupyter-notebook}}

Create an interactive notebook version of your chatbot for demonstration
or teaching:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# In a Jupyter notebook cell}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ chatbot.main }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ Chatbot}
\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ ipywidgets }\ImportTok{as}\NormalTok{ widgets}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ IPython.display }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ display, clear\_output}

\CommentTok{\# Create a chatbot instance}
\NormalTok{bot }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Chatbot(name}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"JupyterBot"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Create input and display widgets}
\NormalTok{messages }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ []}
\NormalTok{output }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ widgets.Output()}
\NormalTok{text\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ widgets.Text(description}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"You:"}\NormalTok{, placeholder}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"Type a message..."}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{send\_button }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ widgets.Button(description}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"Send"}\NormalTok{)}

\CommentTok{\# Display interface}
\NormalTok{display(output)}
\NormalTok{input\_box }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ widgets.HBox([text\_input, send\_button])}
\NormalTok{display(input\_box)}

\CommentTok{\# Define interaction behavior}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ on\_send\_clicked(b):}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ text\_input.value}
    \ControlFlowTok{if} \KeywordTok{not}\NormalTok{ user\_input:}
        \ControlFlowTok{return}
        
    \CommentTok{\# Clear input box}
\NormalTok{    text\_input.value }\OperatorTok{=} \StringTok{""}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Add user message to display}
\NormalTok{    messages.append(}\SpecialStringTok{f"You: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{user\_input}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Get bot response}
\NormalTok{    bot\_response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ bot.get\_response(user\_input)}
\NormalTok{    messages.append(}\SpecialStringTok{f"JupyterBot: }\SpecialCharTok{\{}\NormalTok{bot\_response}\SpecialCharTok{\}}\SpecialStringTok{"}\NormalTok{)}
    
    \CommentTok{\# Update display}
    \ControlFlowTok{with}\NormalTok{ output:}
\NormalTok{        clear\_output()}
        \ControlFlowTok{for}\NormalTok{ message }\KeywordTok{in}\NormalTok{ messages:}
            \BuiltInTok{print}\NormalTok{(message)}
    
\CommentTok{\# Connect button click to handler}
\NormalTok{send\_button.on\_click(on\_send\_clicked)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{chatbot-as-a-web-application}{%
\subsection{Chatbot as a Web
Application}\label{chatbot-as-a-web-application}}

For a more advanced implementation, you could create a web version using
Flask:

\begin{Shaded}
\begin{Highlighting}[]
\CommentTok{\# web\_chatbot.py}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ flask }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ Flask, render\_template, request, jsonify}
\ImportTok{from}\NormalTok{ chatbot.main }\ImportTok{import}\NormalTok{ Chatbot}

\NormalTok{app }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Flask(}\VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{bot }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ Chatbot(name}\OperatorTok{=}\StringTok{"WebBot"}\NormalTok{)}

\AttributeTok{@app.route}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}/\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ home():}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ render\_template(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}chat.html\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}

\AttributeTok{@app.route}\NormalTok{(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}/get\_response\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, methods}\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}POST\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{])}
\KeywordTok{def}\NormalTok{ get\_bot\_response():}
\NormalTok{    user\_input }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ request.json[}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}message\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{]}
\NormalTok{    user\_name }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ request.json.get(}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}user\_name\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{, }\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}User\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{)}
\NormalTok{    response }\OperatorTok{=}\NormalTok{ bot.get\_response(user\_input)}
    \ControlFlowTok{return}\NormalTok{ jsonify(\{}\StringTok{\textquotesingle{}response\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{: response\})}

\ControlFlowTok{if} \VariableTok{\_\_name\_\_} \OperatorTok{==} \StringTok{\textquotesingle{}\_\_main\_\_\textquotesingle{}}\NormalTok{:}
\NormalTok{    app.run(debug}\OperatorTok{=}\VariableTok{True}\NormalTok{)}
\end{Highlighting}
\end{Shaded}

\hypertarget{choosing-the-right-environment-for-your-chatbot}{%
\subsection{Choosing the Right Environment for Your
Chatbot}\label{choosing-the-right-environment-for-your-chatbot}}

Different environments suit different stages of chatbot development:

\begin{enumerate}
\def\labelenumi{\arabic{enumi}.}
\item
  \textbf{Interactive Interpreters (Python/IPython)}: Best for testing
  individual components, debugging, and rapid development.
\item
  \textbf{Script-Based}: Ideal for the final product that users can run
  easily from the command line.
\item
  \textbf{Jupyter Notebook}: Perfect for demonstrating how your chatbot
  works, testing different scenarios, and collaborative development.
\item
  \textbf{Web Application}: Best for sharing your chatbot with a wider
  audience who may not have Python installed.
\end{enumerate}

As you continue to develop your chatbot, you'll likely use multiple
environments - interactive interpreters during development, scripts for
deployment, and perhaps notebooks for documentation and demonstrations.
